story:
Short Summary

I have been a nurse for 23 years and have dedicated my career to mothers and babies. I am also a neonatal nurse practitioner and my dream has always been to improve the health of babies to the point where neonatal intensive care units are no longer needed! I completed my doctorate degree from Vanderbilt University’s School of Nursing in December. My research project was to develop a survey for mothers that asks them if the education they received before giving birth adequately prepared them for making the best choices for them and their babies. I believe that by giving mothers the information that they need at the right time and in a way that they can understand and use will improve the health of mothers and babies. My survey was developed using the latest evidence on patient satisfaction, childbirth education, and health outcomes. There has been little research in improving childbirth education since the 1990’s so this work is important and long overdue. By improving childbirth education we can better prepare mothers and improve the morbidity and mortality of mothers and babies in the United States and internationally!

What We Need & What You Get

I need to make my survey available for nurse educators to use to improve their childbirth class curriculum and to incorporate culturally appropriate information as appropriate. I was accepted to do a 30 minute oral presentation at the 25th annual international Sigma Theta Tau (nursing honor society) conference in Hong Kong in July, 2014 to present my research. I need funding to pay for the travel and hotel accommodations to do so. I am so excited to get to present my findings and survey to an international audience! The cost of airfare, lodging, and conference tuition is $6000. If I do not meet my goal I will use the funding to implement my survey in Atlanta, Georgia hospitals.

The Impact

While global rates of maternal mortality decreased 34% between 1990 and 2008, maternal deaths nearly doubled in the United States during the same period.  The infant death rate in the United States is higher than the rate for most developed countries, due to a significantly higher percentage of preterm births. In addition, considerable differences in infant mortality rates between various racial and ethnic groups have persisted and, in some cases, increased. Contributing factors include the changing demographics of childbearing women, the decreased health status of the Americans overall, low levels of health literacy, and decreased access to quality health care information. My project will serve to improve access to quality healthcare information.

Other Ways You Can Help

I am willing to share my survey tool with organizations and individuals that are interested in improving the quality of their childbirth or prenatal education programs. Please contact me.

story:
Dear Friends and Family, 

We have been selected to represent Centennial State (Colorado) at the 2014 National Miss American Coed Pageant in Florida during the week of Thanksgiving this year.

As Miss Centennial State Sweetheart and Princess, we will be competing for the National Pageant title and thousands of dollars in college scholarships. Since 1983, millions of dollars in college scholarships have been presented to outstanding girls at state and national competitions. We will be competing in the talent, academic achievement, community service, photogenic, personality, and modeling contests. American Coed Pageants, Inc., recognizes and rewards outstanding young women between the ages of three and twenty-three for their past and present accomplishments and encourages us to set and achieve high goals for the future.

As part of this honor and opportunity, we are encouraged to seek sponsorships and donations to assist us with the pageant costs. Our parents have already had to provide additional pageant costs including formal dresses, coaching sessions, dance lessons, and photo sessions on top of other duties. Because the both of us will be competing this year, the costs are double. 

The costs of the pageant include:

Pageant Registration: $1200 x 2 = $2400

Performance fees: $500 x 2 = $1000

Airline Tickets: $600 x 2 =                   $1200

Hotel: 7 nights x $200 =           $1400

Food:                                                                     $500

Total                                                                      $6500 

As you can see, we have a lot of money to rise. We are asking for your support with some of the costs. Your support will help us as future leaders take part in an experience that will help us gain poise, self-confidence and valuable communication skills.

As a prospective supporter/sponsor your name(s), company’s name, and/or organization’s name will be listed in the digital National Miss American Coed Pageant program booklet. You will also be able to request a hyperlink from the digital program booklet to your company’s website. Your sponsorship is tax deductible as an advertising expense for businesses.

Thank you for your support and consideration. Please let us know if there is anything that we can do for you.

 Sincerely, 

Tiegan Martinez, Miss Centennial State Sweetheart

Teya Martinez, Miss Centennial State Princess

story:
Short Summary

My name is Omar and I'm bi-polar. I've been battling medical bills for the past 2 years. My biggest payment is when i broke my wrist and I didn't have insurance. Bills from when I was sent to the emergency room for constant vomiting even when I had medical. I reached very low point in my life one month ago when I thought suicide was a good idea. When I thought it was okay to have a permanent solution to a temporary problem. I committed myself and swallowed my pride and asked for help like I am today. I am currently seeking help at rock springs mental wellness clinic in Georgetown Texas but the cost of being an inpatient has caused a serious of events, good and bad. I decided to not return to work due to the major emotional and physical stress it's played on me so I lost my medical insurance due to that so that is why I am asking for help.

What We Need & What You Get

I owe about 1500 to the clinic just for my inpatient stay and I am currently working out the payments for being an outpatient. My prescribed medicine is well priced so I'm not too worried about that. I am still waiting for the bills to arrive for when I went to the ER the night I committed myself and I already owe them around 1000 for my visit in april.

Overall anything would help me but my goal is at least 600 so I can return to school by the end of the month. 

The Impact

I've never been more ready to start my physical therapy assistant degree.

Risks & Challenges

Starting my life, especially given my medical condition, is a challenge itself. But for the first time in my life I've never been more terrified and excited for the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Seriously anything helps. Whether it be helping me money wise or with just friendly advice. I will forever be grateful. Thank you so much

story:
The GOAL.

Hi everybody!

First off thanks for stopping by, your support and contributions are greatly appreciated!

My name is Louisa Clarke. I am a recent graduate from Ithaca College, graduating with a B.A. in Cultural Anthropology. I have explored several cultures throughout my studies, ranging from Native American studies, to the study of Ethnomusicology and the sacred tabla, to the studies of Genocide in Cambodia, and so on. However, my Anthropology courses have led me to a persistent interest that has been unquenchable since I took my first class on South East Asian cultures. My interest in India first began when taking an Introduction to Buddhism course my sophomore year, and my courses since then have provided me with substantial information on the Indian experience, including hands on experience with instruments such as the tabla for several months.

Now more than ever do I feel ready to take this education and create change with it.

For the next several months, I will prepare to travel and teach in India through a TEFL course online, which will provide me with the necessary tools needed to teach English as a second language. The course has a fee of 300 dollars, but ensures a position at a local school in New Delhi. Education is an important tool for young kids to learn in a foreign country.  Knowing a language as widespread as English can  provide them with many opportunities, especially in the workplace.

My aim is to stay in India for at least 4-5 months, teaching, exploring, and taking in the culture. Calculating all costs, I would need at least 2,000 dollars overall, including travel costs, program fees ( can be up 1000 to enroll ), and cost of living. I am aware of what an extreme amount of money this is, so I am only asking for half of that, as I am working full time to save enough money to take care of the travel costs and cost of living. I truly feel that this will be worth the effort, and that with your help real change can be created.

The goal: 1400.

$300- TEFL Certification

$1,000 flight to New Delhi.

$1,000 for Enrollment Teaching

Once again, I am only asking for your help in the Enrollment process as I am doing what I can work-wise to provide the rest of the funds needed for the trip. Every penny is greatly appreciated! I know how hard every one works for their money, and I express the highest amount of gratitude to those who choose to help me along on my journey. I am beyond excited to continue my experience in volunteering abroad, having traveled to Nicaragua several years ago, and working at an NGO geared towards peace between differing nations and cultures. This is one of my passions in life, and by contributing you're pushing me one step forward to fulfilling my dreams, and spreading education, passion, inspiration, creativity and the value of an education to hundreds of children.

“What lies behind you and what lies in front of you, pales in comparison to what lies inside of you.” – Ralph Waldo Emerson

For more information on the program, and additional inquries please check out the information below:

http://www.experienceteachingabroad.com/tefl-heaven-india-synopsis-of-teaching-english-in-india/

Your contributions are invaluable! Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
My Name is Paul and I am a 22 year old ordinary guy from Germany.

Since I have been in Israel for the first time of my life a few years ago I am dreaming of studying in Tel Aviv. During my many stays there I was lucky to experience a notable sense of philantrophy and while I was traveling the country the local people taught me many times that there is always a way to reach your goal. All the friendly people I met and the friends I made encouraged me to keep on this dream.
For many years now I have taken each step towards this direction despite all the financial problems which happened to inhibit me and I finally reached the almost last step:
I got accepted for the Bachelor program of Electrical and Electronics Engineering at Tel Aviv University's International School of Engineering.
Unfortunately the program requires an annual tuition of 12.500$.
Since I am from a lower middle class family I am not able to afford this amount.

I checked almost every possibilty of finding a scholarship or a loan, but it seems like in the end money is the great barrier which I can not cross.
Determined to find a solution for that problem I came up to try this crowdfunding project.
The idea is that if I get enough money for the first two years I will be able to start studying and search for a better option while being around.
If I can find 5000 people who donate 5 $ for my purpose I can finally realize my dream.

That might sound impossible and maybe it is, but for me it is a better option than giving up so close.
To be honest:


Why should you donate for me ?

It is true, I am just an unknown person who has got plans to study and can not afford it.

For you there is no other reason to donate except supporting someone who needs help.
I can tell you that I would do exactly the same for you at any time.

Furthermore a lot of people might dislike the fact that I want to study in Israel but in my opinion Israel is a great country that is worthy of support.

I promise that if the project does not collect enough money and as a consequence I will not be able to go to Tel Aviv I will donate the money to a non-profit children in need organization.

If you got any further questions or want to make sure that I am a real person please check my Facebook profile:



https://www.facebook.com/paul.mierau.7?ref=tn_tnmn

story:
In a Nutshell

We have started this campaign to develop support to move the Community Transitions Project forward and develop training materials for the “Speaking” Civilian transition workshop. This program has been highly successful and popular so far. The “Speaking” Civilian workshop has been offered three times at Joint Base Lewis-McChord, and is part of a recurring transition course. At this point, we are looking to scale up. The resources generated by this campaign will support 3-4 people on a part-time basis to develop the training materials, a website, and push the CTP and “Speaking” Civilian to the next level.

Who is the Community Transitions Project?

The Community Transitions Project (CTP) was founded on work done by Dylan Medina, a Ph.D. student at the University of Washington in Seattle. Concerned over the challenges facing service members as they reintegrate into civilian life, and seeing massive funding cuts to transition services, Dylan recognized that his research in how people learn to communicate and function in new communities could help. Leah Rankin, Ann Shivers-McNair, and Olivia Hernandez, also graduate students at the University of Washington, have joined Dylan to found and advance the CTP.

Our Mission is to support the transitions individuals make between communities by providing training that helps them achieve greater agency and control as they make the transition. Currently we are focusing on service members’ transitions between military and civilian life, but we hope in the future to expand the mission to other groups that face challenging transitions.

What is “Speaking” Civilian?

“Speaking” Civilian, and the CTP, differ from other transition programs because it focuses on the often forgotten aspect of “fitting in.” This program draws on research in Education, Rhetoric and Composition, and Cognitive Psychology to help participants learn to see the cultural conventions of the communities they will be entering. These individuals will then be in a better position to figure out how to act and communicate in ways that “fit in.” Fitting is important because failing to do so makes it difficult to find jobs and be a member of the community.

Training Outcomes

·  To learn a theory of discourse that allows service members to see culture as a system of conventions and practices that they can learn.

·  To develop an approach to analyzing the conventions of unfamiliar communities.

·  To gain an increased awareness of their own resources and strategies for acting and communicating.

·  To begin to learn how to make use of these resources in civilian contexts.

·  To develop a disposition that allows service members to figure out how to integrate effectively into civilian communities.

Where are we now?

Over the last year, Dylan has been able to provide a training for VetCorp volunteers and has established the “Speaking” Civilian workshop at Joint Base Lewis-McChord. The workshop was offered first as a pilot in November 2013, and thanks to positive participant feedback, was incorporated as an important piece of a new transition course, Northwest Edge. “Speaking” Civilian has since been offered twice as part of Northwest Edge in 2014. It will be offered a third time in June.

Additionally, we have received requests for training materials so that components of “Speaking” Civilian and the entire workshop can be available to a larger group of transitioning service members. To be able to invest the time in creating these training materials, we have set up this campaign to generate public support.

The Plan—Moving Forward

In response to requests we have received for training materials so that “Speaking” Civilian can be more widely available to transitioning service members, we have put together this campaign to generate the public support we need to be able to invest the time in creating these materials. Along with training materials, we will work to build a web presence and continue to support instructors of the “Speaking” Civilian workshop as part of Northwest Edge.

Here’s our plan:

·  Further develop the curriculum for use at other sites. This means work to generalize the specifics of the “Speaking” Civilian that is part of Northwest Edge.

·  Produce a training manual that will include syllabi, original readings, sample exercises, and an instructor guide to the theory behind the workshop.

·  Produce a training video that demonstrates some of the central components of “Speaking” Civilian.

·  Build a website to distribute these training materials and to act as a hub for the Community Transitions Project and future “Speaking” Civilian instructors.

·  All materials will be produced in electronic format for easy distribution. We believe in open access, and so will work to ensure that the materials are freely available.

Here’s where you come in!

We are seeking $20,000 to move this project forward.

The majority of these funds will support 3-4 people part-time through the summer to produce the training materials and website. While all of the work on this project so far has been volunteer, these resources will allow us to invest the time necessary to make high-quality training materials.

Another portion of these funds will be used for building, hosting, and maintaining the web presence. Additionally, we will support instructors for future sessions of “Speaking” Civilian for their time, course material, and transportation costs.

With your help, we’ll be able to take this already successful program and begin to scale up. In the long term who hope to establish a non-profit allow the Community Transitions Project to provide valuable training and support into the future.

Perks to show our appreciation:

·  Everyone who contributes will receive a Thank You email and will be able to say they have taken a material step to support our troops.

·  Supporters contribute at least $25 and will receive a Thank You card (if a mailing address is provided) and recognition on the CTP’s website for their support of our service members.

·  Sponsors contribute at least $100 will receive the Thank You card, recognition as a Sponsor on the CTP website, and a shout out on the CTP Twitter feed.

·  Patrons contribute at least $2000 and will receive special recognition and a short bio on the CTP website, a handwritten letter with our thanks, and co-producer credits in the training manual and video.

The Impact

The training provided by the Community Transitions Project has already made a challenging transition easier by helping service members learn how to figure out their fit in civilian settings. This will allow them to remix the valuable knowledge, skills, and experience they gained through their service for civilian settings. With your support, the Community Transitions Project will be able to reach more service members with the training that already has and will continue to make a real difference in service members’ lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

While we’re asking for funding in this campaign, there are other ways to get involved if you can’t contribute financially.

Take a moment to spread the word about this campaign! If you think it’s valuable, tell your friends. Share the campaign on social media. Use the tools that we’re providing to make some noise.

Most importantly, consider how we in our communities welcome or ostracize newcomers. Transition is largely about fit, and an open, accepting community makes fitting in easier. The choice of whether a community is hostile or welcoming comes down to us.

members to figure out how to integrate effectively into civilian communities. 
Where are we now?
Over the last
year, Dylan has been able to provide a training for VetCorp volunteers and has
established the “Speaking” Civilian workshop at Joint Base Lewis-McChord. The
workshop was offered first as a pilot in November 2013, and thanks to positive
participant feedback, was incorporated as an important piece of a new
transition course, Northwest Edge. “Speaking” Civilian has since been offered
twice as part of Northwest Edge in 2014. It will be offered a third time in
June. 
Additionally,
we have received requests for training materials so that components of “Speaking”
Civilian and the entire workshop can be available to a larger group of
transitioning service members. To be able to invest the time in creating these
training materials, we have set up this campaign to generate public support. 
The Plan—Moving Forward
In response
to requests we have received for training materials so that “Speaking” Civilian
can be more widely available to transitioning service members, we have put
together this campaign to generate the public support we need to be able to
invest the time in creating these materials. Along with training materials, we
will work to build a web presence and continue to support instructors of the “Speaking”
Civilian workshop as part of Northwest Edge. 
Here’s our plan:
· 
Further
develop the curriculum for use at other sites. This means work to generalize
the specifics of the “Speaking” Civilian that is part of Northwest Edge.
· 
Produce
a training manual that will include syllabi, original readings, sample
exercises, and an instructor guide to the theory behind the workshop. 
· 
Produce
a training video that demonstrates some of the central components of “Speaking”
Civilian.
· 
Build
a website to distribute these training materials and to act as a hub for the
Community Transitions Project and future “Speaking” Civilian instructors.
· 
All
materials will be produced in electronic format for easy distribution. We
believe in open access, and so will work to ensure that the materials are
freely available.
Here’s where you come in!
We are
seeking $20,000 to move this project forward. 
The majority
of these funds will support 3-4 people part-time through the summer to produce
the training materials and website. While all of the work on this project so
far has been volunteer, these resources will allow us to invest the time
necessary to make high-quality training materials.
Another
portion of these funds will be used for building, hosting, and maintaining the
web presence. Additionally, we will support instructors for future sessions of “Speaking”
Civilian for their time, course material, and transportation costs.
With your
help, we’ll be able to take this already successful program and begin to scale
up. In the long term who hope to establish a non-profit allow the Community
Transitions Project to provide valuable training and support into the future. 
Perks to show our
appreciation:
· 
Everyone who contributes will receive a Thank
You email and will be able to say they have taken a material step to support
our troops.
· 
Supporters
contribute at least $25 and will receive a Thank You card (if a mailing address is provided) and
recognition on the CTP’s website for their support of our service members.
· 
Sponsors
contribute at least $100 will receive the Thank You card, recognition as a
Sponsor on the CTP website, and a shout out on the CTP Twitter feed.
· 
Patrons
contribute at least $2000 and will receive special recognition and a short bio
on the CTP website, a handwritten letter with our thanks, and co-producer
credits in the training manual and video.
The Impact
The training
provided by the Community Transitions Project has already made a challenging
transition easier by helping service members learn how to figure out their fit
in civilian settings. This will allow them to remix the valuable knowledge,
skills, and experience they gained through their service for civilian
settings. With your support, the Community Transitions Project will be able to
reach more service members with the training that already has and will continue
to make a real difference in service members’ lives. 
Other Ways You Can Help
While we’re
asking for funding in this campaign, there are other ways to get involved if
you can’t contribute financially.
Take a moment
to spread the word about this campaign! If you think it’s valuable, tell your
friends. Share the campaign on social media. Use the tools that we’re providing
to make some noise.
Most
importantly, consider how we in our communities welcome or ostracize newcomers.
Transition is largely about fit, and an open, accepting community makes fitting
in easier. The choice of whether a community is hostile or welcoming comes down
to us.

story:
The Story

I had a famously huge crush on my boyfriend years before we started dating. We've been together for 10 years now ... and long before he proposed to me, I had the liberty to decide that this was the person I wanted to share the rest of my life with.

He is smart, kind, and fair. He lifts me up to reach for the stars and he empowers me to be my best. We support each other to live to our fullest potential and to be happy in life. It's a mutual agreement we both have the liberty to commit to every day for the rest of our days. 

But there are millions of girls out there who don't have such liberty. 

1 in 3 girls in the developing world will be married before the age of 18.

Across countries, cultures, and religions, girls are forced to marry because of tradition, gender roles, and poverty. When it happens, girls are robbed of their childhood and denied their fundamental rights to health, education, and security. 

Imagine if you, or your favourite woman/girl in your life, was uneducated and living in poverty. She would be at risk of dropping out of school, sexual violence, contracting HIV/AIDS, forced marriage, becoming pregnant too early, and dying during childbirth. An education, a few resources, and a system of support could change all of that. 

Everyone deserves the opportunity to reach their potential and take control of their future. That's why we hope you'll join us to provide that for girls in Uganda.

Help us raise $1,000 for
the Girl Power Project®

The Girl Power Project® is a community-based training program that empowers girls living in poverty. It's a program that was developed by a partnership between Just Like My Child Foundation and local attorneys in Uganda who are working to empower women and girls in rural areas. Now, the Girl Power Project® is empowering communities to create the "girl effect" in central Uganda.

The "girl effect" is what happens when investments are made in women and girls. It initiates a ripple effect of change that contributes to improved health and nutrition, and reduces infant mortality. It also raises economic productivity and increases the chances of education for the next generation.

HOW IT WORKS:  Local community members lead workshops in impoverished rural communities where girls (and their families) learn how to avoid early marriage, early pregnancy, and diseases like HIV/AIDS and malaria. Girls who really excel in the workshops are invited to attend a weekend long camp retreat, where they develop their leadership skills to become mentors for other girls like them. They graduate as Girl Power Project® Peer Mentors, equipped to empower girls in their communities to stay in school, resist peer pressures, and avoid early pregnancy, marriage, and disease.

THE IMPACT: $1,000 will send  10 exceptional girls to Camp Girl Power. Each girl that graduates is a Peer Mentor who is committed to empowering 100 other girls in her community. By investing in the Girl Power Project®, we're giving girls living in poverty opportunities they didn't have before to know their rights, protect their bodies, and to stay in school so they can take control of their future.

Every contributor to our campaign will receive updates from the ground with stories from Girl Power Project® workshops, Camp Girl Power, and the girls we're investing in. We challenge you though to make a bigger impact by redeeming one (or several) of our lovely perks. 

Help Spread the Word! 

The share buttons above are just as impactful as contributing money. Double your impact by donating AND sharing this campaign with Friends/Family. Let's see how many times we can get Matt to fulfil the Barbour Challenge Perk.

story:
About Us!

Hello,

We are Emily and Danielle and we belong to the most amazing church, which is Grace Family Church in Lutz Florida!!  God has offered us the chance to go on a missions trip to Ireland with our High School Youth Group and Missionary Ventures.

This missions trip will be reaching out and spreading the gospel to people in Sligo, Ireland.  We will also be learning more about the people there and their culture.  Many of you may think why Ireland? Ireland isn't a country impoverished. The reason for this mission trip to Ireland is purely spiritual. Did you know that less than 1% of Ireland’s population professes a relationship with Jesus Christ?  The goal of this mission trip is to help with outreaches in towns and communities, reaching people with the message of Jesus Christ, helping aide local pastors' ambitions of doing God's work and to see leadership developed and spread.

While God has opened up a door for us to develop more compassionate hearts for His people around the world, we will need prayers and funding to go on this missions trip. The cost of the trip for each of us is $2,500.00.

We look forward to doing God's work in Ireland!  Thank you for your support, God Bless!

Each $20 donation will recieve an "I Supported Ireland Mission Trip" t-shirt.

To find out more about this trip you can visit the following page:  

http://ericandlyndsey.weebly.com/index.html

 

Here is the link for our amazing youth group at our church!

http://gfconline.com/connect/youth/the-move/

story:
BRING JACK HOME

Jack Culolias is a first year student at ASU, and has been missing for more than two  weeks. As of right now we still really don't know much about his dissappearance or how it came about. We've found a shoe and a picture, but the family is still looking for closure. All we know is that we are missing a great friend and family member, and a wonderful person to be around. Jack is still out there and he needs our help.

Jack's last reported sighting was outside of the Cadillac Ranch restaurant in Tempe Marketplace around 11 o'clock. He was escorted out of the restaurant around then, and nothing else has been reported. With such little information available about this incident, we need ALL the support we can possibly get to help bring our boy home. He is around 6 feet tall, and has brown hair and brown eyes. 

With all of this going on, Jack's family has gone through so much, and I can only imagine how they are coping with this. More and more days pass with no news, and all we can pray for at this time is closure. His family needs extreme love and support right now, and so do his brothers. An entire community has been brought together by this event, and its all because of the wonderful smile of Jack. Jack has influenced more people than he may never know, and thats a true testament to the kind of awesome person he is. 

Our contribution requests are simple. We don't need much, just a lot of people to make small contributions, although we will take as much as you can give. The last page we created raised over 6,000 dollars in twelve days, mostly in dollar and 5 dollar contributions. Although Jack's family had to return home, they are in desperate need of any help possible. This money has been used to provide his families travel accomodations, awareness items like T-shirts and bands, private investigators, lawyers, and in the worst circumstances, funeral accomodations. 

If you cannot make a financial contribution, please contribute in other ways! We have a facebook group and are trending on twitter, and these resources can be used to get involved in hundreds of ways. If you have any information or photographs please contact Tempe police. Also, if you have any contribution ideas post them on the facebook page. 

With all this being said, we appreciate everyones continued support and concerns. It's been so amazing to see every one come together like this, and we need this love right now. Keep spreading the word and lets BRING OUR BOY JACK HOME. 

Jack we love you so much, and we all miss you. Stay safe and hang in there bud, you've got a whole world of love and support. 

facebook group:https://www.facebook.com/groups/556856114328864/

PURCHASE T-SHIRTS PLEEEASSSEE AT - http://www.payitsquare.com/collect-page/9011

story:
We are the people that live along the mountains--Nuučan̓uł, which sounds like nuu-chah-nulth. In the media I create I use the International Phonetic Alphabet to reflect the language as my ancestors spoke it.  There are elders who can claim our language is their first language, but there isn’t enough of those speakers to hear our language spoken in everyday life.  With your help I will continue to encourage, through social media, a growing interest to learn our language before it becomes silent.  I currently post to facebook on Nuuchahnulth Speaker, a page I created to connect to people who want to hear the language. I would like to continue this work and expand it. The expanded  work would be to process more material, so that everyone can have more frequent exposure to hearing our language through more frequent posting.  It's a valuable participation to come and listen because it will imprint the Nuuchahnulth language patterns.  With your donation I will also upgrade equipment, pay honorariums to an elder speaker for assistance, as well as attain software to explore creating animated language lessons.  To share my appreciation your perk will say “hii-shuk-ish tsa-waak / Everything is One”,  a Nuučan̓uł belief.  I appreciate your support, share the campaign!  ƛeekoo, ƛeekoo. 

 

The target for the L.O.L campaign is $25,000. Fortunately, I am not asking for that whole $25,000 dollars from just you. Unless, your generous heart also has deep pockets:) Suggested donation amounts (through paypal or credit card) are between $5-$25,000. They each come with a donation perk . If you can’t part with $5 right now, please share this campaign with 5 most likely people to donate on your facebook. There is a higher chance for this fundraising campaign to become a “featured campaign” and greater chance for its success if it’s a featured campaign. It nurtures our spirit to hear our own language. And it will tell the world how we describe life, how rich our culture is. ƛeekoo, ƛeekoo

 

*Perks are going to be sent at the end of the campaign :)

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Aujenee' and I have been selected by People to People and my teachers to be a People to People Student Ambassador!  Our destination is "Canadian Cultures". I am a 5th grader at a charter school and have always been allowed to progress at my own pace.  This manner of education has allowed me to excel academically.  I am an A student and love school, helping people, and managing through daily challenges.  I mention challenges because the past two years have been extremely hard for me and my family.  My brother was murdered and we are "finally" trying to move forward the best that we can.  I want to go so badly on this educational venture and just begin to 'live' again.  Not only will this excursion allow me to do that, it will also allow me to grow while experiencing another culture. I NEED to go on this trip!  I am soooo excited about the opportunities to learn and help others while in Canada.

 

Won't you PLEASE help me attend this 12 day once in a lifetime excursion?  Although I have worked hard for the past several months I have been unable to reach my goal of $5000.00.  I have raised $1500.00 so far through fundraiser campaigns, bake sales, gift wrapping, working as an actress, and forgoing Christmas gifts in exchange for sponsorships.  I am still trying very hard but need YOUR help!  

 

If you help fund my trip it would not only benefit me.  My community, school, friends, peers, girl scout troop, kids church, and everyone I meet will benefit as well.  You probably guessed it by now...I'm a big talker!  I'm excited about learning through experience about Canada, its' history, people, and their culture. As an Ambassador it is my duty to share this knowledge.  To me it is an opportunity to learn not about our differences BUT the indifferences amongst us.  We are ALL more alike than unalike.  We are not threats to one another, we are brothers and sisters, equals willing to accept one another as friends.  As your Ambassador i will befriend everyone I meet and leave them with a warm feeling of genuine friendship.

 

This excursion will allow me to prove this as well as prepare me for my future. It will teach me to be independent and regain trust in others, meet new people that I may have never met, become a leader and speaker of the acceptance of others that don't look or act like you, and it's going to look good on my college resume (0:  

 

This opportunity was not handed to me, I earned it through studying and hard work.  I love school and understand its importance.  I don't take this priviledge lightly.  I know it costs a lot of money. Unfortunately, my mom just can't swing it alone.  She is supporting me and helping the best she can but I don't want to stress her further.  I want to lift her spirits by making her proud of me through this honor. Thank you for helping me and believeing in me!

 

PLEASE SUPPORT MY DREAM OF MAKING A DIFFERENCE IN THE WORLD THROUGH BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF [CULTURAL] DIFFERENCES.

Where Does Your $$ Go:

Breaking it down:

*Airfare

*Housing

*Meals

*Activities

*To making a little girl's heart smile & do flips

What Will We (yes, you too...through Me) Do:

*Visit beautiful waterfalls & wildlife

*Visit historic sites, architecture, artifacts & museums

*Observe sporting events

*Meet politicians & learn about their governmental process

*Eat!!  Customary meals

*Hike

*Hangout with native Canadians & other well deserving students

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Thank you donating to my dream experience.  Another way you can help me is by spreading my campaign to family & friends.  Please feel free to make some noise on my behave!  Indiegogo has cool share tools to help you help me.

For more information about People to People please visit:

http://peopletopeople.com/find/local/na/canadia...

story:
Bigger, Boulder, Better

Hello everyone, thank you for taking the time to read this.

We want to put up the best conference on Breaktrough Energy ever.

Due to popular demand and much enthusiasm we have already started planning the 2013 conference. This time we are bringing GlobalBEM to the United States! 

Here is where you come in:

We didn't break even with our 2012 conference, but thanks to private sponsors we were able to make it happen. That’s why this time we want to get YOU involved and support the cause. We want to spread the word about breakthrough energy technologies and its implications. We can't make this conference happen and bring this wealth of information to the world without your help.

On top of our running costs/operational costs, we have an urgent milestone that we need your help with. Our goal is to raise $30,000 with this campaign to cover airline and hotel reservations for our speakers and team.

Can you envision a world free of fossil fuels, that is both economically sustainable and environmentally responsible?

Meet the team:

Project Story:

One of the major goals of GlobalBEM is organizing conferences to give exposure and bring awareness about Breakthrough Energy. Last November we held our first very successful conference, and we struggled to make it happen. With a combination of no funding, and slow ticket sales, we we almost didn't make the budget and being able to present the mind blowing program we had put together for our audience. Ultimately, because of private Dutch sponsors we were able to make it happen. The 2012 Hilversum, Holland conference was informative, entertaining and unique on many levels.

Our 2013 conference will be held at the University of Colorado in Boulder from October 10th-12th, 2013. 

 

This conference will be even more epic than the 2012 conference, our network has increased since this last conference and we have many supporters. One of our major supporters being the Thrive movement. 

Why Boulder? Boulder is known for being a very progressive city in the US. Since 2006 it has been committed to reducing its carbon footprint. Their drive is to ensure that its residents have access to reliable and clean power. Boulder, CO has engaged the local community to participate in the planning for an energy future that is both sustainable and environmentally friendly. 

 

The University of Colorado Boulder has been pursuing energy research for many years. Their dedication to sustainability is a direct reflection on campus life and within the boulder community. 

 

Check out the link below and read more about how CU-Boulder sets an examples in this field.

http://www.colorado.edu/sustainability

Who we are and what our mission is:

Global Breakthrough Energy Movement is an independent foundation driven by volunteers with the primary goal to facilitate the widespread awareness and use of Breakthrough energy technology and its implications. 

What began as a small group quickly evolved into a wide international network of people from diverse backgrounds including scientists, researchers, academics, artists, and business holders. While the core team is based in the Netherlands, the network spans our entire globe.

We define Breakthrough Energy Technology as an abundant energy source, which produces zero-emissions, that can provide clean, safe, healthy, reliable and affordable energy solutions.

Many of these technologies are based on principles of advanced physics, and include, but are not limited to — over-unity devices, magnet motors, cold fusion, vortex, zero-point and advanced hydrogen.

GlobalBEM will support and promote promising inventions in the field of Breakthrough Energy with the objective to bring these solutions to available applications without restriction.   

GlobalBEM will facilitate and coordinate the innovators’ initiatives in providing comprehensive evaluations in a professional and confidential environment.  

GlobalBEM will create a tantalizing platform to inform and attract all stakeholders to bring these technologies to full production and use to a common acceptance and realization. 

GlobalBEM will use its momentum and reputation to promote funding/donation initiatives, research and marketing in close relation to the interests of stakeholders.

 We defined three main goals for GlobalBEM:

1. Conferences:  Annually unite great minds and innovators from all over the world to share their knowledge, present their technologies and discuss further steps for development and deployment of Breakthrough Energy Technologies. 

2. Educational Resource Document: To create a rich and widely accessible media resource for the purpose of informing and activating the broader public about the history, mechanics and implications of Breakthrough Energy Technologies.

3. Global Movement:  Initiating and acting as a facilitator for a global community, a reunion of humanity calling for the new energy paradigm.


MAKE A CONTRIBUTION TODAY, AND TOGETHER WE CAN FREE THE ENERGY!!

Thank you for your ongoing support and interest.

Be well, see you in Boulder !
 
The GlobalBEM team

globalbem.com
globalbemvoices.com
facebook.com/globalbem
twitter.com/globalbem
youtube.com/user/globalbem
soundcloud.com/globalbem

Bigger, Boulder, Better

Hello everyone, thank you for taking the time to read this.
We want to put up the best conference on Breaktrough Energy ever.
Due to popular demand and much enthusiasm we have already started planning the 2013 conference. This time we are bringing GlobalBEM to the United States! 
Here is where you come in:
We didn't break even with our 2012 conference, but thanks to private sponsors we were able to make it happen. That’s why this time we want to get YOU involved and support the cause. We want to spread the word about breakthrough energy technologies and its implications. We can't make this conference happen and bring this wealth of information to the world without your help.
On top of our running costs/operational costs, we have an urgent milestone that we need your help with. Our goal is to raise $30,000 with this campaign to cover airline and hotel reservations for our speakers and team.

story:
(*NOTE: We are thrilled to have doubled our funding goal. However, the actual amount needed is FAR higher than our funding goal, so your generosity is still very much needed and appreciated!!! Let's see if we can raise $15,000!!)

 

"De'Jaun belongs to all of us now."

I sat in the pews of the church in Savannah, GA on December 10, 2011 as Ed DuBose, the president of NAACP's Georgia State Conference uttered those words.

I was at the funeral of De'Jaun's mother, Martina Davis-Correia, just two months after my last funeral in Savannah: for De'Jaun's uncle, Troy Davis, who had been unjustly executed by the state of Georgia. Virginia Davis--Troy and Martina's mother, De'Jaun's grandmother--had passed five months before Troy was executed.

I first met De'Jaun when he was fourteen years old, and was speaking in New York as the keynote speaker for the NAACP's youth conference in parallel to their centennial. I was amazed at how poised, insightful, and articulate this young man was. An uncle on death row and a mother with terminal cancer had made De'Jaun wise beyond his years.

The more I interacted with De'Jaun over the years that followed, (as I got more involved in Troy's case and began writing a book with his mother Martina) the more I realized--this is a special young man, with incredible gifts to offer the world. Troy, Martina, and Virginia all knew it--their dearest wish was for De'Jaun to get a top-rate education and to develop his full potential.

I am asking you to help De'Jaun realize his potential, utilize his gifts, and pursue the opportunity of a lifetime.

De'Jaun has been accepted to Morehouse College, where Martin Luther King Jr. once studied. It is the school of his dreams.

After all that this young man has lived through in his 18 years, he deserves so much to have the chance to pursue his goals (which are to obtain a dual degree in electrical engineering and business) at an educational institution that is not only excellent and arduous, but that shares De'Jaun's commitment to social justice and social change.

De'Jaun needs our help to fulfill his dreams, and to realize Troy, Martina, and Virginia's hopes for him.

I hope you will contribute what you can, and use Indiegogo's sharing tools to get the word out so that others can do the same. (*Note: the total amount needed far exceeds the $4300 funding goal, so if we can surpass that goal, all the better!)


With Martina, Troy, and Virginia gone, Ed DuBose's words keep ringing in my ears:

"De'Jaun belongs to all of us now."


With great hopes for De'Jaun's future,

Jen Marlowe
www.donkeysaddle.org

(This campaign is approved by the Davis family.)

(If you would like to contribute $1,000 or more, please send a check made out to:

"I Am Troy Davis Fund"

and mail it to:

Kimberly Davis

PO Box 2105

Savannah, GA 31407)

story:
The Nanaimo Aboriginal Centre (NAC) is a non profit organization serving the urban Aboriginal community in Nanaimo/Ladysmith.  NAC’s vision is to see every Aboriginal student graduate high school.  We believe this work must begin with early childhood education.

In 2011/12 the graduation rate for Aboriginal students in Nanaimo Ladysmith was 49.9%, for all students it was 71.6% and for all students in the province of BC the grad rate was 81.8%. There are successful support models that exist today that realize graduation rates between 90 ad 100%. Nanaimo Aboriginal Centre believes we can achieve this here in Nanaimo if we collaborate and commit to a long-term and comprehensive strategic plan.

The work at Nanaimo Aboriginal Centre will focus on these key areas:

  • Prevention
  • Early Childhood Development
  • Culture, Language & Connection to the Land
  • Outreach
  • Best Practices & Research
  • Evaluation
  • Collaboration

NAC recognizes the critical importance of supporting healthy human development between conception and Kindergarten.  These formative years are, as research indicates, critical in terms of setting the stage for success in school and beyond.  NAC also appreciates that public agencies, organizations and families must work together in order to realize the vision of supporting every child to graduate high school.  While NAC will focus on the early years we will invite collaboration with those groups who share the vision of providing support to students through elementary, secondary and into post-secondary grades.

                             

Our Board of Directors for 2013/14 includes Michael Leggett, Paige Fisher, David Drakeford, Rachele Beaulieu, Mike Herold, Terri Mack, Jarrett Walter and Joan Brown.  Our Executive Director is Chris Beaton.

Funds raised through this campaign will be used to support developmental activities for Nanaimo Aboriginal Centre.  We will develop funding proposals, formally define our Mission Statement and Vision, expand our membership base and continue to speak with community, public agencies, government and the private sector to invite their involvement.  We have already:

  • established an Aboriginal Family Night program (in partnership with the Mid Island Metis Nation)
  • begun a Community Profile Project
  • secured the first Aboriginal Accounting Mentorship program in Nanaimo
  • presented to several local Rotary Clubs & met with dozens of community groups
  • established a Child Friendly Cities Working Group
  • established a After School Program Working Group
  • secured funding for a Native Soccer Tournament in May 2014 in Nanaimo
  • established a presence on social media - Facebook and Twitter
  • initiated a education focused research project in partnership with VIU

All good work that requires staff time and resources.   Our new website will be operational in a few weeks.

We invite you to partner with us by making a donation.  Join us in supporting success for Aboriginal students.

Please share with friends and family.  Hay ch qa (thank you).

story:
Our Story

We are two young sexual health educators who are serving in Illinois as Chicago Health Corps AmeriCorps members. As sexual health educators, we are charged with providing sex-positive, comprehensive sexual health education to 9th and 12th grade students in local Chicago Public schools. In order to learn more we are planning to attend the 26th annual conference held April 13th-15th by the Civil Liberties and Public Policy program called From Abortion Rights to Social Justice: Building the Movement for Reproductive Freedom (http://clpp.hampshire.edu/2012-conference). We both feel incredibly privileged to spend a year interacting with and learning from Chicago youth but our modest stipends make it hard for us to afford plane tickets from Chicago, IL to Massachusetts for the conference.


The Impact

We hope to bring back new strategies for our classroom that will help us better address the needs and wants of todayâ€™s youth. We also hope to increase our awareness and knowledge about transphobia, racism, sexism, heterosexism, ableism, etc. in order to intentionally create a classroom of acceptance and learning. We also acknowledge that this learning will reach far beyond our one year of AmeriCorps service. We plan to use the knowledge and skills that we gain at the conference to inform our personal and professional goals lifelong. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

$220 to cover the cost of two participants at the conference

$780 to cover the cost of two round trip airfares from Chicago, IL to Massachusetts 

 

If we are unable to reach our fundraising goal we will try to personally fund the remaining cost. If this is not possible we will donate money raised on Indiegogo to the conference. This will help defray the cost of other participants who cannot afford to pay the full registration fee. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can do to help spread the word would be awesome. 

Tell all your friends!

Post a link on your facebook, twitter, blog, etc! 

Contribute with a group of people! 

Ask your company/organization/volunteer locations to contribute!

story:
Short Summary

 

Hello all,

My name is Kimberly Nguyen. I am a poet and a math student at Carleton University. This year, I will be participating in the Alternative Spring Break program at school.

Here is a brief description of what it's all about (directly from Carleton's website):
"Participants will travel to Vancouver, British Columbia where they will focus on the issue of urban poverty within Canada. The city of Vancouver grew from its oldest neighourhood – the Downtown Eastside, which is the poorest postal code in Canada. Students will visit the streets of this neighourhood which are a transitional home for thousands, serve with a variety of partners in the city focusing on anti-poverty and housing-rights organizations, and will have the opportunity to listen to guest speakers on these issues."

I will be staying in the Downtown Eastside of Vancouver during reading week, which is from February 16th to 24th, with my ASB group from Carleton. During that week, we will be working with local partners and providing services in the community. We will be visiting Insite, North America's first legal supervised injection site, and we will be talking to sex workers to learn about these issues.

This will be a great opportunity for me to learn and experience something I am passionate about, "first world" poverty. As a poet, it is very important for me to speak upon things which people need to hear about but usually don't. My goals as a poet are to provoke thought and inspire, and also to educate. To be able to do these things, it is crucial for me to not only know, but to understand. This trip will definitely inspire me, and hopefully help me create art that can inspire others.

Every donation to this campaign will be a part of making that possible.


To donate directly to the program (either to me personally OR to the general fund for other students as well), you can visit this link:
https://cu-fyeo.ca/programs/asb/donate.php

To learn more about the program, you can click here:
http://www6.carleton.ca/seo/community-service-learning/alternative-spring-break/

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Flying to the other side of the country is not cheap.

This trip is going to cost $2000 (I put my goal as 2180 because this site charges a 9% fee), which is just over two months work of work for me, as an overnight cashier at Loblaws (before taxes and deductions).

The money goes directly to Carleton's ASB program and it covers my flight, stay, and meals for the week (so basically everything I'd need for that week). I will be going for the week of February 16 - 24, 2013.

What's in it for you:

10$ - You will get a spoken word/music/cover CD that I am working on.

20$ - You will get that CD, and I will make a drawing/painting of whatever   you want.

50$ - You will get the above things PLUS I will write a song for you about anything you want, post it on youtube and give you a shoutout.

100$ - All of the above PLUS I will sing a song for you live and buy you dinner.

 

If I don't reach my goal by then, whatever donations I receive will still help reduce my fees. If I do go over my goal, the donations I receive will go to helping me to travel to Vancouver again in April for the Canadian Individual Poetry Slam (where I will be representing Ottawa's Urban Legends poetry slam and competing for the National Champion title and a spot at World's Individual Poetry Slam).

 

 

The Impact

A question you may ask is: "Why don't we just donate the money to the hungry?"

If you feed a man for now, he'll go hungry again later.

Giving money to the poor is a nice gesture, and it may help, but only temporarily at best. If you walk around downtown, just handing money out to people you think need it, you won't see where it goes. It is possible that people will use your money for drugs or alcohol, but realistically, you can't expect someone to go and pay rent with the toonie you just tossed them. A better way to donate is through organizations like the Food Bank, but even then, their website even says 'Money doesn't end hunger'.

Not only do I want to make a change, I would like to make a lasting impact. I really feel like it's not extremely unrealisticto do so, and this experience will give me a lot of ideas on how and where to start. It will mean a lot to me to be able to experience actually working with this community first hand.

 

Another question you may have is: "How do we know we can trust you?"

For those who know me, you know my intentions are pure. As for those who don't, I have provided a link in the summary section for you to read more about the ASB program and a link where you can donate to other students as well. I have also included a video of one of my poems, and I will attach another poem at the bottom of the page.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you believe in me, but don't have the money, you can help me out by spreading the word about my campaign. Share it, tweet it, put it on your tumblr, tell everyone you know. 

 

 

 

 

Hunger Games                                 

   -a poem by Kimbit

 

If only we could care for stray humans half as much as we cared for stray cats.
If only we paid half as much attention to the homeless man who mentions that any change we spare can help him
To buy a meal because he's hungry and he can't afford to pay that.

You see, with stray cats,
When they follow us around,
We don't seem to mind so much.
We may even stop just to pet them, try to befriend them;
We don't mind so much when they want our attention
While the guy lying there is dying to get some,
But he dares not approach us because he knows we don't let him
So much as make eye contact or say hi, let alone get in
A few words to explain why he's out here begging

So he doesn't even bother, he just sits there in silence.
Keeping calm, he carries on, blending in with the sidewalk
And whenever I walk by, I feel like this is somehow my fault,
So I stop and I talk to him for a minute,
Or rather, I listen
To see how he's gotten here and see what I can give him.
But at the same time, I'm cautious because some guys can talk us
Into giving them change not for food, but narcotics.

Well, sir,
If you're hungry, that's a McDonalds, just there
Let me get you some food - oh, you want change for bus fare?
All right, that's cool, too; I'll get you some tickets from the Zesty's.
Oh.. you still just want the change, huh? Well then you better forget me.
I refused to be responsible for helping you get high
And you just ruined anything possible like that for the next guy.

You see, stray cats don't lie
Or try to play us like that,
So it might be understandle why we would handle them better,
But it's still pretty messed up how
Life for some are better at an animal shelter,
How some people's dreams are to be treated like an animal;
They see those "Water For Your Dog" bowls and wish that their cup could be just half as full

Why is it that when speaking of hunger, people only refer to the kids starving in Africa
And neglect the fact that kids are here, starving in our capital.
It's factual, I'll have you know
That kids make up 37% of people who use food banks.
That's out of 45,000 people
Per month, here in Ottawa!

You don't have to do math to tell that this don't add up.
How are so many still starving in a city so developped?
They are right under our noses, but we look up too much to notice.
Trying to keep our own bellies swollen where we keep our focus.
And I don't even know 45,000 folks, but
That's 5.5 per cent of the city's population,
And if we can't get that down to zero,
Then how do we expect to get rid of "third world" starvation?

Now, don't get me wrong... I'm not suggesting that we stop trying or give up.
I just wanted to emphasize on how much this sucks.
And there's no way I can single-handedly put an end to this;
If only I posessed the power of periods following sentences.
However, the power I do posess is in my penmanship;
How legible I light these lines, write these rhymes, and make clear these messages.
Telling it just how it is, trying to make a difference,
But I'm still pretty much powerless if I don't deliver this.
Though perhaps the powers in parliament could try and push away this problem.
Probably.
I mean, I know they can, but don't, so I'll take a stand and speak upon it.

I could spend all day texting M-E-A-L to 45678
But despite any donations made, the problem stays because dollars
Aren't all that makes the calls on whether or not they're starving.
This problem will only be solved when our hearts stop being hollow.
story_txt:
Short Summary
 
Hello all,
My name is Kimberly Nguyen. I am a poet and a math student at Carleton University. This year, I will be participating in the Alternative Spring Break program at school.
Here is a brief description of what it's all about (directly from Carleton's website):"Participants will travel to Vancouver, British Columbia where they will focus on the issue of urban poverty within Canada. The city of Vancouver grew from its oldest neighourhood – the Downtown Eastside, which is the poorest postal code in Canada. Students will visit the streets of this neighourhood which are a transitional home for thousands, serve with a variety of partners in the city focusing on anti-poverty and housing-rights organizations, and will have the opportunity to listen to guest speakers on these issues."
I will be staying in the Downtown Eastside of Vancouver during reading week, which is from February 16th to 24th, with my ASB group from Carleton. During that week, we will be working with local partners and providing services in the community. We will be visiting Insite, North America's first legal supervised injection site, and we will be talking to sex workers to learn about these issues.
This will be a great opportunity for me to learn and experience something I am passionate about, "first world" poverty. As a poet, it is very important for me to speak upon things which people need to hear about but usually don't. My goals as a poet are to provoke thought and inspire, and also to educate. To be able to do these things, it is crucial for me to not only know, but to understand. This trip will definitely inspire me, and hopefully help me create art that can inspire others.
Every donation to this campaign will be a part of making that possible.
To donate directly to the program (either to me personally OR to the general fund for other students as well), you can visit this link:https://cu-fyeo.ca/programs/asb/donate.php
To learn more about the program, you can click here:http://www6.carleton.ca/seo/community-service-learning/alternative-spring-break/
 
 


What We Need & What You Get
Flying to the other side of the country is not cheap.
This trip is going to cost $2000 (I put my goal as 2180 because this site charges a 9% fee), which is just over two months work of work for me, as an overnight cashier at Loblaws (before taxes and deductions).
The money goes directly to Carleton's ASB program and it covers my flight, stay, and meals for the week (so basically everything I'd need for that week). I will be going for the week of February 16 - 24, 2013.
What's in it for you:
10$ - You will get a spoken word/music/cover CD that I am working on.
20$ - You will get that CD, and I will make a drawing/painting of whatever   you want.
50$ - You will get the above things PLUS I will write a song for you about anything you want, post it on youtube and give you a shoutout.
100$ - All of the above PLUS I will sing a song for you live and buy you dinner.
 
If I don't reach my goal by then, whatever donations I receive will still help reduce my fees. If I do go over my goal, the donations I receive will go to helping me to travel to Vancouver again in April for the Canadian Individual Poetry Slam (where I will be representing Ottawa's Urban Legends poetry slam and competing for the National Champion title and a spot at World's Individual Poetry Slam).
 
 


The Impact
A question you may ask is: "Why don't we just donate the money to the hungry?"
If you feed a man for now, he'll go hungry again later.
Giving money to the poor is a nice gesture, and it may help, but only temporarily at best. If you walk around downtown, just handing money out to people you think need it, you won't see where it goes. It is possible that people will use your money for drugs or alcohol, but realistically, you can't expect someone to go and pay rent with the toonie you just tossed them. A better way to donate is through organizations like the Food Bank, but even then, their website even says 'Money doesn't end hunger'.
Not only do I want to make a change, I would like to make a lasting impact. I really feel like it's not extremely unrealisticto do so, and this experience will give me a lot of ideas on how and where to start. It will mean a lot to me to be able to experience actually working with this community first hand.
 
Another question you may have is: "How do we know we can trust you?"
For those who know me, you know my intentions are pure. As for those who don't, I have provided a link in the summary section for you to read more about the ASB program and a link where you can donate to other students as well. I have also included a video of one of my poems, and I will attach another poem at the bottom of the page.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you believe in me, but don't have the money, you can help me out by spreading the word about my campaign. Share it, tweet it, put it on your tumblr, tell everyone you know. 
 
 
 
 
Hunger Games                                 
   -a poem by Kimbit
 
If only we could care for stray humans half as much as we cared for stray cats.If only we paid half as much attention to the homeless man who mentions that any change we spare can help himTo buy a meal because he's hungry and he can't afford to pay that.
You see, with stray cats,When they follow us around, We don't seem to mind so much.We may even stop just to pet them, try to befriend them;We don't mind so much when they want our attentionWhile the guy lying there is dying to get some, But he dares not approach us because he knows we don't let himSo much as make eye contact or say hi, let alone get inA few words to explain why he's out here begging
So he doesn't even bother, he just sits there in silence.Keeping calm, he carries on, blending in with the sidewalkAnd whenever I walk by, I feel like this is somehow my fault,So I stop and I talk to him for a minute,Or rather, I listenTo see how he's gotten here and see what I can give him.But at the same time, I'm cautious because some guys can talk usInto giving them change not for food, but narcotics.
Well, sir,If you're hungry, that's a McDonalds, just thereLet me get you some food - oh, you want change for bus fare?All right, that's cool, too; I'll get you some tickets from the Zesty's.Oh.. you still just want the change, huh? Well then you better forget me.I refused to be responsible for helping you get highAnd you just ruined anything possible like that for the next guy.
You see, stray cats don't lieOr try to play us like that,So it might be understandle why we would handle them better,But it's still pretty messed up how Life for some are better at an animal shelter,How some people's dreams are to be treated like an animal;They see those "Water For Your Dog" bowls and wish that their cup could be just half as full
Why is it that when speaking of hunger, people only refer to the kids starving in AfricaAnd neglect the fact that kids are here, starving in our capital.It's factual, I'll have you knowThat kids make up 37% of people who use food banks.That's out of 45,000 people Per month, here in Ottawa!
You don't have to do math to tell that this don't add up.How are so many still starving in a city so developped?They are right under our noses, but we look up too much to notice.Trying to keep our own bellies swollen where we keep our focus.And I don't even know 45,000 folks, butThat's 5.5 per cent of the city's population,And if we can't get that down to zero, Then how do we expect to get rid of "third world" starvation?
Now, don't get me wrong... I'm not suggesting that we stop trying or give up.I just wanted to emphasize on how much this sucks.And there's no way I can single-handedly put an end to this;If only I posessed the power of periods following sentences.However, the power I do posess is in my penmanship;How legible I light these lines, write these rhymes, and make clear these messages.Telling it just how it is, trying to make a difference,But I'm still pretty much powerless if I don't deliver this.Though perhaps the powers in parliament could try and push away this problem.Probably. I mean, I know they can, but don't, so I'll take a stand and speak upon it.
I could spend all day texting M-E-A-L to 45678But despite any donations made, the problem stays because dollarsAren't all that makes the calls on whether or not they're starving.This problem will only be solved when our hearts stop being hollow.

story:
Hello friends and family,

My name is Ty the father of the little girl in the pictures you see. The mother of my child is threatening to take my daughter away from me forever. I’ve talk to many different lawyers and they all believe that I should have sole custody of my little girl. I have been threatened by her many times. This includes, but not limited to, moving to Atlanta with my daughter and most recently, falsely accusing me of kidnapping when I pick my daughter up from now. So to protect myself, I’ve been forced to stay away from seeing my daughter since September 3, 2012. She’s six years old now and I may not have the joyous pleasure to see the last twelve years of her childhood. Your contribution will help me fight for this wonderful little girl and to bring her home to me where she belongs. I can’t express how bad it feels to be kept from the one thing that keeps you motivated to be a better person.

The entire $8000 will go directly to my legal fees. The reason it’s so high is because I’ve been stuck with paying two attorneys, my attorney and the GAL (my daughter’s attorney). I’ve been stuck with the higher bill for the GAL attorney fees because my daughter’s mother doesn’t work and has not been able to maintain stable employment since my daughter has been born. I’ve been sitting in quiet desperation for the last six years hoping and praying for a way to end this. I’m so grateful that I found this site where there’s a community of individuals that looks to help others in their time of need.

Any possible assistance you can offer will be greatly appreciated, whether it is donation of $10 or sharing this with your friends and family. The smile on that little girls face is all I care about at. This article is the reason I’m trying so hard to stay in my daughter’s life. So everything I raise will go to directly to the legal fees I will accrue in this custody battle.

As always, I sincerely thank you all,

Ty

story:
Here's the Story

   Sis. Amelah El-Amin from the Oakland Bay Area Community was diagnosed with Stage 1 Breast Cancer in the beginning of February.  Though she made it clear she did not want this to be a public announcement, it has made it to those who care about her personally we would like to make this journey as easy as possible for her. She is committed to healing from this disease and that is her focus. In her words, "I have every intention, by ALLAH's leave,  to HEAL from this Dis-Ease and live free of it for the rest of my life...ALLAHUMA AMEEN

On her behalf we make two requests... One is to make dua for her. Her requested dua is for us to beg ALLAH to alleviate her body of all disease, allow her to heal quickly, and maintain quality health from here on out. Secondly we request, anyone who is able to assist her financially to do so while she is going through the various therapies, possible surgery, and recovery process.

What she needs

Sister Amelah's Monthly Expenses are about 2,000 a month. She currently has two daughters living at home. Please help her to get through this process without the stress of financial hardships insha'Allah. 

 Every Dollar is much appreciated and we thank you in advance. JazahkAllah Khair. 

 

                                -A Poem by Sister Amelah-

Bismillah...13/30

Another's view of us is more accurate I suppose;
and what others find us worthy of is usually not what we would've chose ...

I am greatly humbled by the many efforts currently being taken;
to bring ease to my family while satan whispers we've been forsaken...

Well the devil is a lie; this truth is nothing new;
and when it comes to our CREATOR, there's nothing HE can't do...

Every struggle we encounter is yet another gift;
to raise our spiritual vibrations and give our souls a lift...

If I was the master planner, I would've traveled this road quite silently;
but since I'm merely a servant I accept GOD's decision to have others accompany me...

I just have a few simple ground rules for those coming along for the ride;
that you only bring with you positive vibrations as we're taking this journey in stride...

This has "Created A Necessary Care Experience Rapidly" that I submit to wholeheartedly;
and I truly believe with all I am, through this GOD is bringing ease to me...

So please don't waste precious time on thinking, "How unfortunate for her",
just continue to thank and praise our CREATOR for the miraculous healing about to occur...ALLAHUMA Ameen
