The Indigo Report combines 4 sciences that reveal your strengths, behaviors, motivators and skills.  Based on your unique combination, the report provides you with potential fields of study and career opportunities that you would thrive in.  
To get a better idea of what you can do with this information, let me tell you what my report tells me... about me.  


I'm very high Dominance, high Influencing on the DISC behaviors graph.  High D's tend to be competitive, decisive, and determined. High I's tend to be enthusiastic, persuasive, and optimistic.  I sort-of knew these things about myself, but seeing it in the report and being able to compare my extreme scores to normative samples helped me understand where I will thrive, and what environments I should avoid in the workplace. 
If I had known this at 18, I would have realized that the government career I was pursuing and majoring in was a terrible fit.  I need a fast paced, dynamic environment where I can be a results oriented leader and be free of repetitive and detailed work (low Compliance).    

When you have your DISC scores, you can better choose your classes, field of study, and understand your strengths and weakness when working with other people.    

So what motivates me? 
I'm a passionate Social, and slightly above average Utilitarian, so making money without making an impact on society will never satisfy me.  That's why I started a social enterprise, but always felt repelled by Wall Street. 
Motivators help you know "why" you do the things you do.  I tell students the best way to point yourself in a fulfilling direction is to look at your top two motivators.  For example, if your top motivator is Aesthetic, make sure your college environment provides a harmonious living environment.  Surroundings matter to high Aesthetics.  


Your 26-page Indigo Report reveals this and much more, including higher education options that match your passions. Here are a few options that my report suggested for me.  I didn't even know what an entrepreneur was when I was in college - now there are many opportunities for young entrepreneurs.  Read more details on our website.

_________________

Want to get your report now?  Click on the $50 perk and we will send you a link to take the Indigo within 48 hours.  It takes about 45 minutes and your report will automatically be emailed to you.  

_________________


Our commitment to inclusion:
We created the Indigo Foundation (501c3 status pending)  as part of our company's commitment to inclusion.  The goal of the Indigo Foundation is to provide the Indigo Assessment free of cost to low income students.  Half the money we raise on Indiegogo will be automatically donated to a students in need.  We are already working with several organizations.  

Our first Boys and Girls Club Indigo workshop was held in July via our technology partner, TTI.  Here's what some of the participants had to say:




"I learned what my strengths are and to respect people's differences." Chase

"I learned that the career I am going after matched my
personality type." Vivian

"I learned that we need other people with different
personalities to create a great team." Vanessa

"People should not try to
change others. They are who they are and don't need to change." Harrison



Another of our partners is Project Voyce, a Denver non-profit seeking "to empower youth to create positive change within themselves, their school, their community, and the world."  Listen to the inspired students of Project Voyce share their dreams and perspectives on college and career choices:
 



____________________________

Some of the people we've worked with




_________________________




Indigo Report testimonials:







"It helped me to look at my life in the big picture and to explain why I am me."                  - Santiago A.


"It really gives you a new perspective on what you CAN do with your life and not what you HAVE to do."                  - Allison L.


"This product is the future...            - Jim Maraviglia -- CalPoly University,  ‎Associate Vice Provost

"It makes you realize you have one life and it's worth living well."          – Cully Brown, High School Senior

It actually helps as opposed to personality tests online."          - Taylor C., High School Senior

I've never seen my students so engaged…"             - Vincent Pizziconi -- ASU Department of Bio Engineering, Professor 
"At a recent College Prep Camp, we had over 80 students take the Indigo assessment prior to beginning their college search. For the first time in their young lives, these students got an internal look at themselves, to understand one another as individuals.  Thank you Indigo for helping provide invaluable clarity!"           - Kerstyn Pocklington, Ready.Aim.Future, Founder  

_____________________________
Finding our place in the world

It’s time to encourage students to stop trying to fit in a box and find their own place in the world.  I believe that we all belong and have exquisite gifts to give. One father expressed it this way:

Our son Oliver is going through the college selection process. If those who serve as gate keepers could truly see him, in all his glory, they’d all take him in a moment. 
They’d take him for his wisdom in navigating the difficult choices of adolescence without losing himself. 
They’d take him for the energy wound up in him like a spring, just waiting to be harnessed. 
They’d take him for his calm under pressure; for his smile. 

But then, if we truly saw one another for the gifts we carry, every child would be viewed this way. Everyone would find a welcome somewhere. - Carl Whiting, Professor and Father
_________________

Like what we are up to?                               Join now by selecting a perk                                                                                    - and - Share with your friends.


_________________

A BIG Thank You from our team in Boulder, CO!

story:
Summary

I have grown up in the wilderness across Canada. Spending summers in tree forts 20ft above glacial lakes in British Columbia, being rocked to sleep by waves while we lived on a floating Shark Research Station in an inlet of the Pacific Coast, and exploring the shores of our great inland sea - Lake Superior. I had the pleasure of being raised by a nature loving family, with my fingers in dirt and my nose in plants my whole life. I worked for many years as a Natural Heritage Educator with Ontario Parks sharing this love for nature with others of all ages, and learning how to create information rich educational programs and guided hikes. It is my dream to continue sharing that love for nature through curriculum based outdoor education programs- incorporating technology at times to engage even the most disengaged children. 

Where is the money going? Why?

The $20 000 I am trying to raise will go towards certifying myself within the Ontario Education System (the 9 month program alone is $19000 at CSU), in addition to the time and resources costs required to create a repertoire of guided hikes and educational activities. The first of many of these programs will be ready for September 2015. 

This goal is part of a broader picture where I would like to see Ontario with more curriculum based outdoor education programs in schools, and more systems of alternative education with a natural history focus. I am a strong believer in the importance of engaging children with nature in order to create a healthy respect for natural world around them. 

As a side project, I am also working on writing a series of educational, interactive children's books that will be incorporated into these educational programs. So far these books cover the topics of Tree Identification (The Ultimate Tree Scavenger Hunt), Lichens (The Adventures of Ally the Algae and Frank the Fungi, Witches Hair and Goblin Puke), and Mimicry (Don't Eat Me!).

I realize that if you are funding programs in hopes of receiving a physical product in return, this project does not seem as appealing. That being said, please take the time to consider the importance of your children, your nieces and nephews, your grand children, your neighbours, your community, and children across Ontario's appreciation for the natural world around them, and the impact that this will have on future generations to come. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Right now, the biggest hurdle for this project is funding. The program start date at CSU is August 18th, and through this experience I will be able to further tailor the interpretive programs to the curriculum. Funding the books is important too, and my company Newmaster Publishing Ltd. has started a Kickstarter campaign for that cause. It is important that I have the time and resources to create these programs and ensure I can cover the costs of travelling to different educational conferences to promote them. If I receive an overwhelming response of support I would love to get more people involved and see this program grow across Canada and Internationally!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Although funding is the most important part of this project at the moment, if you have ideas or know people who would like to volunteer their resources to help create more informative and interactive programs, please send them my way (annabelnewmaster@gmail.com)! Spreading the word about this campaign is also very important, please use the share tabs for indiegogo to spread the word!

story:
What is the Chief Sealth-Honduras expedition?

Chief Sealth is a comprehensive high school that offers a wide array of opportunities for students who value learning in a dynamic, multi-cultural environment. It is an exceptional place that celebrates innovation and individuality. As a center of international educational excellence, we provide students opportunities to study the world both in the classroom and beyond.

With the help of the Operation Wallacea Organization a group of students will have the chance to study ecology in the field for two weeks. The Honduras expedition is run in the endemic rich cloud forests of the Cusuco National Park or the lowland forests of the Jeanette Kawas National Park near Tela. The students spend their first week in a forest camp and will be on site with an international team of academics who are collecting data on the carbon, biodiversity and community benefits of the forest. These data are then being used as part of annual reports to help with funding the protection of the Cusuco Park under the Reduction in Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+ scheme) or if based in Tela on packaging the forests for funding under this scheme.

 

The second week will operate from one of the two marine research sites run by Operation Wallacea – Utila or Tela. The main research objective at these sites is to complete annual monitoring of the coral and reef fish communities so the effectiveness of the management strategies at the two sites can be assessed. At both sites, important research on the associated mangrove systems is also being carried out in order to take a holistic approach to tropical coastal ecosystem conservation. Details of student coursework and field study can be found in the Honduras Schools Booklet.

Chief Sealth is a school of very high needs.  Every dollar that you donate will help to open a world of opportunities for an amazing group of young people.

What We Need

This expedition requires funds.  If our group goal of $22,000 is reached, 96% of your donation will go directly to helping fund student travel and OpWall expedition costs.

  • OpWall expeditions cost $1900 US/student + in-country transportation costs (~$200 US/student)
  • Plane travel to Honduras ~$600 US roundtrip
  • If we do not reach our total goal our students will be forced to pay for their trips themselves with funds they might otherwise be using to pay for their future education costs.
  • Any funds beyond the actual costs will be put towards some of the optional training and experiences available to students while they are on expedition (Tree canopy climbing, extra dive activities, etc)! Beyond that residual funds will be used to help make this a sustainable biannual program for students from Chief Sealth International. 


The Impact

Experiencing the world and people outside your own town/state/country can change a person's world view forever.  Contributing to worlds body of knowledge can change the way we interact with our planet. Please help us to gift this amazing group of young students the experience of a lifetime.

The Risks

Trips like this can put undue stress on any family's budget. The longer our group goes without donors the greater the risk of students being forced to drop out of the group, putting the expedition in jeopardy.  Timely donations will help to alleviate this risk! Please consider donating now. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute funds at this time, our students are gladly accepting gently used sleeping bags and rugged backpacks for this expedition.

For more information on Operation Wallacea in Honduras check out their web site here: http://opwall.com/sixth-form-high-school/locations/honduras-school-expeditions/

story:
Who We are

We are a nonprofit that knows of a gap: the lack of post-secondary options to train adults with autism for higher skilled work. 75% of adults with autism are unemployed. Graduation rates at higher educational institutions are abysmal. And, many of those employed are in work that underutilizes their strengths.

EnCircle Technologies was started by two parents of young adults with autism. Becky Llorens and Teri Walden were dismayed at the lack of post-secondary options to help their sons learn and grow in job skills. They saw many adults with autism, languishing, without the training for job skills that matched their potential. 

They knew that their university community drew parents of children with autism due to a large autism research center. And, so they decided to do something about it by creating a space and place for adults with autism to train for technology jobs.

    The Impact

    By training adults with autism for jobs in which they can make a living wage we are adding to something we all strive for.  We all want choice, independence and meaning in our lives.  We all want the opportunity to learn and grow as individuals and utilize our unique strengths to make the world a better place.  People on the autism spectrum are no different.

    As parents, Becky Llorens and Teri Walden are committed to making this a reality in their community.

    Risks & Challenges

    The technology world moves quickly with new innovations every day.  We will have to keep up to be sure we are providing the best learning experience for our students.  We are fortunate to live in a college town where we have access to young people who are willing to share their expertise and help us along the way.

    We know that it's important to keep the business community involved so that we are training our students for jobs that exist.  From the start of this project we have met with local businesses and have worked with all stakeholders in this process.  We will continue to do this.

    There are many challenges ahead but this mission is so critical that we will do what it takes to make it successful.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please help us by getting the word out.  Spread the message on your Facebook page or Twitter.  Talk to your colleagues at work and your family and friends.  

    And, of course, please donate!

    Don't forget to share using the buttons above.

story:
12 of us are going to a small town in Belize called Orange Walk. Our goal is to bring much needed supplies to the children and families, as well as engaging in ministry and building relationships with the locals.


We are aiming to raise at least $3000 to go towards our total cost of getting us to Belize, buying supplies for the families, and doing projects around the area such as repairs in the church and homes.


An important part of our trip is the camp we will be running at a local church for about 100 children. The purpose of this camp is to teach the kids the message of love and hope, while giving them a chance to have lots of fun and make lifelong memories. An experience like this can be very special to these children who are living every day in poverty.


If you feel it in your heart to donate, you will receive a beautiful print photograph from the trip once we return.


If you can't contribute financially but would still like to help, you can spread the word by sharing this page with your friends. 

Thank-you!

story:
Short Summary

Burhaniye Alevi Culture Society is an umbrella organisation for approximately 200.000 Alevis living in Balıkesir.

There are 40 volunteers working in Alevi Cultural Society and Cemevi in Burhaniye. Building construction has been stopped because of lack of money. By this time, we bought the land, started the building construction for the society.

What We Need & What You Get

  • There will be a library with full of books,
  • a place of worship,
  • a funeral home,
  • a soup kitchen for homeless people,
  • a free public education center,
  • a music education center,
  • and presentation of Alevi Culture in this center.
We just need $10.000 for all these services.

Other Ways You Can Help

You could help us by sending books, kitchenwares, carpets and music instruments.

story:
Kitesurfeuse Professionnelle, depuis quelques années, j'ai la chance de parcourir le monde en vivant de ma passion.
  • En Aout dernier, j'ai découvert Madagascar, et le village d'Anakao au sud du pays, j'ai été touché par la population leur sourire et plus particulièrement celui des enfants.
  • Je me suis sentie également mal à l'aise de constater leur conditions de vie et d'éducation, la seule école est trop petite pour pouvoir accueillir tous les enfants du village, résultat 60% d'entre eux sont analphabètes .
  • Aujourd'hui j'ai envie d'essayer d'agir à mon niveau, profitant de ma petite notoriété dans mon milieu. 
  • Aidons les à agrandir leur école, aidons les avec des fournitures, des cahiers, chacun selon nos moyens.
  • Je repars à la fin du mois de Mai dans ce même village, et je ne veux pas y retourner les mains vides.


 Nous avons besoin:


  • De tout le nécessaire éducatif possible, cahiers, crayons, trousses, jeu ...
  • Rassembler des fonds pour construire du mobilier sur place
  • Tous les fonds seront reversés à l'école d'Anakao que le projet aboutisse ou pas.

Unissons nous!!

L'union fait la force!!! petit + petit on devient gros et plus fort.

  • J'ai l'esprit de compétition et je suis déterminée à aider ses enfants avec ou sans vous, mais je pense que c'est une belle aventure à vivre que cela soit pour vous ou moi même ... le sourire d'un enfant c'est magique et  savoir que vous y êtes pour quelques chose, cela ne peut que vous rendre plus heureux.

Risques et défis

Le soucis des associations existantes à Madagascar c'est qu'elles sont beaucoup à être corrompues on ne sait jamais où vont les fonds exactement, c'est pour ça que je me rend sur place, pour donner directement aux responsables de l'école et aux enfants.

Vous pourrez suivre en images ce voyage sur ma page d'athlète Facebook Marie Desandre Navarre, et ainsi découvrir la situation Anakao, les enfants et l'école. Un film  sera réalisé par la suite, afin de partager tout ça avec vous.

story:
Short Summary


Hwiemtun (Fred Roland)
Hwiemtun has worked with youth, culture and wilderness for over 20 years. "My Traditional name is Hwiemtun (English name Fred Roland) and I was born and raised on Vancouver Island and have learned from many fo the elders of this territory. My mother is from the Cowichan territory and my (late) father’s lineage was Hawaiian. My years of learning from various tribes globally are now used for bridging between our traditional world and contemporary worlds'
Hwiemtun's Indigenous Education and Cultural Centre on his ancestral home by the Cowichan River is almost complete. We need to help him raise a final $10 000 to complete the main building. Most of the materials have been collected and a crew of professional carpenters and builders have offered their services. The $10 000 will be used to buy the materials needed to complete this project in time for the Indigenous Arts Festival in June 2015. $5 000 will be used to sponsor 3 Elders to attend the Festival from Central and South America.
Having this main building at the Education and Cultural Centre will allow Hwiemtun and the 'Wolf Cowichan' Program to have a venue to bring Indigenous Elders and youth together to learn and pass down knowledge and skills to the next generations.
It is important that the Elders can be hosted appropriately for these kind of programs to be provided.
In contributing to this campaign, you will be assisting a group of dedicated educators and community members who have already volunteered their time and resources to this project. Please help us get the job finished!


What We Need & What You Get

The frame of the building is already up. 

Much of the lumber has been collected.

$10 000 is needed to pay for roofing material, additional lumber and other building supplies.

All carpentry and building services are by volunteers.

3 Elders: Victor Choc, a Mayan Elder and educator from Toledo, Belize; Aurora Garcia Saqui, a Mayan herbalist and healer from the Maya Centre, Belize; and 'Roberto' a Quechua educator from the Amazon Region of Ecuador will each receive $1200 to attend the Festival.

$1400 will be used for promotional material for the Festival.

All contributions over $15 will receive 50% off admission to the Festival. 

All contributions over $50 will receive a deer hide medicine pouch made by our students.

All contributions over $100 will receive our special herbal and smudging medicine mix with ingredients from North, South and Central America.

All contributions over $1000 will receive a hand-made, hand-painted drum.

The Impact

Indigenous Elders and the knowledge they carry are at risk of being lost. The Indigenous Education and Cultural Centre and the Indigenous Arts Festival have already touched hundreds of students with teachings, skills and ceremony. The building resource will allow us to reach more students and host the Elders in a comfortable and appropriate manner.

For the past 15 years, Hwiemtun and the staff of 'Wolf Cowichan' have been successfully offering these programs to youth in Thailand, Belize, Ecuador, the USA, Germany and Canada. The first Festival in 2012 brought cultural groups from Thailand and Belize to the communities of Saltspring Island and Cowichan. This coming together of traditional culture and local youth has been a successful addition to the ongoing wilderness and Indigenous skills mentoring that Hwiemtun and the 'Wolf Cowichan' team offer on a weekly basis to local students.

Risks & Challenges

Hwiemtun and his team have already built the sweatlodge centre, the meeting yurt, and the traditional ceremonial yurt, the outdoor kitchen and the workshop centre. All this has been done with personal funds and volunteer labour. The final amount needed of $10 000 will allow the Centre to be completed.

Other Ways You Can Help

We will appreciate all contributions and ask you to share this campaign with your friends, family and email lists. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Short Summary

Hwiemtun (Fred Roland)
Hwiemtun has worked with youth, culture and wilderness for over 20 years. "My Traditional name is Hwiemtun (English name Fred Roland) and I was born and raised on Vancouver Island and have learned from many fo the elders of this territory. My mother is from the Cowichan territory and my (late) father’s lineage was Hawaiian. My years of learning from various tribes globally are now used for bridging between our traditional world and contemporary worlds'
Hwiemtun's Indigenous Education and Cultural Centre on his ancestral home by the Cowichan River is almost complete. We need to help him raise a final $10 000 to complete the main building. Most of the materials have been collected and a crew of professional carpenters and builders have offered their services. The $10 000 will be used to buy the materials needed to complete this project in time for the Indigenous Arts Festival in June 2015. $5 000 will be used to sponsor 3 Elders to attend the Festival from Central and South America.
Having this main building at the Education and Cultural Centre will allow Hwiemtun and the 'Wolf Cowichan' Program to have a venue to bring Indigenous Elders and youth together to learn and pass down knowledge and skills to the next generations.
It is important that the Elders can be hosted appropriately for these kind of programs to be provided.

story:
Heya!

So I'm leaving 'Merica (with the kiddos) for a bit and heading to Australia to go to Grad School. I will be studying International Law and International Relations at The University of New South Wales in Sydney. We will take off January 19th to get settled and acclamated prior to classes. Maddox begins classes January 27th as well. Living abroad, in Australia has been one of my dreams for a long time and now it's a reality! Yay!

These funds will be used for the cost of flights, overseas health coverage and schooling for Maddox and luggage fees for me and my two kiddos; Maddox and Artis.

*Partial proceeds raised will go towards The CTUIR Higher Education Fund for a special college scholarship designated to anyone who wishes to study abroad or focus on the areas of public policy, government, economic development, sustainability, journalism, media and or/arts. (If we meet the goal)

Thank you to all who will make my dream a reality.

Cheers!

story:
GAL ESPACIO MONTESSORI

GAL is located in Puerto Morelos, Quintana Roo, México.

GAL se encuentra ubicado en Puerto Morelos, Quintana Roo, México.

Puerto Morelos is a town of 15 thousand inhabitants, its geography is wonderful: jungle, sea, mangrove and very quiet. The which we choose to live here we arrived in search of quality of life for ourselves and our children.

Puerto Morelos es un poblado de de 15 mil habitantes, su geografía es maravillosa: selva, mar, manglar y mucha tranquilidad. Los que elegimos vivir aquí llegamos en búsqueda de calidad de vida para nosotros y nuestros hijos. 

       

Our mission is to provide education for the whole child in accord with the principles and methods of Dr. Maria Montessori, for children between 18 months-6 years old. 

Nuestra mission es proporcionar una educación holistica basada en la filosofía Montessori para niños y niñas entre 18 meses y 6 años. 

Gal Espacio Montessori began its activities in August 2014 with very few resources but a lot of enthusiasm.

Gal Espacio Montessori comenzó sus actividades en agosto del 2014 con muy pocos recursos pero mucho entusiasmo.


We have created a environment where the individuality of every child is honored and where children can develop all of their capabilities. GAL has a strong focus on  artistic expression.

Hemos creado un ambiente donde la individualidad de cada niño/a es honrado, y donde los niños/as pueden desarrollar todas sus capacidades y donde se pone gran énfasis en la expresión artística.

"Si la ayuda y la salvación han de llegar, sólo podrá ser a través de los niños"

"If the help and salvation are to come, they can only come from the children"

María Montessori


Our classroom environment fosters the fulfillment of the young learner’s highest potential – social, emotional, behavioral, physical, artistic, and intellectual – as a member of a family and a community. Using the Montessori philosophy, we provide a learning environment that encourages all our students to become confident, independent, caring and creative individuals.

GAL Espacio Montessori ofrece un lugar cálido, personalizado y tranquilo. Aquí los niños y niñas pueden desarrollar sus múltiples potencialidades, su sensibilidad e independencia, en un ambiente multiedad y multicultural.  

GAL Espacio Montessori makes early childhood education accessible to families from various economic backgrounds. 

Una de nuestras premisas principales  es que la educación montessori este al alcance de todos, por eso creamos un fondo de becas para que cada vez más niños/as puedan acceder a un aprendizaje alternativo de calidad.

The entire student population is composed of children from various cultures, nationalities and socioeconomic backgrounds. We are proud of our diversity, which reflects the community in which we live.

Toda la población estudiantil se compone de niños de diferentes culturas, nacionalidades y orígenes socioeconómicos. Estamos orgullosos de nuestra diversidad, que refleja a la comunidad en la cual vivimos.

We believe that a diverse community benefits all children and our goal is to offer scholarships to at least 50% of the children to include ones whose families do not have sufficient resources.

Creemos que una comunidad diversa beneficia a todos los niños/as. Nuestra meta es poder ofrecer becas a por lo menos el 50% de los niños, para incluir a aquellos cuyas familias no tienen recursos suficientes.

Many children of limited economic means, receive scholarships covering from 20 - 100% of the tuition which is currently  $1900 mex pesos/month (around $140 Dollars). 

Muchos niños de escasos recursos económicos, reciben becas que cubren entre el 20% y el 100% de la matrícula que actualmente es de $1900 pesos mex/mes (alrededor de $140 dólares).

Therefore, in order to ensure the GAL's ability to further enrich the educational career of its students, the school needs the economic support of concerned and proactive people, like you, who think that education is the means to improve life and create a sustainable future.

Por lo tanto, para garantizar la capacidad de GAL para enriquecer aún más la carrera educativa de sus alumnos, la escuela necesita el apoyo económico de personas proactivas como usted, que piensan que la educación es el medio para mejorar la calidad de vida y crear un futuro sostenible.

We thank you for taking the time to read this and hope you take a minute to support us.

Te agradecemos por tomarse el tiempo de leer esto y esperamos que puedas  apoyarnos.

How you can help?¿Cómo puedes ayudar?

Montessori materials are beautifully made, invite discovery, and are essential for true Montessori education. 

Los materiales Montessori están bellamente realizados, invitan a descubrirlos, y son esenciales para una verdadera educación Montessori.

Your donation will allow us to purchase our needs.

Any amount helps! $5, $10, $25 or more…. 

Please consider asking your friends and family to donate too.

Let's raise more than 100% of the goal! Additional funds will go toward purchasing more materials, improve and enlarger our indoor and outdoor environments and for scholarships. 

Su donación nos permitirá adquirir materiales para nuestros ambientes. ¡Cualquier cantidad ayuda! $5, $10, $25 o más…. 

Por favor, apóyanos difundiendo entre tus amigos y familiares. 

¡Ayúdanos a recaudar más del 100% de la meta! Los fondos adicionales se destinarán para poder ofrecer más becas a niños y niñas de bajos recursos.

Other ways you can help -Otras formas de ayudar 

• GAL Espacio Montessori has set up a scholarship campaign called “Programa Guardian” through which you may donate an amount equal to the tuition for one school cycle for a youngster whose family could otherwise not afford it.

• GAL Espacio Montessori ha establecido una campaña denominada "Programa Guardián" a través del cual usted puede donar una cantidad igual a la matrícula de un ciclo escolar de un niño/a cuya familia de otro modo no podrían permitirse.

Please consider joining GAL Espacio Montessori’s scholarship program “Programa Guardian”. The goal is to be able to help more low-income families enter a Montessori program.

“Programa Guardian” scholarship fund, sponsor a student!:

1 chid for 1 month: $140 dlls.

1 child for 1 year: $1,680 dlls.

Por favor, considere unirse al Programa "Guardián", cuyo objetivo es poder ayudar a más familias de bajos ingresos a acceder a una educación Montessori. "

"Programa Guardian"

Patrocina a 1 niño/a durante 1 mes: $140 dlls. 

Patrocina a 1 niño/a por 1 año: $1,680 dlls.

•  Donate materials: Montessori Materials (new or used), Children's books, Children’s furniture, High quality manipulative and toys.

Donar materiales: Materiales de Montessori (nuevos o usados en buen estado), libros infantiles, mobiliario infantil, juguetes y juegos educativos.

•  Spread the word! Please share this campaign with your family and friends.

¡Corre la voz! Por favor comparte esta campaña con tu familia y amigos.

Want to know more about GAL? Here are some links: ¿Quiere saber más sobre GAL? Aquí hay algunos enlaces:

•  Our School's Blog: www.espaciogal.blogspot.com

• This video: About GAL, shows us, our space and how our environment is. 

•  Montessori education hinges on children working independently at each one's own pace with special Montessori materials. Here's a list of needed materials. 

 • Nuestro blog: www.espaciogal.blogspot.com

 • Este video: Acerca de GAL, nos muestra, cómo es nuestro espacio y nuestro medio ambiente. 

•  Aquí una lista de materiales montessori.

story:
Short Summary

INFORMATION ON IMPOSING TERM LIMITS

ON THE US CONGRESS,

WITHOUT THEIR APPROVAL

(Term Limits for US Congress)

THE GAME PLAN

What We Need & What You Get

The Impact

Article 5 of the US Constitution gives us the opportunity to impose Term Limits on the US Congress WITHOUT their approval. When 34 States request a Convention for a specific topic, an Article 5 Convention is called.At the Convention the Amendment is presented. Once ratified by 38 States, it becomes part of the US Constitution, without requiring the approval of the US Congress.

To accomplish this task is going to take a monumental effort. The magnitude of a national, grassroots effort will require dedication, perseverance, and a well-planned, strategic effort.

THE MAIN THRUST of this projects finances is to build Awareness, Education, and than a Call to Action on the part of the States Citizens. 

  • Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean you can’t help:

  • Contact us.. https://www.facebook.com/TermLimitsforUSCongress 
  • Support us.. http://termlimitsforuscongress.com/
  • Be a Lead on a County or State level or be a petitioner in your state   http://termlimitsforuscongress.com/contact.html 
  • Facts to consider..
    • Just about any thing you want to know about the campaign

  •  And that’s all there is to it.  
    Oh Except you Bumper sticker and T Shirt to wear proud as a patriot.

story:
Our Story 

Our school’s journey began five years ago when founders Julie Speier and John Crilly first moved from New York City to San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua. A seasoned educator, Julie recognized the need for a high quality school, with low student-teacher ratios, a sustainable curriculum, English language learning, and highly qualified educators trained to work with a diverse student body.  The school opened its doors in 2009 with just 1 teacher and 6 students and a half day program.  Five years later, the school has expanded exponentially into a high quality primary school educating a diverse Nicaraguan and Expat student body of children from the ages of 18 months to eight year.  Now, with 54 students, 1 director, 4 lead teachers, a Spanish teacher, ESL instruction, and 2 teaching assistants, we are outgrowing our current location!

Thanks to a very generous land donation from Finca las Nubes, San Juan del Sur Day School now has the space upon which to build a beautiful campus - one that will grow with our students, ultimately servicing children in pre-kindergarten thru the 12th grade.  However, we need your help!

Our goal is to raise $150,000 over the next few months for the construction and materials of Phase 1 of the new campus which includes a 5-classroom primary school building, furniture, parking lot, and playground.   All donations will go directly to costs associated with the construction of the building, materials and labor.  The school's expenses (salaries, maintenance, school supplies, food, taxes, etc.) will continue to be covered by tuition payments.

PLANS FOR PHASE ONE

Primary School building:

  • One 6x6 meter flexible classroom with divider for out Toddler program/Pre-K-1: for students ages 18 months – 3 years
  • Three 4x6 meter classrooms (Pre-K2: ages 3-5; Kindergarten/1st grade room: ages 5-7; 2nd-4th Grade Multiage room: ages 7-9)
  • Toddler bathroom, children's bathroom, faculty bathroom
  • Small office/faculty room
  • Kitchen

One Large 8x6 meter dining hall/common area

Furniture

Playground

Parking lot

CONSTRUCTION

The talented, experienced building team at Finca las Nubes, a leader in sustainable construction, intentional building, and environmental preservation, will manage construction of the school.

Our urgency to begin construction is based on our rapid growth over the last few years.  We are quickly outgrowing our current space and our lease expires at the end of the year.  Instead of finding a new rental space that will require a significant investment to make it school-ready, we have decided to invest in the school’s future, putting our money into bricks and mortar of our own.  This has suddenly become a reality with the extremely generous land donation of 30 pristine acres, given to the school by Finca Las Nubes. 

"Finca Las Nubes, [located approximately 2 miles from town] is first and foremost dedicated to preserving the environment and helping others do the same. We support the development of sustainable farming techniques and the promotion thereof. Most of us have satisfied our own needs and are bent on giving back. Finca Las Nubes is designed to provide a base of operations for these projects." 

This amazing land donation, with mountain, ocean and lake views will provide our students with the ideal learning environment, featuring natural landscapes, organic gardens, wood working shop, beautiful walking trails, playing fields and opportunities to work with and help care for the farm and its animals.  Finca Las Nubes uses sustainable living practices in all that it does and this important part of our mission is well matched.  Locating our school on this stunning property will allow us to attain our goal of becoming a full Pre-K through 12th grade International English school.

DONATIONS

San Juan del Sur Day School is raising funds for the first phase of construction through various channels including friends, families, fundraising events, crowdfunding websites (see below), corporations and those with a personal interest in the development of the school and the community.

To kick-start our building campaign, the great grandfather of one of our students has generously offered to match the first $20,000 in donations. Please help us take advantage of this offer, your donation gets doubled and we can receive this extra $20,000.

In recognition of donations of $30,000 or more, a donor may choose to dedicate/name one of the 4 classrooms or the dining hall of the new campus.

San Juan del Sur Day School currently operates as a small private registered business in Nicaragua. 

Donations can be made via one of four avenues:

·  Donations can be made directly to our construction and materials accounts here in Nicaragua at LaFise and at Wells Fargo in the US overseen by San Juan del Sur Day School.  Please contact john@sanjuandelsurdayschool.com for account information.

·  For tax deductible donations of $100 or more: Comunidad Connect, a 501 (c) (3) U.S. non-profit organization working in Nicaragua to promote sustainable community development, cultural integrity, and civic engagement will accept donations on our behalf and transfer monies directly to the construction project.  CC charges a 5% administrative fee, which helps to support all of the beneficial projects in which CC is involved.

·  For Credit Card donations, please feel free to donate directly from this page.  You can find a "contribute now" button at both the top and bottom of this page.  Indiegogo retains 4% of monies received through their site if we reach our initial goal of $10,000 or 9% if we do not reach our goal.

·  Any amount of cash donations can be made directly at the school.

VISION FOR THE FUTURE

Our vision for San Juan del Sur Day School does not end with a primary school.  We intend to launch the second phase of construction, which will include an extension to the primary school building, a middle school (grades 6-8), playing fields, a competition size swimming pool and administrative offices in 2017.  By 2020, we plan to add a high school for students in grades 9-12.

In addition to continued fundraising, the objective for the school is to eventually fund future construction and improvements from, not only donations, but also income generated by tuition.  As the school’s enrollment increases, so too will our income for future projects.  Our plan is to expand organically, based on the needs of our growing student body.  We will continue to grow with our oldest students and assign teachers and classrooms as enrollment demands.  Our goal is to maintain a student-teacher ratio of 12:1 for our youngest students and to meet international standards of 24:1 in the older classrooms.

In February 2009 the school opened with six students.  As of January 2014, we have 54 students enrolled, with 8 new students set to enroll by September 2014.  Eight of our students have been enrolled with the school since 2009, and as our school ages, we delight in seeing not only siblings enroll, but the newest members of our community. Using historical data of the school over the last 5 years, we project enrollment to increase to 100 students within the next three years. Moving the school to Finca Las Nubes, and attaining local accreditation within the year will open our doors to a whole new demographic of students from Rivas and the neighboring areas. We predict a continuous and sustainable net profit over the next 5 years of 18% on earnings, which shall be retained by the school for future development. The business is solvent, healthy and growing in the right direction.  For a more detailed financial breakdown of the business, and projections, please contact our Director of Operations: john@sanjuandelsurdayschool.com

WHY SAN JUAN DEL SUR DAY SCHOOL?

San Juan del Sur Day School has provided quality English education to children of San Juan ages 18 months to 8 years for the past five years. Our mission is to create a community of life long learners and responsible global citizens comprised of both Nicaraguan and International families.  Our goal is to grow with our oldest students through high school by providing them with a safe, creative, sustainable campus that prepares them to go on to higher education, enter the workforce, and give back to the community.  Without our school, many of our talented students may not have the resources and opportunities to earn the necessary education to become international learners.

English Education

San Juan del Sur Day School benefits, not only the community of San Juan del Sur by keeping and attracting resourceful, global citizens with entrepreneurial spirits, but it also educates local children so that they can be more productive members of society, using their education and critical thinking skills to help create jobs, take care of their families and our resources.  San Juan del Sur Day School currently provides scholarships or financial aid to approximately 16% of our students with the goal of sustaining 25% of our total student body with educational assistance in the near future. Funding for these scholarships is generated via school tuition and individual sponsors.  While tuition is covered for these deserving students, they still require a proper campus to grow, develop and explore the world around them. 

"An extra year of good schooling lifts a country’s yearly economic growth by 1%, making poor countries richer and, in the long run, less in need of foreign aid – and more able to trade.”[i]

International Community

Of the 54 students currently enrolled in the school, approximately one quarter are local Nicaraguans, one quarter are "expats" and the other half have one Nicaraguan and one expat parent (hailing from Canada, U.S., Russia, Ukraine, Germany, Costa Rica, Holland, Switzerland, Spain, Cuba and Ireland).

An international education offers the opportunity to celebrate diversity in a spirit of understanding and tolerance and to develop a positive regard and awareness of other people. This is an education that goes far beyond the confines of the classroom and sees in the learning process the chance for some remarkable lessons. An appreciation of different cultures and backgrounds creates a sense of openness and understanding that enables students to work well with others and for many, to lead people with different viewpoints in a cohesive team.  A key factor for success in adulthood is a child’s ability to communicate with people from different backgrounds. We see an opportunity to develop cross-cultural understanding, an international outlook and an ability to build quality relationships with people from different backgrounds.

"The nature of the problems the world needs to solve today cannot be solved at the level at which they were created. We need to see beyond the fragmented differences of culture, language and religion to a more fundamental reality. One of the great advantages of an international education is that you can create an environment in which young people from different cultures, nationalities and languages are brought together in one place. They have the opportunity to learn that what makes them human is not their cultural identity, language, or religion alone but it is also something essentially spiritual that transcends all of these things. In other words, they have the chance to recognise that there is a common humanity which transcends the differences at which world problems are often experienced today."

~ Dr. Jonathan Long, Headmaster of the Round Square school in Britain[ii]


Portable Education

The appeal of San Juan del Sur Day School is great for many of our multi-cultural families. Our curriculum, based significantly on the International Baccalaureate (IB), but also incorporating standards outlined by the Nicaraguan Ministry of Education, provides students with a high quality portable education that will stand them in good stead whether they move on to a new country or remain in Nicaragua. By following the model of the IB schools[iii] and completing the rigorous process to obtain International English School Accreditation(NEASC) via: The New England Association of Schools and Colleges our students will be well prepared to thrive in any educational setting.

The NEASC accreditation is a system of accountability that is ongoing, voluntary, and comprehensive in scope. It respects differences in institutional populations, missions, and cultures, and fosters institutional change grounded in the judgment of practicing educators. It is based on standards which are developed and regularly reviewed by the members and which define the characteristics of good schools and colleges.[iv]

Almost half of our students come from blended Nicaraguan/Expatriate families.  These families seek an education for their children that will soon be accredited in both Nicaragua and internationally, giving their children the opportunity to seamlessly continue their education in either of their home countries. Furthermore, by sending their children to SJdS Day School, our parents are reinforcing their children's exposure to the two languages and cultures taught at home: English, the primary language of instruction, as well as Spanish via other students, teaching assistants, and formal lessons.

Each student, each family has their own story.  Yet the common thread for all is the desire to learn.  Help us to continue their story by donating to the building fund.

WHY NICARAGUA?

Expatriate retirees have been flocking to Nicaragua for years, but anecdotal evidence suggests a spike in relocation of families with young children, as well.  The rapid increase in enrollment and request for information at San Juan del Sur Day School over the last three years positively correlates with these findings.  In place of vacations, foreigners are setting up long term residences in Nicaragua thanks to a more affordable, simpler way of life that allows for more family time in a beautiful, tropical climate.  They are driven by entrepreneurial opportunities, affordable real estate, low crime rates, and reasonable health care.

Stable Investment Opportunities

Although one of the poorest nations in the region, Nicaragua’s economy is showing rapid growth.  In 2012, Nicaragua set a new personal best for foreign-direct investment (FDI), netting $1.28 billion—a remarkable 33% increase from the year before, according to investment-promotion agency ProNicaragua. The level of investment growth is even more impressive considering it comes on top of a monstrous 91% jump in foreign-direct investment in 2011. In real terms, foreign investment levels have more than doubled over the past two years.  “The historic level of growth reached in 2012 demonstrates the commitment of the Government of Reconciliation and National Unity to continue improving the investment climate, facilitate investment processes, and promote socio-economic development in the country,” said Gen. Alvaro Baltodano, presidential delegate for foreign investment.[v] The 2013 Doing Business Report, recently published by the World Bank, revealed that Nicaragua improved a position in its overall ranking with positive developments in the Trading Across Borders, and Resolving Insolvency categories. This is the third consecutive year the country has improved its position within the report, which demonstrates a positive impact of the various efforts carried out to improve the country’s investment climate.[vi]

Safety

Nicaragua significantly improved its position in the western hemisphere in the 2013 Global Peace Index (GPI).  Other prestigious institutions have recognized Nicaragua not only as one of the safest destinations in the region, but also as a country with an excellent business climate.[vii]  The Inter-American Institute on human rights identified Nicaragua as the safest country in Central America.  A United Nations report also revealed that the crime rate was lower than the U.S., France and Germany.[viii]  In 2012, The Economist named Nicaragua “A Surprising Safe Haven,” less violent than booming Panama, and soon safer than Costa Rica, a tourist haven.[ix]

Popularity

Just two months into 2014 and Nicaragua has appeared in over 5 articles touting its appeal to tourists, foreign investors, expatriates and retirees.  The country has been featured numerous times by the Huffington Post and was named one of the “best value travel destinations for 2014” by Lonely Planet[x] and a “Top 10 Destination to Watch in 2014” by Condé Nast[xi].  In 2013, both the Wall Street Journal, as well as the Christian Science Monitor suggested Nicaragua as a popular retirement location.  Nicaragua was also featured in two seasons of the popular CBS television series, Survivor.  The outpouring of positive press coverage for the country in recent years has helped to shift perceptions of a once misunderstood country, paving the way for increased investment and stability.  To follow Nicaragua’s press coverage, you can visit Nicaragua’s tourism board (INTUR).[xii]

WHO WE ARE

Julie Speier: Co-Founder, Director, and Head Teacher

Before moving to San Juan del Sur, Julie was the program coordinator of the toddler program at Cincinnati Country Day School where she worked closely with parents and oversaw 3 head teachers, 3 assistant teachers and 36 students. She also taught Pre-K, Kindergarten and first grade while there. During her time at CCDS she was mentored in and used the Constructivist approach to education. She also worked with colleagues to develop and implement a curriculum that is still in use there today.

While at CCDS, Julie also coached the middle school Cross Country and Swim teams. She served on numerous committees including SEED (Seeking Equality through Educational Diversity), Search for the New Head of School, ISACS (Independent Schools Association of the Central States) and Growth and Development. She worked closely with the Head of School and the Lower School principals allowing her the opportunity to observe and learn from these gifted leaders.

Prior to her work with CCDS, she lived in Hawaii where she taught second grade ESL at Kalihi Kai Elementary School and developed a love and passion for the ocean and surfing.  At Boston University she earned her degree in Early Childhood Education as the recipient of a full swimming scholarship.  In addition to her passion for teaching, and love of surfing, Julie is also a certified yoga teacher. Julie has two young daughters and one on the way with her partner John Crilly.

John Crilly: Co-Founder and Director of Operations

After studying Construction and Civil Engineering in Ireland for 2 years, John relocated to New York where he worked in the Restaurant and Hospitality business for 20 years.  During that time, he designed, operated and owned his own establishments while simultaneously studying Building Management and Finance and real estate appraisal at New York University’s Graduate School.  In 2008, John and his family relocated to San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua and opened the doors to San Juan del Sur Day School in 2009.  In his role as Director of Operations, John oversees the school’s accounting and purchasing, and will supervise the construction of the new school.

PARTNERSHIPS 

San Juan del Sur Day School has formed a partnership with Comunidad Connect, a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit organization working to improve the quality of life of people in Nicaragua by matching local and global resources with opportunities for sustainable development.  An ear to the ground and a strong connection to the community, Comunidad Connect recommends local children, showing academic promise and a strong support network, for San Juan del Sur Day School’s scholarship program.  In addition to scholarship recommendations, Comunidad Connect also assists San Juan del Sur Day School in the planning and implementation of meaningful community-based field trips.  Such field trips include monthly visits to the community of Astillero and the project “One Less Bag, One More Turtle,” where students learn about the importance of recycling and protecting our environment and also to the women’s jam collective in El Carizal where students are introduced to local, sustainable business practices.  It is with a partnership like this between our school and Comunidad Connect that we will be able to fulfill our mission and grow in a sustainable and responsible way.  

High quality education can help to transform children, who in turn transform our communities, cities, countries and the world for the benefit of us all. Quality education helps to create citizens who understand politics and can make beneficial changes to governmental systems, people who work together to create strong, open institutions, and societies. We thank you in advance for donating what you can to our construction fund, so that we can continue to further the opportunities available to our students, community, country and world.  The completion of this exciting project will provide a space for higher learning for generations to come.  We are grateful for this opportunity and we look forward to your support.

Sincerely,

Julie Speier (Co-Founder/Director) and John Crilly (Co-Founder/Director of Operations)

----

FAQ's

How exactly will you use my contribution?

Monies raised for the construction of phase 1 of San Juan del Sur Day School will be used for just that.  All donations will go directly to costs associated with the construction of the building, materials and labor.  The school's expenses (salaries, maintenance, school supplies, food, lawyer fees, taxes) are covered by tuition payments.

Will $150,000 really cover your building costs?

Yes!  $150,000 will cover the costs of phase 1 of our construction.  However, our vision for San Juan del Sur Day School does not end with a primary school.  We intend to launch the second phase of construction, which will include a second primary school building, a middle school (grades 6-8), playing fields, a competition size swimming pool and administrative offices in 2017.  By 2020, we plan to add a high school for students in grades 9-12.

Why is this campaign for only $10,000 if you need $100,000?

Indiegogo (the crowdfunding site) suggests that we start small.  But fear not, as we are dreaming big!  We would be thrilled to surpass this initial goal and to go on to raise the entire amount needed.

---

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to make a financial contribution, you can still help!  Get the word out by making some noise about our campaign!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word via email, Facebook, and Twitter.

[ii] http://www.newsweekshowcase.com/education/schools/europe/articles/The-Benefits-of-an-International-School-Education

[iii]https://www.ibo.org/pyp/

[iv] https://www.neasc.org/about-accreditation/benefits

[v] http://www.nicaraguadispatch.com/news/2013/07/nicaragua-notches-record-investments-in-12/8148

[vi]http://www.doingbusiness.org/~/media/GIAWB/Doing%20Business/Documents/Annual-Reports/English/DB13-full-report.pdf

[vii] http://www.prlog.org/12157266-nicaragua-remains-one-the-safest-country-in-latin-america.html

[viii] http://thenicaraguareport.com/2011/03/investment-opportunities-in-nicaragua/

[ix] http://www.economist.com/node/21543492

[x] http://www.lonelyplanet.com/travel-tips-and-articles/lonely-planets-best-value-travel-destinations-for-2014

[xi] http://www.cntraveller.com/recommended/itineraries/destinations-to-watch-2014

[xii] http://visitnicaragua.us/about-nicaragua/news-items/
story_txt:
Our Story Our
school’s journey began five years ago when founders Julie Speier and John
Crilly first moved from New York City to San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua. A
seasoned educator, Julie recognized the need for a high quality school,
with low student-teacher ratios, a sustainable curriculum, English language
learning, and highly qualified educators trained to work with a diverse student
body.  The school opened its doors in 2009 with just 1 teacher and 6 students and a half day program.  Five years later, the school has expanded exponentially into a high quality primary school educating a diverse Nicaraguan and Expat student body of children from the ages of 18 months to eight year.  Now, with 54 students, 1 director, 4 lead teachers, a Spanish teacher, ESL instruction, and 2 teaching assistants, we are outgrowing our current location!Thanks to a very generous land donation from Finca las Nubes, San Juan del Sur Day School now has the space upon which to build a beautiful campus - one that will grow with our students, ultimately servicing children in pre-kindergarten thru the 12th grade.  However, we need your help!Our goal is to raise $150,000 over the next few months for the
construction and materials of Phase 1 of the new campus which includes a 5-classroom primary school building, furniture, parking lot, and playground.   All donations will
go directly to costs associated with the construction of the building,
materials and labor.  The school's expenses (salaries, maintenance, school
supplies, food, taxes, etc.) will continue to be covered by tuition
payments.
PLANS FOR PHASE ONE
Primary School building:
One 6x6 meter flexible classroom with
divider for out Toddler program/Pre-K-1: for students
ages 18 months – 3 years
Three 4x6 meter classrooms (Pre-K2: ages 3-5; Kindergarten/1st grade room:
ages 5-7; 2nd-4th Grade
Multiage room: ages 7-9)
Toddler bathroom, children's bathroom,
faculty bathroom
Small office/faculty room
Kitchen

One
Large 8x6 meter dining hall/common area
Furniture
Playground
Parking lot


CONSTRUCTION
The talented,
experienced building team at Finca las Nubes, a leader in sustainable
construction, intentional building, and environmental preservation, will manage
construction of the school. 
Our urgency to begin
construction is based on our rapid growth over the last few years.  We are quickly outgrowing our current
space and our lease expires at the end of the year.  Instead of finding a
new rental space that will require a significant investment to make it school-ready,
we have decided to invest in the school’s future, putting our money into bricks
and mortar of our own.  This has suddenly become a reality with the
extremely generous land donation of 30 pristine acres, given to the school by
Finca Las Nubes.  
"Finca Las Nubes,
[located approximately 2 miles from town] is first and foremost dedicated to
preserving the environment and helping others do the same. We support the
development of sustainable farming techniques and the promotion
thereof. Most of us have satisfied our own needs and are bent on giving
back. Finca Las Nubes is designed to provide a base of operations for these
projects." 
This amazing land
donation, with mountain, ocean and lake views will provide our students with
the ideal learning environment, featuring natural landscapes, organic gardens,
wood working shop, beautiful walking trails, playing fields and opportunities
to work with and help care for the farm and its animals.  Finca Las Nubes
uses sustainable living practices in all that it does and this important part
of our mission is well matched.  Locating our school on this stunning
property will allow us to attain our goal of becoming a full Pre-K through 12th
grade International English school.

DONATIONS
San Juan del Sur Day
School is raising funds for the first phase of construction through various
channels including friends, families, fundraising events, crowdfunding websites
(see below), corporations and those with a personal interest in the development
of the school and the community. 
To kick-start our
building campaign, the great grandfather of one of our students has generously
offered to match the first $20,000 in donations. Please help us take advantage
of this offer, your donation gets doubled and we can receive this extra
$20,000.
In recognition of
donations of $30,000 or more, a donor may choose to dedicate/name one of the 4
classrooms or the dining hall of the new campus.
San Juan del Sur Day School
currently operates as a small private registered business in Nicaragua.

via one of four avenues:
·  Donations can be made directly to our construction
and materials accounts here in Nicaragua at LaFise and at Wells Fargo in the US
overseen by San Juan del Sur Day School.

·

tax deductible donations of $100 or more: Comunidad Connect, a 501 (c) (3) U.S.

which helps to support all of the beneficial projects in which CC is involved. 
·

their site if we reach our initial goal of $10,000 or 9% if we do not reach our goal.
·

amount of cash donations can be made directly at the school.

Popularity
Just
two months into 2014 and Nicaragua has appeared in over 5 articles touting its
appeal to tourists, foreign investors, expatriates and retirees.  The country has been featured numerous
times by the Huffington Post and was named one of the “best value travel
destinations for 2014” by Lonely Planet[x] and a “Top 10
Destination to Watch in 2014” by Condé Nast[xi].  In 2013, both the Wall Street Journal,
as well as the Christian Science Monitor suggested Nicaragua as a popular
retirement location.  Nicaragua was
also featured in two seasons of the popular CBS television series, Survivor.  The outpouring of positive press
coverage for the country in recent years has helped to shift perceptions of a
once misunderstood country, paving the way for increased investment and
stability.  To follow Nicaragua’s
press coverage, you can visit Nicaragua’s
tourism board (INTUR).[xii]


WHO WE ARE

Julie Speier:
Co-Founder, Director, and Head Teacher
Before moving to San
Juan del Sur, Julie was the program coordinator of the toddler program at Cincinnati
Country Day School
where she worked closely with parents and oversaw 3 head teachers, 3 assistant
teachers and 36 students. She also taught Pre-K, Kindergarten and first grade
while there. During her time at CCDS she was mentored in and used the
Constructivist approach to education. She also worked with colleagues to
develop and implement a curriculum that is still in use there today.
While at CCDS, Julie
also coached the middle school Cross Country and Swim teams. She served on
numerous committees including SEED (Seeking Equality through Educational
Diversity), Search for the New Head of School, ISACS (Independent Schools
Association of the Central States) and Growth and Development. She worked
closely with the Head of School and the Lower School principals allowing her
the opportunity to observe and learn from these gifted leaders.
Prior to her work
with CCDS, she lived in Hawaii where she taught second grade ESL at Kalihi Kai
Elementary School and developed a love and passion for the ocean and surfing.
 At Boston University she earned her degree in Early Childhood Education
as the recipient of a full swimming scholarship.  In addition to her
passion for teaching, and love of surfing, Julie is also a certified yoga
teacher. Julie has two young daughters and one on the way with her partner John
Crilly.
John Crilly: Co-Founder
and Director of Operations
After studying
Construction and Civil Engineering in Ireland for 2 years, John relocated to
New York where he worked in the Restaurant and Hospitality business for 20
years.  During that time, he
designed, operated and owned his own establishments while simultaneously
studying Building Management and Finance and real estate appraisal at New York
University’s Graduate School.  In
2008, John and his family relocated to San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua and opened
the doors to San Juan del Sur Day School in 2009.  In his role as Director of Operations, John oversees the
school’s accounting and purchasing, and will supervise the construction of the
new school.
PARTNERSHIPS  
San Juan del Sur Day
School has formed a partnership with Comunidad
Connect, a U.S. 501(c)(3) non-profit organization working to improve the
quality of life of people in Nicaragua by matching local and global resources
with opportunities for sustainable development.  An ear to the ground and a strong connection to the
community, Comunidad Connect recommends local children, showing academic
promise and a strong support network, for San Juan del Sur Day School’s
scholarship program.  In addition
to scholarship recommendations, Comunidad Connect also assists San Juan del Sur
Day School in the planning and implementation of meaningful community-based
field trips.  Such field trips
include monthly visits to the community of Astillero and the project “One Less
Bag, One More Turtle,” where students learn about the importance of recycling
and protecting our environment and also to the women’s jam collective in El
Carizal where students are introduced to local, sustainable business practices.
 It is with a partnership like this between our school and
Comunidad Connect that we will be able to fulfill our mission and grow in a
sustainable and responsible way.  
High quality
education can help to transform children, who in turn transform our
communities, cities, countries and the world for the benefit of us all. Quality
education helps to create citizens who understand politics and can make
beneficial changes to governmental systems, people who work together to
create strong, open institutions, and societies. We thank you in advance for
donating what you can to our construction fund, so that we can continue to
further the opportunities available to our students, community, country and
world.  The completion of this
exciting project will provide a space for higher learning for generations to
come.  We are grateful for this
opportunity and we look forward to your support.
Sincerely,

Julie Speier (Co-Founder/Director) and John
Crilly (Co-Founder/Director of Operations)

----FAQ'sHow exactly will you use my contribution?Monies raised for the construction of phase 1 of San Juan del Sur Day School will be used for just that.  All donations will go directly to costs associated with the
construction of the building, materials and labor.  The school's expenses
(salaries, maintenance, school supplies, food, lawyer fees, taxes) are
covered by tuition payments.

Will $150,000 really cover your building costs?Yes!  $150,000 will cover the costs of phase 1 of our construction.  However, our vision for San Juan del Sur Day School does not end with
a primary school.  We intend to
launch the second phase of construction, which will include a second primary
school building, a middle school (grades 6-8), playing fields, a competition size swimming pool
and administrative offices in 2017. 
By 2020, we plan to add a high school for students in grades 9-12.Why is this campaign for only $10,000 if you need $100,000?Indiegogo (the crowdfunding site) suggests that we start small.  But fear not, as we are dreaming big!  We would be thrilled to surpass this initial goal and to go on to raise the entire amount needed.---
Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you are unable to make a financial contribution, you can still help!  Get the word out by making some noise about our campaign!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word via email, Facebook, and Twitter.  [i] https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/making-sure-children-in-developing-countries-get-a-good-education[ii] http://www.newsweekshowcase.com/education/schools/europe/articles/The-Benefits-of-an-International-School-Education[iii]https://www.ibo.org/pyp/[iv] https://www.neasc.org/about-accreditation/benefits[v] http://www.nicaraguadispatch.com/news/2013/07/nicaragua-notches-record-investments-in-12/8148[vi]http://www.doingbusiness.org/~/media/GIAWB/Doing%20Business/Documents/Annual-Reports/English/DB13-full-report.pdf[vii] http://www.prlog.org/12157266-nicaragua-remains-one-the-safest-country-in-latin-america.html[viii] http://thenicaraguareport.com/2011/03/investment-opportunities-in-nicaragua/[ix] http://www.economist.com/node/21543492[x] http://www.lonelyplanet.com/travel-tips-and-articles/lonely-planets-best-value-travel-destinations-for-2014[xi] http://www.cntraveller.com/recommended/itineraries/destinations-to-watch-2014[xii] http://visitnicaragua.us/about-nicaragua/news-items/

story:
Hi and welcome to my journey, I follow my feet…

My Campaign

I have been accepted to attend a summer intensive learning programme in Boulder, Colorado, June 23rd to August 2nd 2014. My goal is to raise funds in the amount of $4000 (R44 000) to make this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity a reality.

The programs I will participate in are:

  • Surfing the Creative® International Youth Leadership Programme and  
  • Dance of Adolescence - training for practitioners working with youth around the world

During the training I will be exposed to a variety of applications of arts-based practices such as Movement, Writing, Voice, Theatre, Art, Ceremony, Intentional Dialogue and other forms of Self-Expression. Each of the phases of this work will be taught through 5Rhythms® dance, writing, small group work, and diverse creative and ritual activities. Furthermore, the training will include the pedagogical and practical study of the maps/methods that shape the Surfing the Creative® Rites of Passage Process developed by Melissa Michaels (Ed.D).

In between these programs I will also have the opportunity to work in close contact with Melissa and her team establishing more practical ways to apply this teaching within the communities where I live and work.

Why not study in South Africa?

At present there are no formal movement or art therapy training programmes available in South Africa. Surfing The Creative® is the first contemporary youth leadership rites of passage programme rooted in dance. Melissa Michaels, founder of this programme, has been engaged in initiating, educating, and mentoring young people all over the world for more than three decades. She has extensive experience in working with developing communities and understands the complexities of working with diverse youth.

This movement based cross–cultural programme offered by Melissa is not only unique but also appropriate for supporting youth in underserved communities. Furthermore, this programme focuses on educational aspects as well as arts-based therapeutic practices. This means working with young people’s need for information, guidance, and clear understanding of how to make positive choices are at the core of the process.

If you would like to learn more about Melissa's wonderful work, please visit the Golden Bridge Organisation's website.


Who I am and why I am following my feet

My name is Elsmie and I am inspired by that which stirs the creative soul. Painting, movement and writing are the ways through which I express ideas or subjects that touch me deeply. During the process of researching and writing the thesis for my MA Industrial Psychology at the University of Johannesburg (2010), I studied the subjects of Positive Psychology and Embodiment Theory or ‘the embodied mind’ intensively. This experience inspired me to change my field of study to Clinical Psychology where I hope to do more research on embodiment and the therapeutic value of the creative arts. Currently I am completing undergraduate psychology subjects through the University of South Africa (UNISA) which will enable me to apply for an Honours and Master’s degree in Clinical Psychology.

Since I started my studies as a psychology student at UNISA, I have become involved in a joint project run by UNISA, the Tygerberg Art Centre and a partnering NGO where one of the first phases of this project is the establishment of an informal art centre in a multicultural community in Delft, Cape Town.

I was fortunate enough to receive a 50% scholarship to attend Surfing The Creative® workshops led by Melissa Michaels in January 2014 in Cape Town. The training for practitioners working with youth exposed me to the variety of creative arts-based methods that are available. I was amazed by the application of these methods in transcending cultural and language barriers.

In due course I hope to expand the activities at the art centre to include dance and movement, music, art and drama activities to benefit the youth of this community. The intention of this project is ultimately to inspire young high school learners to envision a positive future for themselves through the process of facilitated arts-based activities as well as long-term mentorship and support. 


What your contribution funds

Embarking on this learning opportunity depends on significant financial support. I have applied for local scholarships and I am also looking for sponsors in my community. The Golden Bridge Organisation has generously offered me a partial scholarship for the summer intensive learning programme.

My goal is to raise funds in the amount of $4000 (R44 000). Here is a breakdown of expenses:

Costs:

Training/Workshop Costs  -   $2100  (R23 100)

Travel Costs  -   $2011  (R22 121)

  • Airfare 
  • Transfers / Local Travel 

Visa Application  -   $160  (R1800)

Room & Board   -   $1360 (R14 960)

Personal Expenses   -   $460  (R5000)

TOTAL  $6091  (R67 000)


Incoming Funds: 

Golden Bridge Partial Scholarship  =   $1960  (R21 560) (Mostly toward Room & Board)

Estimated Earnings through Part-Time Work  =  $460  (R5000)

TOTAL  $2420  (R26 620)


Total amount to be raised  =  $4000  (R44 000)

(Including Indiegogo’s percentage)


Should contributions exceed the amount that I need for this campaign, funding will go towards resources for the art centre in Delft e.g. Maintenance; Transport; Art supplies and auxiliary support for kids.


The impact

Your contribution to my campaign will allow me to participate in this incredible opportunity of attending a summer learning programme abroad. My intention with this training is to broaden my understanding and experience of movement-based learning. This deepening, I hope, will allow me to understand more of who I am and to see how I can give and share this understanding with others personally and professionally. 

My love of the arts and the creative process has sparked in me the understanding that we are all essentially creative beings.  This is why I hope to be able to carry that which I learn during my time abroad into my work as a psychology student and with the community programmes I am involved in. Considering that there are no similar programmes offered in South Africa, by contributing, you will be helping me to bring much needed information and innovative ways of learning to the communities of my home country.


What you get for contributing

I am offering a range of perks to show my gratitude for contributions! These include a heartfelt shout out on my blog; a postcard from South Africa; a postcard of my feet painting (see photo); a set of 3 blank postcards of different feet paintings; an art print of my feet painting; a choice of a small original painting or a larger original painting and lastly an original painting of you and your loved ones’ feet - an unconventional family portrait!

Please note that the value of the perks include international shipping costs from South Africa.


Other ways you can help

If you would like to help in a way besides financial contribution, please share my story with friends and family!
