story:
Bref résumé

Les contributeurs financent des idées qui leur plaisent et des personnes en qui ils ont confiance. Voici quelques pistes à suivre dans cette section :

  • Présentez-vous et parlez de votre parcours.
  • Décrivez brièvement votre projet et pourquoi il est important à vos yeux.
  • Expliquez l'importance du projet auquel les contributeurs vont participer.

N'oubliez pas, restez concis mais original. Demandez-vous : si quelqu'un s'arrêtait de lire à cet endroit, serait-il prêt à faire une contribution ?

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

Fournissez plus de détails aux gens :

  • Expliquez le montant du financement dont vous avez besoin et à quoi il va servir. Soyez clair et précis : les contributeurs ont besoin de vous faire confiance pour vous aider.
  • Parlez de vos contreparties uniques. Suscitez l'intérêt de vos visiteurs !
  • Décrivez où les fonds iront si vous n'atteignez pas complètement votre objectif.

L'impact

N'hésitez pas à expliquer votre projet plus en détail et indiquez aux visiteurs en quoi leur contribution fera la différence :

  • Expliquez pourquoi votre projet est précieux pour le contributeur et pour le monde.
  • Mettez en avant vos expériences réussies sur des projets tels que celui-ci (si vous en avez).
  • Rendez votre projet concret aux yeux des visiteurs et suscitez la confiance.

Risques et défis

Les gens apprécieront la transparence de vos propos. Soyez ouvert et démarquez-vous en exposant les risques et les obstacles auxquels vous allez peut-être faire face pour atteindre votre objectif.

  • Expliquez pourquoi vous pensez être en mesure de relever ces défis.
  • Décrivez comment vous comptez résoudre ces éventuels problèmes.

D'autres façons d'aider

Certaines personnes ne peuvent pas contribuer mais cela ne veut pas dire qu'elles ne peuvent pas aider :

  • Demandez aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour de votre projet.
  • Rappelez-leur d'utiliser les outils de partage Indiegogo !

Et le tour est joué.

story:
Conor Mulligan and Chad Shelton, two San Diego State University graduate students are raising money to rent a lighting control console necessary for an independent entertainment lighting design study.

Conor and Chad are working toward their MFA in theatrical and entertainment lighting design. The independent study for which they are raising money is a study in the use of pre-visualization software in the aid of lighting design.

The project is designed as such:

A group of songs spanning multiple genres will be used as the source material for a concert lighting design package. A lighting rig will be designed and drafted for the venue assigned, The Don Powel Theatre at SDSU. To emulate the schedule of a touring show the lighting package will be loaded into the venue the day of the event. Once loaded in Conor and Chad will adjust in real space the lighting effects/cues created in the virtual space of the pre-visualization software. Once adjusted the light show will be presented.

The money raised will be for the rental of a GrandMA lighting console. This console was chosen in particular for its prevalence in the concert lighting industry as well as its pre-visualization software. A week long rental has been proposed as the appropriate amount of time for completion of the above project. The rental cost for a week is $1000. Conor and Chad are raising money to pay for this rental as part of their education and professional development.

story:
This campaign is called South Sudan Stand Up!  A program of Stand 4 Education which is geared towards bringing school supplies, uniform, clothes & shoes for children located in South Sudan. As well as providing sanitary products for women & girls who are in need of these items. 

The 20 year civil war in Sudan left the newly independent country practically devoid of infrastructure, services, or health care. The educational needs are urgent as South Sudan currently has the lowest access to education in the world. Only 33% of children between the ages of 7-14 go to school, only 10% of the girls go to school (the lowest rate in the world), and over 93% of all women in South Sudan are illiterate. For this reason, Stand 4 Education is creating a worldwide structure wherein every child and woman living in poverty is able to access education and economic opportunities to build a peaceful, prosperous, and empowered life. 

We have partnered with Impact A Village to help provide school supplies, books, uniforms and basic needs for the children of the "Malek Primary School” in South Sudan as well as sanitary and hygiene products for women and girls. The 5-room school house was completed in 2010 and holds 300 students but due to lack of schools in South Sudan, the school ended up holding about 600 students. Many students are now displaced due to the recent December 2013 conflict. We are seeking a budget of $8,500 to provide students with basic school supplies for their return to school. Stand 4 Education aims to reach this budget goal for the second and third term of the school year. 

After the mentioned budget have been raised Stand 4 Education's founder Mari Malek will travel back to South Sudan this year(date to be announced) and bring the students of the "Malek Primary School" supplies as well as bring women and girls sanitary products. Stand with Mari Malek to help the children of her native land. All the money raised will be spent on school supplies, educational materials such as backpacks, pencils, notebooks, colors etc... Mari will document this trip via photos and videos and keep you all updated of the trip through social media and our blog. Thank you for taking the time to read this and any donation will be greatly appreciated and mean the world to these children. 

If you are interested in becoming a sponsor or donating school supplies, shoes, clothing, etc... please email info@stand4education.org
For more info about our efforts please visit www.stand4education.org

#stand4education  #southsudanstandup

Every 2 T-shirts sold, provides a child in South Sudan with a school supply kit. Please go to www.magdalenaconcepts.com/shop/stand-for-educat... to purchase a $25.00 Black Unisex T-Shirt. Displaying the logo of Mari's organization, Stand for Education, boldly in front. Its fabric is a 100% fine jersey cotton, soft & durable tee. Made in the USA, hand-printed in Brooklyn using water based ink which is eco-friendly & very durable.

PRESS:

Fusion

HuffPost Live

VICE

Featured on models.com is the fundamental & dynamic drive of how & why, the Stand For Education organization came about. 

ROOTS: Stand 4 Education - http://models.com/oftheminute/?p=74019

Special Thank you to Fusion for supporting our efforts and sharing our story. 


Photos of The Malek Primary School by IMPACTAVILLAGE

The 20 year civil war in Sudan left the newly independent country practically devoid of infrastructure, services, or health care. The educational needs are urgent as South Sudan currently has the lowest access to education in the world. Only 33% of children between the ages of 7-14 go to school, only 10% of the girls go to school (the lowest rate in the world), and over 93% of all women in South Sudan are illiterate. For this reason, Stand 4 Education is creating a worldwide structure wherein every child and woman living in poverty is able to access education and economic opportunities to build a peaceful, prosperous, and empowered life. 

We have partnered with Impact A Village to help provide school supplies, books, uniforms and basic needs for the children of the "Malek Primary School” in South Sudan as well as sanitary and hygiene products for women and girls. The 5-room school house was completed in 2010 and holds 300 students but due to lack of schools in South Sudan, the school ended up holding about 600 students. Many students are now displaced due to the recent December 2013 conflict. We are seeking a budget of $8,500 to provide students with basic school supplies for their return to school. Stand 4 Education aims to reach this budget goal for the second and third term of the school year. 
After the mentioned budget have been raised Stand 4 Education's founder Mari Malek will travel back to South Sudan this year(date to be announced) and bring the students of the "Malek Primary School" supplies as well as bring women and girls sanitary products. Stand with Mari Malek to help the children of her native land. All the money raised will be spent on school supplies, educational materials such as backpacks, pencils, notebooks, colors etc... Mari will document this trip via photos and videos and keep you all updated of the trip through social media and our blog. Thank you for taking the time to read this and any donation will be greatly appreciated and mean the world to these children. 
If you are interested in becoming a sponsor or donating school supplies, shoes, clothing, etc... please email info@stand4education.orgFor more info about our efforts please visit www.stand4education.org

#stand4education  #southsudanstandup


Every 2 T-shirts sold, provides a child in South Sudan with a school supply kit. Please go to www.magdalenaconcepts.com/shop/stand-for-educat... to purchase a $25.00 Black Unisex T-Shirt. Displaying the logo of Mari's organization, Stand for Education, boldly in front. Its fabric is a 100% fine jersey cotton, soft & durable tee. Made in the USA, hand-printed in Brooklyn using water based ink which is eco-friendly & very durable.

HuffPost Live
VICE
Featured on models.com is the fundamental & dynamic drive of how & why, the Stand For Education organization came about. 
ROOTS: Stand 4 Education - http://models.com/oftheminute/?p=74019
Special Thank you to Fusion for supporting our efforts and sharing our story.

story:
Background

My name is Matt McLean and I am the director of the Young Composers & Improvisors Workshop. We are a  501 (c) 3 non-profit organization based in New York City. (I'm a full time music teacher at Little Red School House & Elisabeth Irwin High School)  In 2010 we began a progressive music curriculum where all of our 5th and 6th graders learn how music works through the experience of composing their own original pieces that are performed by professional musicians. The curriculum is based on a number of technological innovations (most importantly Noteflight), online composer mentoring and a partnership with the professional chamber group Metropolis Ensemble.  

We had the idea of setting up YCIW as a separate entity so that we could provide the service as a free resource to NYC Public Schools. 

Our Mission

Our mission is to help classroom music teachers include music composition as a viable part of their curriculum in a normal music classroom. We provide students with a progressive composition experience that takes place in the classroom with their teacher and visits from our musicians to hear their music. Every student, regardless of experience, begins composing right from the start using our progression online curriculum and with the help of online composer mentoring from YCIW composer mentors.    Young Composers & Improvisors Workshop is a free resource to NYC public schools. We held our first public school Workshop at the Bronx Charter School for the Arts on June 19, 2013 and presented our second concert in June 2014. We are now running the program in 3 NYC public schools: R.F. Wagner Secondary School for Arts and Technology, The Equity Project Charter School and the Bronx Charter School for the Arts.   You can hear all of the student pieces and see pictures and scores on our website here. 


Why Are We Fundraising Now

YCIW is running in 3 NYC public schools: R.F. Wagner Secondary School for Arts and Technology, The Excellence Project Charter School and the Bronx Charter School for the Arts.  We will have public young composer concerts of student compositions in June at both Bronx Arts and Wagner. We will hold a young composers concert at the TEP school in the Fall of 2015.  We need support in order to put on these young composers concerts.


Where Your Money Will Go

Your donations will enable us to put on 3 public concerts of student pieces at the Bronx Charter School for the Arts, R.F Wagner Secondary School for Arts and Technology and TEP School .

The money will go directly towards:

  1. Paying for 6 musicians to visit each school while the students are still working on their pieces. The young composers will have a chance to hear their music and ask questions of the musicians. This is a very important step in the composing process. 
  2. Paying for 6 musicians and 1 conductor for each of the 3  public Young Composers Concerts. The concerts will be recorded.
  3. Paying for 3 professional composer mentors. Our composer mentors provide feedback and tutelage directly on each student's Noteflight score. 

The Impact: A Community of Composers

As a music teacher I have seen the joy and satisfaction that composing original music can bring to my students.  Composing is the most powerful way of exploring skills and concepts that help students gain mastery over how music works. 

I have been very lucky at LREI to have the support which has enabled me to get over 400 student pieces performed since 2010.  I firmly believe that giving this same opportunity to as many public school children as possible will not only enrich their experience but may also help impact music education as a whole. Our connected world, along with great educational technology, has made it feasible for every student to be part of a "community of composers." A community which not only brings them lessons and strategies but also provides encouragement and mentorship. 



Help support public school students compose their own music! YCIW is a community of composers, teachers and musicians engaging public school students in a progressive online curriculum, composer mentoring and live concert performances of their original work.

story:
Can you picture it?

A traveling, edible, tactile learning garden planted right in the back of a pickup truck. A mobile farm bringing seasonal produce at different levels of growth directly to neighborhood schools. Students eagerly engaging in hands-on learning – touching, smelling, and tasting fresh fruits and vegetables. 

Our vision is to reach more schools and communities, especially those who don't have their own gardens. You can help bring the Field-to-Fork experience to more local schools.

You can help us build our own Louisville Truck Farm! 

And our target launch date is June 17, 2015!

Let’s build Truck Farm together!



Who is The Food Literacy Project?

The Food Literacy Project is a nonprofit organization that is engaging young people in farm-based education every day. Nestled on a corner of Oxmoor Farm in the Hikes Point neighborhood of Louisville, KY, the Food Literacy Project uses Field Day Family Farm as an outdoor classroom to introduce young people to the joys of farming and tasting fresh, healthful, local produce. We use our outdoor teaching kitchen and fire-brick oven to inspire young people and their families to explore the story behind their food.


More and more each year, we are also working with students in their classrooms, cafeterias, and school gardens. Through our Field-to-Fork Afterschool Clubs, students spend 12 weeks learning about nutrition, exercise, cooking, food systems, and food justice. They become leaders in their school gardens. They learn culinary skills alongside Louisville’s best chefs. They even involve their families in cooking new recipes with local produce.

Every day, we see children fall in love with vegetables – then take it one step further by becoming change agents within their own families and schools.


In a nutshell, our farm-based, hands-on educational programs are making a difference in the way young people think about food.

And right now, you have a unique opportunity to expand, deepen, and strengthen this work by making this dream of Truck Farm a delicious reality!

What is Truck Farm?

Truck Farm will be a mobile, educational garden that reaches thousands of children and their families in our community. It will enable us to bring our programs into more schools, especially those that don’t have their own gardens. 

Plus, you and your family will get to engage with Truck Farm at community fairs, farmers’ markets, and other fun events. This heightened visibility will bring the message of healthy, down-to-earth eating to thousands of Louisvillians each year!

Currently, we don’t have the resources to meet the pressing demand for our farm-based education services. But your investment in Truck Farm will help us rally the community’s support, enabling us to expand our school and farm-based programs!

The teens in our Youth Community Agriculture Program will assemble Truck Farm – they’ll fill the bed with the right layers and mix of soils, plant the first crop of vegetables, and be Truck Farm’s first ambassadors. This will be an important aspect of their 7-week deep dive into sustainable agriculture, our local food system, and healthy eating practices.



What We Need & What You Get

Truck Farm Louisville is an initiative of the Food Literacy Project at Oxmoor Farm, a 501(c)3, non-profit tax-exempt organization.

In addition to the truck itself, which needs some repairs but is being donated in-kind, Truck Farm requires lots of other resources.  We need materials like root barrier for the truck bed, expanded shale/vermiculite, compost, potting soil, seed packets, gardening tools, portable step stools so students can see over the truck bed, and bins full of teaching materials.  We also need insurance, registration, vehicle maintenance, fuel, a policy authorizing drivers of Truck Farm, and a vehicle wrap to mark this powerful resource with the Food Literacy Project’s (and sponsors’) logos.

Finally, as is true for our farm-based education programs, we need experienced staff to facilitate Truck Farm experiences, and we need the teens in our Youth Community Agriculture Program (YCAP) to invest time in transforming the pickup truck into a mobile, edible classroom.  Food Literacy Project staff will need to adapt our farm-based curricula to the Truck Farm context before taking our programs on the road.

With your help, Truck Farm will be an inspiration at over 20 schools and community events, and reach over 3,200 children and adults over the next year!

Check out the perks on the right side of this page to see what you can get from being a Truck Farm donor!

The Impact

Truck Farm will be the linchpin of our community outreach efforts and a capacity-builder for our Field-to-Fork programs.

  • We will take Truck Farm to schools so students can get their hands dirty learning about the origin of our food.
  • Kids and families will be inspired by the notion that you can build a garden anywhere!
  • Truck Farm will bring the field-to-fork experience to families at community fairs, farmers' markets, parades, and neighborhood festivals.

  • Participants will get their hands dirty, try something new, and build respect for the land and the natural world while participating in hands-on education experiences.

  • We'll spread the word of healthy, down-to-earth eating!

Risks & Challenges

We must secure $41,930 in order to launch Truck Farm and maximize its impact throughout the season.  Raising $20,000 in this campaign will transform an ordinary pickup truck into a mobile farm and inspire thousands of community members to reconsider where and how food grows. 

If we don't reach our $20,000 goal, Indiegogo will still distribute your donations to us – and that will take us a long way toward the total cost of the project.

If we surpass our goal, the extra will go towards ongoing vehicle repairs, development of further Truck Farm specific curricula, and fuel for more Truck Farm stops at local schools and community events.

Aside from funding, our biggest challenge will likely be the timeline.  Our launch date goal is in mid-June, and though the truck is on its way to us, it needs to visit the mechanic and be outfitted for vegetable-growing between now and then.  Fortunately we have competent volunteers and staff standing by to bring this vision to fruition! 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the news! Help us reach as many people as possible by sharing our campaign.
  • Volunteer! Get more info here: http://foodliteracyproject.org/volunteer.

story:
Introduction

After a successful crowd funding campaign five months ago we were able to build an extension to our lovely skate park. This with the help of a wonderful international (Germany, Maldives, UK, France and India) team whom through hard work and dedication made this project a success. This couldn’t be possible without the help of many donations through our indiegogo crowd funding campaign.
The new skate park is a huge success amongst our smaller children and our girls. Because of this success we are in need of more protective gear and funds for transport. The safety of our kids is our number one priority at the Kovalam skate club so we ask your help to make this possible.

S.I.S.P. in a nutshell

Sebastian Indian Social Projects (S.I.S.P.) is a non-profit organization working in the coastal region of Thiruvananthapuram, the capital of India’s south-western state of Kerala. S.I.S.P. was founded by two Belgians, Paul Van Gelder and Werner Fynaerts in 1996. S.I.S.P. strives to accelerate social and economic change in the rural context by collaborating with local community members to build a better society where all people have easy access to education, health care, and employment opportunities. S.I.S.P. has an explicit commitment to remain disassociated from any religious activity and to work both for and all side the poorest among all communities.

“No school, no skating”

The S.I.S.P. Kovalam Skate Club is located at S.I.S.P., Kovalam, India and was founded in 2014 as a part of the bigger NGO S.I.S.P.  We had already co-founded earlier the Kovalam Surf Club and the principle “no school, no surfing”, but during monsoon we had no alternative. Now with free skateboarding lessons we can motivate the school drop-outs also during monsoon to continue their education with “no school, no skating”.

Skateboarding has been proven to be extremely popular amongst youth from all cultures and social backgrounds and is, just like surfing, a powerful tool to uplift youngsters facing harsh living conditions.

An advantage of having an open-air park is that also girls get more attracted to skating. Parents here often worry about their daughters practicing sports in the presence of boys. Having a park in the school courtyard means that girls will be able to skate in presence of adults in an easily visible place, so they will feel more at ease. At present the girls often can’t join the boys in their games because the girls’ clothes are impeding or the sport is culturally not considered suitable for girls. Skating overcomes both these boundaries and contributes to equality between boys and girls, which is still, unfortunately, uncommon in most of India.

Keep the dream alive

Today we are facing some difficulties with traditional Indian customs. A lot of our girls in S.I.S.P. are interested to learn more about skateboarding but aren’t allowed from their families. This because they have to take the bus on their own towards the skate park. This is also the case for our smaller children. We want these children to be able to enjoy skateboarding as we know it is a powerfull tool for youth empowerment.

Due to the popularity of our newest skate park we have more and more children who want to participate in the project. We are in lack of enough protective gear to keep the children safe.

What do we need?

  • To bring our school girls and smallest children safely to the skate park we’re in need of funds for a rickshaw service.
  • Helmets, knee pads, elbow pads and wrist protection for the new members of the Kovalam Skate Club.

Pleas visit http://www.sisp.in/ for more information about our projects.

story:
This coming spring marks the 10th anniversary of the Ivy Native Conference, a conference dedicated to bringing together Native American undergraduate students, graduate students, and affiliates from across the Ivy League schools in order to create a space for important dialogues focusing on issues facing our Native communities today. The Ivy Native Council (INC) is comprised of student representatives from each of the Ivy Leagues. Every year INC hosts two gatherings: the Summit during the Fall and the Conference in the Spring. INC votes each year on the location of the Summit and Conference to rotate hosting the events, allowing each Ivy League institution the opportunity to host.

Native Americans at Harvard College is very excited to be hosting this year's Ivy Conference, which will take place April 10th-12th 2015. Our conference’s theme is “Economic Vibrancy in 21st Century Native Communities”, and will focus on the widely diverse economic endeavors, challenges, and successes present throughout Indian Country. To fully realize our vision, we would like to invite all of you to support our conference.

We are a student-run organization, and while we have support of the university and affiliated programs, we must seek outside funding to cover all our costs. With your help, we hope to host a successful conference and provide the necessary provisions for our attendees and speakers in order to support the important dialogue that will take place. We hope that all who are able to help us will as the annual conference provides a place for native students to gather and communicate about issues directly affecting our communities, to propose ways of tackling these issues, and to support each other through all trials we may face. The conference and summit allow us all to connect and band together in a safe place where we can truly work towards the futures of ourselves and our communities. 

Thank you immensely for your time and consideration.


Note on perks:

Should you contribute the $50 minimum to receive the personal thank you on behalf of all of us, we request that you leave a comment with your email so that we may provide you with this as soon as possible. We thank all of you again.

We are a student-run
organization, and while we have support of the university and affiliated
programs, we must seek outside funding to cover all our costs. With your
help, we hope to host a successful conference and provide the
necessary provisions for our attendees and speakers in order to support the
important dialogue that will take place. We hope that all who are able to help us will as the annual conference provides a place for native students to gather and communicate about issues directly affecting our communities, to propose ways of tackling these issues, and to support each other through all trials we may face. The conference and summit allow us all to connect and band together in a safe place where we can truly work towards the futures of ourselves and our communities. 
Thank you immensely
for your time and consideration.Note on perks:Should you contribute the $50 minimum to receive the personal thank you on behalf of all of us, we request that you leave a comment with your email so that we may provide you with this as soon as possible. We thank all of you again.

story:
Below BC Wants to Raise $25,000!

Below BC is a new non-profit society created in 2015 with a quest to bring geology and the broader earth sciences alive for the public through education and a variety of media.

In 2016, we have set our sights on developing informative and fun online resources that are accessible to everyone. We started by photographing some of the spectacular mineral collections held out of public view at the Pacific Museum of the Earth at the University of British Columbia. These images, along with the stories behind each mineral, have been extremely popular with geologists and science enthusiasts everywhere.


Our next step is to develop an intuitive 'online museum' to host these images and to showcase the geological treasures BC has to offer. That got us to thinking… rather than photographing images in 2-Dimensions, can we bring a full 3-Dimensions to this experience? Turns out we can, but we need your help. Below BC wants to buy a 3-D camera that is typically used for commercial product photography to allow us to record and manipulate an image from all angles. This will allow the viewer to experience the specimen as if you were holding it in your hand and looking up its life history all at the same time. 

The funding will also go towards enhancing our website and hosting the online museum to increase the public’s access to the finest mineral specimens BC has to offer.

For more information on other initiatives Below BC is undertaking in 2016, please visit our website at www.belowbc.com


What We Need & What You Get

Any funding we raise will be invested directly into Below BC. If we reach our goal of $25,000, we will be able to purchase the 3D photography equipment and start to curate our enhanced website  and online museum. A portion of the funds will also cover the costs associated with photographing private rock, mineral and fossil collections throughout BC.

By contributing, you are helping bring a rich and varied geological collection to life! Specimens from across the province will be brought together in one place and accessible to everyone. For the scientific community, we will also include 'type specimens' to help with interactive education and research into the geological abundance of British Columbia.

We are offering some amazing rewards for your contribution!

  • $50 - Receive a 'mystery mineral or fossil' specimen from us
  • $100 - Set of six Below BC Mineral postcards
  • $200 - The Ultimate Geological Reference Card pack!
  • $500 - Receive one of each of the above!
  • $1000 - Family pass to the Britannia Mine Museum
  • $5000 - Below BC will come to you* and use our new equipment to photography your rock specimens to use on your corporate website
* must be in BC, maximum one day of photography


The Impact

This project is just one of Below BC’s many initiatives to share BC’s rich and varied geological history with you. Our online museum will allow these usually inaccessible rocks, minerals and fossils to become a hands-on resource for all British Columbians. 


Risks & Challenges

The risks for this project are minimal. If we do not meet our goals, then the funds raised will be used to fund other aspects of Below BC and help cover the costs of some of the outreach programs we already have in place (see www.belowbc.com for a list of our 2016 activities). This is not our only source of funding - we are also looking at the research, education and geological organizations who offer a variety of grants. 

In 2015, we achieved an exceptional amount with a relatively small grant. We have continuously experienced a demand from both the public and scientific community for the resources we are developing, and are keen to share our love of the natural world through geoscience education and outreach!


Other Ways You Can Help

As they say “Sharing is Caring” – but for us that doesn’t necessarily mean money – help spread the word by supporting our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn… or your book club, hiking group, and even your friends. Use your imagination – we certainly do! 

We are also co-hosting the upcoming Vancouver Gem and Mineral Show between March 11th and 13th. 100% of the ticket sales sold through this link will be donated to Below BC!

story:
Short Summary

Boneshaker Books is a community supported, collectively organized, and all volunteer staffed bookstore. Since opening in 2011, we've been a welcoming space that promotes social justice through books, education and activism in our community. We offer discerning readers a curated selection of progressive and radical literature, non-fiction, graphic novels, poetry, and zines that spark conversation, inform and inspire. 

As a community supported bookstore, we rely on your support to stay fabulous. Renew your vows to Boneshaker Books with a donation, and fall in love with us all over again! 

None of us are independently wealthy, and there aren't exactly any investors knocking down our door to keep independent bookstores alive. And yet, here we are. Thanks to your purchases, thanks to your events, thanks to your donations, thanks to your love. You keep us alive. You are the literal backbone of Boneshaker Books - and with your donation of $250 or more, you'll make it official by joining our Skeleton Crew.

When you join our Skeleton Crew, Boneshaker Books will carry your favorite book in our permanent collection forever. That's right- we won't let it go out of stock, ever. By joining our Skeleton Crew you have the opportunity to not only support Boneshaker Books, but also make a contribution to your fellow community members! Give the gift of a book - and the gift of a bookstore.  

Boneshaker has grown a lot in the past five years. Our inventory is bigger than ever, we host dozens of events every year, and our community of readers continues to grow stronger. We intend to keep growing for many years to come. This year we're launching a Bicycle Book Trailer to help us attend events across the Twin Cities. We're dipping our toes into online sales. We're paying off debt and becoming sustainable, long-term. We want to be your local bookstore for many more years, and it starts here. Today. With your donation. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We expect to spend around $1,000 on building/stocking our Bicycle Book Trailer. Many of our volunteers do not own cars, but we can't ignore tabling at events. By helping us build a Bicycle Book Trailer, we'll be able to table at more events without compromising our ideals about sustainable transportation.
  • As we dip our toes into the scary world of Online Sales, we'll have some start-up costs along the way. But without taking this step, Boneshaker may get left behind by progress. We need to see if online sales is right for Boneshaker Books, and with your support, we can.
  • And finally, your contributions will assist with the very un-sexy chore of paying off some debt. A more financially independent bank account = more books on our shelves = more sales = a more sustainable Boneshaker Books.
In exchange for your generous financial contribution, we've got some exciting rewards for every level of support:
  • Skeleton Crew membership! Have your favorite book carried forever at Boneshaker Books. Never tell someone to just buy it from Amazon again.
  • Personalized love letters, written by a Boneshaker collective member in the literary style of your choice. 
  • A book blind date! Tell us a little about yourself, and we'll set you up with the book of your dreams! Comes complimentary with bubble bath solution, chocolates, and a Boneshaker beer coozie. 
  • A comix-style portrait of yourself as a witch, drawn by local artist and Boneshaker, Anna Bongiovanni!
  • And more!

The Impact

Short term, your contribution will fully fund our Bicycle Book Trailer, and will launch Boneshaker Books into the exciting world of online sales. You'll also help our Skeleton Crew section grow into a true representation of the diverse interests of our community, and you'll be able to confidently tell your friends where they can pick up your book recommendation. Never tell them to just order it on Amazon again.  
Long term, those investments should result in a Boneshaker Books with multiple funding streams, and more financial stability. We feel strongly about the importance and necessity of bookstores, especially for the many radicals and weirdos who make up the Boneshaker community. Boneshaker Books is an important space for the Twin Cities' radical community, providing a welcoming space that promotes social justice through books, education and activism in our community. Your support of Boneshaker is important for our bookstore, important for our community, and important for you - because you're a part of our bookstore, too.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Think again. Maybe you can't make a financial contribution, but you can contribute in other ways! Spread the word about our funding efforts on social media, to your email contacts, and face-to-face with your friends and co-workers. Your enthusiasm for Boneshaker Books is contagious, and soon enough your friends and neighbors will feel it too!

And you can always support us the old fashioned way - by stopping in for some conversation and a book!

story:
Short Summary

I fell in love with weight training in high school. As an obese teenager, I struggled a lot with body image but found pride in gaining strength through working out. I've pursued fitness from multiple angles and discovered Crossfit in 2014. It changed my entire thought process on what it meant to be "fit" and "strong" and helped me overcome a negative mindset towards myself. My desire is to grow in my knowledge and understanding so I can help people in this same journey. I want to inspire and equip others!

What I Need & What You Get

  • Crossfit certification happens through a weekend course of physical and knowledge testing. The fee for the course and certification is $1,000.
  • My goal is to raise $1,000 to cover the course. Any additional money given will go towards room & board for the weekend, travel expenses, and fees.
  • I have registered for the course, so regardless of reaching the intended goal, I will be attending. My intent with this campaign is to relieve pressure financially on my family. We are a one income family with a 13-month old boy. 
  • I will be giving various perks to all those who contribute! From a free workout to personal training sessions, I want you to know your money has blessed me and I want to give back!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute, consider sharing this with some of your friends who might be able to!

story:
The Front Porch

Inspired by the rich musical heritage of Central Virginia, The Front Porch connects people from all walks of life through traditional roots music. Our talented instructors offer classes and jams in a variety of musical styles, including bluegrass, old time, acoustic blues, and folk. The Front Porch’s listening room hosts world class performers in an intimate environment. We hold family-friendly dances, jamborees, and outdoor concerts throughout the year. 

Our place in the Charlottesville area is unique and crucial. The Front Porch gives people of all ages and abilities a place to learn and play music with others. We prioritize educating and preserving vital cultural traditions that originated in Appalachia and the Piedmont. We emphasize, above all, direct participation in the creative process.

What We Need 

Numerous costs add up quickly when launching a non-profit. Revenue from tuition and ticket sales alone does not cover the cost of providing our programs to the community. Over 90% of our costs are directly attributable to our programs.  The Front Porch's programming will be made available to anyone, regardless of their ability to pay.  We need funds to support students who can’t afford lessons or instruments, and to bring local talent to our events, jams and workshops. We need support to retain qualified teachers and to meet all other expenses in order to meet our mission objectives.

Your support will fund:

Scholarships and tuition assistance ($8,000)

Instrument loan program ($2,000)

Community events and concerts ($3,000)

Jams and workshops ($1,000)

Administrative costs ($1,000)

Your contribution will grow the Front Porch into a dynamic center where ALL people who wish to participate may do so. We are offering rewards for each donation tier, but ultimately the impact is the real reward. Every gift counts. We need to demonstrate broad public support for this grassroots, volunteer-led arts organization.

Our Vision

Our goal is to create a hub for traditional and roots music in Central Virginia by engaging as many people as possible. We are already partnering with other non-profit music organizations. We plan to host educational and performance events for diverse audiences across a wide range of acoustic genres. And we want to expand our reach into local schools and community centers.  

Of course there are challenges to launching a non-profit music center. It requires tremendous collective energy and support. The Front Porch must arise from a shared belief in the power of music to create meaningful experiences and grow a strong community. Show your support today. Vote for arts education and cultural preservation by giving generously to this worthy project. 

Warmly,

Emily Morrison

Executive Director

story:
Our Story

The Pop-Up Museum of Queer History is a grassroots organization that transforms empty spaces into temporary autonomous shrines dedicated to celebrating the rich, long, and largely unknown histories of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people. We believe that our community - and especially our youth - deserve to know our history. If you don't know you have a past, you can't believe you have a future.

 

In cooperation with the Leslie Lohman Gay Art Foundation, the next Museum will pop up in NYC from August 6 - 25th. We need your help! We have artists, academics, and interested historians (amateur and professional!) creating exhibits on everything from intersex immigrants in the early 1900s, to the life of Carl van Vechten, to oral histories of American queers. We have a screening series of historical lesbian movies. We have a professional development class designed to teach secondary school teachers the importance of including queer lives and events in their curricula. Now, all we need is the money to make this happen.

The Impact

The Pop-Up Museum will make queer history visible in a fun, engaging way. We will show that queer history didn't begin with Stonewall, isn't only found in New York or San Francisco, and isn't just about well-off, white communities. We will bring our installations to any community interested in partnering with us. We will actively work with educators to use the museum as a teachable moment for youth of all genders and sexual orientations.

What We Need & What You Get

As a small community organization, even a $5 donation means a lot to us! Our goal of $5000 will enable us to create the next physical manifestation of the Pop-Up Museum, as well as provide a basic website to archive all the exhibits. Any money raised over our goal will go to creating future Pop-Up installations around the country, and strengthening our web presence, thereby making queer history available to everyone with an internet connection. We are thankful to be under the fiscal sponsorship of the MIX NYC Queer Experimental Film Festival, meaning that all donations are tax deductible. We are pursuing many other funding avenues, including grants, co-sponsorships with queer organizations, and individual donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Let folks know about us! Like us on Facebook (Facebook.com/QMuseum)!

If you're interested in making an exhibit or volunteering, shoot us an email at queermuseum@gmail.com.

story:
Our Story

I'm a franco-american filmmaker with 10 years of experience. I went to Haiti on FEBRUARY 20th  to shoot a documentary film following my long time friend CLAIRE FALISSE and her association Prométhée Humanitaire that supports "CHEMINS LA VIE / PATHS  OF LIFE", a STREET CHILDREN local association in Jacmel. I will join Claire in one of the towns that was devastated by the 2010 earthquake. We will get a close eye view of the what she's doing there and of course meet the boys, listen to their stories. After getting funding for a piece of land near Jacmel, Claire's intention is to raise enough money to build an orphanage there for 20 orphaned children.

Here's Prométhée Humanitaire's website:

www.prometheehumanitaire.org/en/index.php

You can find out about me and my small independent production:

www.clockwise1.com/

 

Cinéaste américano-francais avec 10 ans d'expérience, je reviens de Haïti  ou j'ai tourner tourner un film documentaire qui suit CLAIRE FALISSE mon amie de longue date et les efforts de son association Prométhée Humanitaire qui finance une association locale offrant un CENTRE ("Chemins La Vie") aux enfants des rues de Jacmel, une des villes dévastée par le séisme de 2010. Nous verrons de près  les efforts de claire sur place et bien sûr rencontrerons les garçons du centre, écouterons leurs histoires. L'intention de Claire est de réunir assez d'argent pour construire un orphelinat pour héberger 20 enfants victimes  du séisme de 2010.

Voici le site Web de Prométhée Humanitaire:

www.prometheehumanitaire.org/

Voici un lien pour en savoir plus sur moi et ma petite production 

www.clockwise1.com/

 

The Impact

This documentary film aims to raise awareness on the situation of Haiti through a personal POV of someone (CLAIRE) who, just like you and me, has a normal life but wants to contribute and do something for a great cause. After witnessing first hand on my end in Vietnam, the addiction that comes when you start to help the most deprived endangered human beings, I saw the difference one can make in a street child's life by just giving some of your time, and want to continue promoting this idea. The once beautiful little town of Jacmel is also in the process of being rebuilt from the ground up and it will certainly play a key part in the future of these kids.

Thank you for your contributions.

Ce film documentaire vise à sensibiliser le public sur la situation en Haïti à travers une vision personnelle de quelqu'un (CLAIRE) qui, tout comme vous et moi, mène une vie normale, mais veut contribuer et faire quelque chose pour une grande cause. Après avoir été témoin moi même au Vietnam, de la joie qui survient quand on commence à aider les plus démunis des êtres humains, j'ai vu la différence qu'on peut faire dans la vie d'un enfant de la rue, en donnant simplement un peu de son temps. Je veux continuer a promouvoir cette idée. La ville de Jacmel, autrefois magnifique est également en train d'être reconstruite et cette reconstruction jouera certainement un rôle clé dans l'avenir de ces enfants.

Pour INFO: Le site INDIEGOGO accepte, par PAYPAL ou CARTE DE CRÉDIT / DÉBIT, les dons qu'il me verserons par la suite et ceux-ci servirons strictement a faire de ce reportage un pilier pour l'appel de fonds en faveur de Prométhée Humanitaire et ses efforts en Haiti. Prométhée est une association reconnue d’utilité publique en France.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7'500.

This will go towards trip and transportation expenses, staying there 14 days (food and lodging) and editing. 


Nous avons besoin de $7'500.

Ceci couvrira les dépenses de voyage, transport sur place, 14 jours, déplacements, tournage, montage. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Please show your support by LIKING us on FACEBOOK:

https://www.facebook.com/promethee.humanitaire

 

Find out about Promethee and how they work. 

http://www.prometheehumanitaire.org/en/index.php

We are looking for ways to establish ourselves in the States as well. Right now we are recognized by the French governemt as a legal trustworthy association (which is no small feat if you know the french:O)

P.H. claims an altruistic approach to raise awareness of these children's catastrophic situation, victims of hunger, disease, abuse or prostitution.

 

Blog about us, Twitter about us

Claire's interview has been shown on many humanitarian geared websites:

http://www.action-gscf.com/humanitaire/tag/fali...

http://www.goodnesstv.org/en/videos/voir/27460/2/

http://voltaire.magnify.net/video/Promthe-Human...

 

PS

Feel free to ask me for translation in case something's in french and you'd like a transcript.

 

Thank you / Merci
story_txt:
Our Story
I'm a franco-american filmmaker with 10 years of experience. I went to Haiti on FEBRUARY 20th  to shoot a documentary film following my long time friend CLAIRE FALISSE and her association Prométhée Humanitaire that supports "CHEMINS LA VIE / PATHS  OF LIFE", a STREET CHILDREN local association in Jacmel. I will join Claire in one of the towns that was devastated by the 2010 earthquake. We will get a close eye view of the what she's doing there and of course meet the boys, listen to their stories. After getting funding for a piece of land near Jacmel, Claire's intention  is to raise enough money to build an orphanage there for 20 orphaned children. 
Here's Prométhée Humanitaire's website:
www.prometheehumanitaire.org/en/index.php
You can find out about me and my small independent production:
www.clockwise1.com/
 
Cinéaste américano-francais avec 10 ans d'expérience, je reviens de Haïti  ou j'ai tourner tourner un film documentaire qui suit CLAIRE FALISSE mon amie de longue date et les efforts de son association Prométhée Humanitaire qui finance une association locale offrant un CENTRE ("Chemins La Vie") aux enfants des rues de Jacmel, une des villes dévastée par le séisme de 2010. Nous verrons de près  les efforts de claire sur place et bien sûr rencontrerons les garçons du centre, écouterons leurs histoires. L'intention de Claire est de réunir assez d'argent pour construire un orphelinat pour héberger 20 enfants victimes  du séisme de 2010.
Voici le site Web de Prométhée Humanitaire:
www.prometheehumanitaire.org/
Voici un lien pour en savoir plus sur moi et ma petite production 
www.clockwise1.com/
 


The Impact
This documentary film aims to raise awareness on the situation of Haiti through a personal POV of someone (CLAIRE) who, just like you and me, has a normal life but wants to contribute and do something for a great cause. After witnessing first hand on my end in Vietnam, the addiction that comes when you start to help the most deprived endangered human beings, I saw the difference one can make in a street child's life by just giving some of your time, and want to continue promoting this idea. The once beautiful little town of Jacmel is also in the process of being rebuilt from the ground up and it will certainly play a key part in the future of these kids.
Thank you for your contributions.

story:
Hello Everyone!

     My name is Asia Williams and I’m a senior at The Florida State University, I was 1 of 5 to be selected among 5,000 students to represent The College of Human Sciences in our International Study Abroad Program in London, England. I have been waiting to be apart of this program since my freshman year and now that I have the opportunity I'm financially unable to go. Florida Legislative has recently passed a bill that grant funding is no longer allotted for summer courses, and my first generation student grant was under the funding. The cost of tuition, books, and room and board is $6,000 and I’m only receiving $3,750 in student loans, I’ve asked close friends and family to assist me but I’m still short $2,000.

     I’m extremely active in the Tallahassee community. I’ve helped raised over $3,000 to assist with HIV/AIDS research and treatment on a local and national level through my Sorority Sigma Gamma Rho, and started my Chapters first annual Scholarship Pageant that honors outstanding young men that are making a difference on a collegiate and local level.

      I’m passionate about serving others and educating our youth and have goals of becoming a high school counselor to empower students to seek higher education. I’m asking you to look deep in your heart and even deeper in your wallet to assist me in this opportunity. ANY donations will be truly appreciated and if you are unable to assist me financially, spreading the word about this campaign and your heart felt prayers are ALWAYS welcomed!

 

Thank you so much and God bless!

story:
I WANT TO THANK MY ANONYMOUS DONOR. THANK YOU SO MUCH! I WON'T LET YOU DOWN. :)

THANKS KIMBERLY RICHARDS! YOU'RE THE BEST!!

FOR PEOPLE WHO CHOOSE PERKS, PLEASE EMAIL ME AT rmani.indiegogo@yahoo.com SO THAT I CAN SEND YOU WHAT i OWE YOU. PLEASE INCLUDE YOUR NAME AND THE PERK YOU CHOSE. THANKS SO MUCH FOR DONATING!!!

The Story of a Girl who Really Wants to Spend her Summer at Stanford! :) Please Read

     Hi! My name is R'mani Haulcy. Nice to meet you! Thank you for taking the time to view my campaign. So I know you must be wondering. What exactly does this person want? Well, I'm not a director for some amazing, up-and-coming movie. I'm not fundraising for a lethal disease, nor am I suffering from one so it can't be any of that. I'm just a teenage girl with big dreams and I need your help. 

      I'm 16-years-old and broke but I don't want that to hold me back when I'm faced with new opportunities. I attend Walter Payton High School in Chicago, IL and I am a junior. I went to an elementary school sponsored by the University of Chicago. Because of this, I was challenged from the time I walked through the door and I've pushed myself ever since. My school was technology-driven and left me with knowledge of movie making (iMovie), song making (GarageBand), and much more. I've been working my butt off for as long as I can remember and I continue to work as hard as I can everyday. I have maintained a GPA of 4.7 out of 5, sometimes higher, since my freshman year of high school. I graduated from my elementary school as my class' valedictorian. I take advantage of the numerous opportunities at my school and challenge myself every year with college level classes. I'm also taking an eighth class at Harold Washington College downtown so that I can get general requirements for college out of the way and strengthen myself as an applicant. I am doing my part to make sure Stanford sees that I will be an amazing asset to their school. I'm also a goofy, fun-loving actress/writer/singer/musician/artist/whatever else you can think of. My extracurricular activities make me all the more well rounded. I have so much potential and I want to share it with the world. I just need a little help. 

     What I really need your help with is a summer program at Stanford University for high school students. Stanford is my dream school and this might be my only chance to see the school and make sure I want to go there before applying for early decision. I've only been on a plane once. I've never really had a chance to see the world. I'm extremely social and I love experiencing new things. Attending this program at Stanford would give me college credits that I can't get elsewhere and a summer I will never forget.

     I'm new to Indiegogo so I'm just trying it out. I can't find a scholarship that isn't too specific and my family just does not have the money so Indiegogo is my only hope. Please help as much as you can!

The Impact

     I want to be inspiration for those around me. I find pride in giving others hope and I do so by being an example. If I can do it, anyone can. The elementary school that I went to wasn't top notch but I managed to get accepted into one of the top high schools in my city and now I want to go to a top college. I don't plan on letting anything stop me. The journey will just be a lot easier with the help of you guys out there. 

     If I can't go to Stanford I won't die and I won't lose my job but I will miss out on an incredible opportunity and be a lot less prepared for the world around me. I've made a mistake by allowing myself to get so excited about the program but I have done so and it would heartbreaking if I could not attend the program simply because I could not afford it.

What We Need & What You Get

     In the end I need $11,000. I have to pay for my plane tickets there and back home, room and board and at least eight college courses. It truly is the college experience encompassed in eight short weeks. In the end, the price for the program is $11,019 and that doesn't include toiletries that I have to buy and spending money for trips we take while we're there. I hope it goes well!

     If I don't reach my goal, the money will be saved for my college education. So many colleges have expensive application fees so any money that I can get would be tremendously helpful.

Other Ways You Can Help

     If you can't donate money, and I completely understand if you can't, you can also help me get that much closer to Stanford by telling people about my cause. I need as much help as i can get. Tell friends and family or colleagues. Who ever. All I ask is that you help me spread the word. If you help me get there, I promise I won't let anyone down. I won't take your money for granted. I'm going to do big things in life and if you help me, I'll help who ever else I can tenfold. Thank you again for your time. :)

     If I don't reach my goal, the money will be saved for my college education. So many colleges have expensive application fees so any money that I can get would be tremendously helpful.

Other Ways You Can Help
     If you can't donate money, and I completely understand if you can't, you can also help me get that much closer to Stanford by telling people about my cause. I need as much help as i can get. Tell friends and family or colleagues. Who ever. All I ask is that you help me spread the word. If you help me get there, I promise I won't let anyone down. I won't take your money for granted. I'm going to do big things in life and if you help me, I'll help who ever else I can tenfold. Thank you again for your time. :)

story:
My Story

I have lived, volunteered with, and rescued wolves and wolf dogs for the past 12 years.  I am currently studying to recieve my degree in Wolf Ethology.  Studying wolves in the wild is an invaluable experience that few scientist ever actually get.  

Once I recieve my degree I plan on working as a wolf-conservationist and to continue my wolf dog rescue work.    


The Impact

This money will ensure that I am able to get first hand educational experience viewing wolves in the wild.  Most research of wolves has been done with captive wolves behind fences.  In recent years it has been discovered that there is a big difference between the lives of captive wolves and those of wild wolves.  To have the opportunity to have direct experience with wild wolves is the chance of a lifetime and one of the most profound learning opportunities available.  This experience will count directly toward my degree which will better prepare me for real world experiences after college. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please e-mail, facebook, twitter and share this campaign with others.

story:
Our Story

We are Heritage High School in East Harlem and we are starting a band! Founded in 1996 with help from Columbia University Teacher's College, the school was founded as an arts integration school. All of our 300 students take music and art. Only a few public high schools in New York City offer art or music, and we are fortunate to have both.

 

We are starting a band! When music is studied without music making it is foreign and abstract. By putting instruments into the students' hands, music goes from being a subject of study to something that is alive and comes from within. It becomes personal. To help teach our students of their musical heritage, we will play and perform various musical styles that developed in Harlem such as jazz, blues, and afro-cuban jazz.

The Impact

Your money will help put instruments in students' hands. Students feel entrusted with instruments, empowered by playing in an ensemble, and engaged by making music. Many of our students come from humble backgrounds; 82% are on free or reduced-price lunch. To be responsible for an instrument of their own will be a profound experience for our students many of whom have rarely been trusted with valuable equipment. Also music education has been shown to positively influence students' self-confidence, creativity, and test scores in other subjects. Creating a band will encourage positive growth in our students and our school community as a whole.

 

Band programs also bring together parents and communities. Through public performances this ensemble can raise awareness for the school and bolster morale. When parents see their child learn an instrument and perform in concert they appreciate the opportunity that was offered their child and want to help the school. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need saxophones, trombones, trumpets, basses, pianos and drums. The best deals are available through ebay and I can play the instruments to inspect the quality of what is purchased. If you have an instrument you'd like to donate directly, please e-mail anavedo@schools.nyc.gov. We have had over 20 students cycle through the band program but there are only instruments enough for a few kids at a time. Some of the instruments that we do have are in disrepair or need to be replaced.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Post this link on your facebook page or share the link with interested friends! Every little bit helps! Again, if you have a trumpet, trombone, saxophone, keyboard, or bass that you would like to donate please contact me directly at anavedo@schools.nyc.gov.

story:
I am Eric, an artist wanting to return to college to continue my formal training in creative arts.

My work centers on drawing, painting, and digital art influenced by animation and pop art. I create impressions of characters, imagining them in other worlds and different states of mind. If I’m creating a drawing it may take the form of a sketch a more complicated piece depending on my mood. Paintings are a great way to go more in-depth and in detail. My pieces are created out of various emotions and this gives me the ability to explore and navigate thoughts and feelings. It is my hope that when people see my work that they are drawn into the emotion and world of each image.

I have found art as a release from negative mental illness symptoms. Art has always been a fulfilling way for me to relax and express myself.

I simply love making art and it is a major part of who I am. Since high school I’ve participated in Untitled group shows in Nashville for 5 years. In addition to my work having been selected for 3 group exhibits, my art has also been featured in four publications. In 2008 I had a solo exhibit at Outloud! bookstore, which was an incredible learning experience. The education I have received so far has been a great influence on my artwork.

After one year at Middle Tennessee State University I had the opportunity to go to Memphis College of Art and Design. Due to my severe symptoms of bipolar disorder I was unable to continue. I returned to the middle Tennessee area. In early 2011, I was lucky to be provided shelter and assistance from an organization called Park Center and remained in a special program there until August 2012.

During this time I returned to Middle Tennessee State University. Because I was spending over 5 hours a day commuting from Nashville to Murfreesboro using public transportation, in addition classes, I was unable to meet treatment requirements. Imagine starting school full time after not attending for years and being unable to go to your doctors or therapist for mental health treatment. I had to withdraw from classes. Because of my withdrawal I now owe money to the directly to the university.

Since that time I have been living independently in Murfreesboro and paying off my MTSU bill with my Social Security income.

 Now that my recovery is progressing really well I want to continue my college education. But to do so I must first pay off the remaining bill at Middle Tennessee State University. Until I pay the amount in full I will not be able to register for classes nor get my transcripts to apply for any other school. I've been looking forward to paying off this bill because I really want to attend school in fall of 2014. To finish paying off this bill at the current rate that I'm able to afford with my disability income it will take over two years. To pay off my withdrawal bill before then I need your assistance. Because my goal is to go back to school for art I decided art is the best way to reach it!

There are many rewards for donating- All made with passion and love.

Funds raised will go towards paying off my bill and expenses related to returning to school such as moving, school supplies, and transportation, as well as creation of perks!

Please Share with all of your friends!

treatment requirements. Imagine starting school full time after not attending
for years and being unable to go to your doctors or therapist for mental health
treatment. I had to withdraw from classes. Because of my withdrawal I now owe
money to the directly to the university.
Since that time I have been living independently in Murfreesboro and
paying off my MTSU bill with my Social Security income. Now that my recovery is progressing really well I want to
continue my college education. But to do so I must first pay off the remaining
bill at Middle Tennessee State University. Until I pay the amount in full I
will not be able to register for classes nor get my transcripts to apply for any
other school. I've been looking forward to paying off this bill because I
really want to attend school in fall of 2014. To finish paying off this bill at
the current rate that I'm able to afford with my disability income it will take
over two years. To pay off my withdrawal bill before then I need your
assistance. Because my goal is to go back to school for art I decided art is
the best way to reach it!There are many rewards for donating- All made with passion
and love.
Funds raised will go towards paying off my bill and
expenses related to returning to school such as moving, school supplies, and
transportation, as well as creation of perks!Please Share with all of your friends!

story:
I am a 46 yr old HIV+ male living in Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) and current have been accepted to MacTech Distance Education http://www.homeed.com of Nova Scotia to take a A+ Technical Support Specialist course to help me reduce or eliminate my need for ODSP.  I am hoping to raise the funds to help pay a short fall for my education, I did receive a percentage of grant from Ontario Student Assistance Program (OSAP), but not total funding.

When I graduate from the course I intend to open my own business in the Muskoka Parry Sound area offering Computer Sales and Service, where there is a lack of this type of business in the area.  This being a tourist area, I know many tourist who bring their laptop and/or computer with them to the cottage to be able to either take an extra day from work (I know lots of people who do this) and also keep in touch with friends and family who are not with them, also the local residents in Town that have computers.

I have spent many years playing with and working on my own computer, and I built my own computer from Scratch so that I could take advantage of High Graphics ability for some programs that I do use.

If you would like to send Donations to me Directly, your can send your Cheque or Money Order to:

Rod Levett

P.O. Box 173

MacTier, ON

P0C 1H0

Your help will be greatly appreciated in this endeavour, as I am working hard to secure funding from other sources as well, so please make your donation today, I would greatly appreciate it.

KickTraq Crowdfunding Help 

Kicking It Forward

story:
What does a chocolate tub have to do with helping today's children remember the Holocaust?

Hi, my name is Leon Prochnik

Long before the fictitious Willie Wonka, I was a REAL boy whose family owned the second largest chocolate factory in Poland.

Each time I visited the factory I’d race over to this giant tub full of melted chocolate, stick my arm in the tub and lick off every last drop of chocolate my mischievous arm had scooped up.

But this sweet ritual was not to last.

When I was six years old, Hitler’s armies invaded Poland with a mandate to kill the country’s Jews, and because my family was Jewish, we found ourselves fleeing for our lives.

                                                 

   THE BOY FROM KRAKOW - Photo of me in Krakow's Main Square in May        1939 - three months before the German invasion.

For the next year and a half our exodus carried us from Poland to Lithuania, from Lithuania to Russia, from Russia to Japan, from Japan to Canada, and, finally, blessedly, to the United States.

During my family’s flight from darkness I kept my spirits up with memories of the chocolate tub.

But although I'm an award-winning author and lecturer, until earlier this year when Los Angeles’ Museum of Tolerance invited me to share my Holocaust Survivor story with middle-school students, I'd resisted lecturing or writing about my experience of the Holocaust (to avoid painful memories I'd long ago convinced myself that my story, especially the part about the chocolate tub, was too "childish").

Ironically,  when I did share my story at the Museum of Tolerance, it was the tub's persistence in my thoughts and dreams during my family's flight from Nazi-occupied Poland that most gripped my young listeners (after my presentation, as the students mobbed me for autographs, a boy asked "Was the chocolate in the tub milk or dark?", a girl asked "Do you still dream about the tub?", and another girl clutched my hand and announced "You're my hero!").

And the excitement was just beginning.

That very afternoon an official from the Museum of Tolerance called to ask when I could speak again, and the next morning I received an invitation to speak at the Los Angeles Museum Of The Holocaust as often as I was available (see recent story about me in the L.A. Times http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-chocolate-nazis-20130722,0,2450176.story).

But the most rewarding validation came several days later – envelopes stuffed with drawings sent to me by the kids who have heard me tell my Holocaust story and had drawn their versions of it (to see sample drawings click the WEBSITE button below).

Deeply touched by these drawings, I began to take my presentation - which I call  “THE BOY FROM KRAKOW & THE CHOCOLATE TUB” - to schools in the greater Los Angeles area, and, as more and more drawings kept arriving, I thought “There must be a way of not only permanently preserving these wonderful drawings but honoring the students who drew them for their unique contributions to Holocaust history!”

I’m pleased to announce that I’ve found a way to achieve this goal!

It’s called HEAR IT, DRAW IT, REMEMBER IT FOREVER - an interactive program that not only invites students of all races and religions to illustrate my Holocaust experience BUT PRESENTS EACH PARTICIPATING STUDENT WITH A  BOOK THAT INCLUDES HIS OR HER DRAWING - a testament to their connection with the Holocaust for them to treasure and share with others for the rest of their lives!

The challenge: how to subsidize this ambitious project at a time when schools are hard pressed for money?

The answer: get one or more non-profit foundations to make HEAR IT, DRAW IT, REMEMBER IT FOREVER available to all schools that wish to participate.

Here is where you come in.

To get the foundation support needed to make HEAR IT, DRAW IT, REMEMBER IT FOREVER available nation-wide, I’m asking you to help me raise $20,000 to fund a PILOT PROJECT that demonstrates the effectiveness of this unique Holocaust remembrance program.

While I seek foundation sponsorship, your donation will help me visit schools that  sign on to this pilot project, share my “THE BOY FROM KRAKOW & THE CHOCOLATE TUB” presentation with their students, and provide a professionally published book, free of charge, to every student who has done a drawing! - each drawing a priceless testament to a chapter of history that must never be forgotten.

If this innovative way of helping today’s children remember the Holocaust speaks to you, please contribute as much as you can so I can bring the HEAR IT, DRAW IT, REMEMBER IT FOREVER project to as many schools as possible.

If today's children don't remember the Holocaust, who will?

Thank you

Leon Prochnik

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD to family, friends, and your own group mailing list. Please pass on this Indiegogo page to everyone you know through Facebook, Twitter, Google+, LinkedIn, your blog, and, of course, the old-fashioned way – word of mouth!

story:
Background:

I am an artist, lecturer and in 2011, I was awarded a PhD scholarship in Digital Performance by the Cultures of the Digital Economy Research Institute at Anglia Ruskin University, Cambridge, UK. My creative practice research investigates the convergence between science, art, touch and technology through drawing upon my interdisciplinary training in the fields of fine art, performance, audio programming, Chinese Medicine, biomedicine and clinical practice.

Campaign:

My current work Pulse Project (a performance series that uses Chinese pulse reading and audio programming to create sonic portraits of individuals' interior embodied landsacpes) has been receiving increasing interest internationally. Unfortunately, my scholarship doesn't cover travel and accomodation for presenting my research at international conferences. I was really excited recently to be invited to present at a conference at Stanford University in California, but sadly, I had to decline due to lack of funding. Now I have been asked to present at an intensive international conference by Pauline Oliveros's organisation: The Deep Listening Institute and I don't want to have to say no again!

Impact:

 

I have presented at many UK conferences and exhibited my artwork nationally and in Europe. However, presenting my work to an international audience is crucial for the development of my research in terms of connecting to a wider audience, to possible collaborators, to publishers, staging exhibitions, etc. This project reflects the current climate of convergence by bringing together art and science, the ancient and the modern, east and west.

The Deep Listening Institute is an internationally respected organisation that specialises in sonic research. They have invited me to present Pulse Project during the first week of July 2013. This would be an amazing opportunity to connect with other expert artists and academics who would be interested in my unique research and this exposure would certainly open up new avenues for the dissemination of my work (via publication, exhibition, collaboration, etc).

But I need YOU to help me get to there and start the ball rolling or the emerging international interest in my research will grow cold and my research will never reach its true potential!!!!

What the funding will cover:

The majority of the funds will go towards air fare. Current quotes for a round trip economy flight between London and New York on Delta is: £1,335.00 - GBP. The remainder would be spent on hotel stay (on average are £275 for 4 days). Return transportation between Penn Center to Albany runs at £50. The remainder would be spent on other transport costs (i.e., between the airport to Penn Central, between the hotel and the conference center, etc.), food, costs of printing up posters and business cards for desseminating research at this event.

If I don't reach my entire goal, the money will go into a travel fund to present my research internationally. This would profoundly affect my research and its capacity to reach wider audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you could help me by sharing my campaign, which would have a great impact on my research and its reach.

story:
VOTE DIGNITY

Dignity Foundation is a global advocate for our youth and is fundraising $100,000 to sponsor 200 inner city kids at risk to participate in the Creating World Leaders program. We are a charitable organization located in the South Bronx. The 16 week Creating World Leaders journey includes a 3 part series of leadership and personal development training. Upon completion the youth leaders will have applied the tools they have learned by being in service to their community, by creating and completing a tangible community service "World Leaders Project." This 100 day journey is a life changing experience that will challenge and develop our youth into becoming the world leaders of tomorrow in a fast pace world. 

Did You Know:

  • Did you know that each year approximately 1.3 million students fail to graduate from high school?
  • 75% of teen crimes are committed by high school drop outs? 
  • Did you know that 43% of girls from the ages of 15-19 are pregnant in the zip code 10460 in the Bronx?
  • Suicide is the leading cause of death among teens? 
  • That 1 out of 3 kids are bullied and stay home from school? Most of these kids never leave their block.

By empowering these kids in getting off the streets and into a powerful life, they are taking ownership of their life and reclaiming the power of shaping their futures and their communities.  These 200 youth leaders will be the driving force of transformation within their homes and communities. We believe that when people discover their self worth, they will create a circular motion of self-expression and transformation within their community. Support us in sponsoring these 200 future leaders that represent a huge ripple effect of empowerment and self achievement for the South Bronx. 

THE IMPACT

Our Creating World Leaders mission in creating a #REGENERATION consists of a 5 Part Global Campaign: 

  • We are raising $100,000 to sponsor 200 inner city youth at risk in the South Bronx.
  • We are creating a massive global viral campaign for our youth to have a voice. 
  • We are having our first annual youth conference in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic speaking to 1,500 students in October 2013. 
  • We will be visiting Ninos de Cristo Orphanage in La Romana, Dominican Republic speaking to 500 orphans in October 2013.
  • We will be visiting Vivekananda Mission to speak to 10,000 orphans in Kolkata, India in December 2013.

OUR ULTIMATE GOAL IS $250,000 AND THAT WILL LAUNCH DIGNITY UNIVERSAL'S ANNUAL YOUTH PEACE CONFERENCE: CELEBRATE YOUR PURPOSE IN SEPTEMBER 2014 AT YANKEE STADIUM IN THE BRONX!!!!!!


Other Ways You Can Support:

  • THE BEST MARKETING TOOL IS WORD OF MOUTH... so share our youth campaign with your family, friends, co-workers and everyone you come across!!!
  • Join a community of healers, trainers, speakers, yogis, fitness trainers, love activists, come visit the center and share your gifts and talents in our community center. Send your info to info@DignityUniversal.com
  • Refer our Youth to join the Creating World Leaders Journey in November 2013. For more information, please visit: www.DignityUniversal.com 
  • Like our Facebook Page: www.facebook.com/DignityUniversal
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and spread the word!!!


         And that’s all there is to creating a #Regeneration!!!                                                                         

                            Join us in our mission of Creating World Leaders!!! 

                                                                           Dignity Universal: WE ARE ONE.


"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has." -Margaret Mead
