story:
Updates:

  • Northlake Hills Elementary School

The project will start in September at Northlake Hills Elementary School serving children with special needs in Mrs. Fairbanks's classroom (a yearlong project)

  • Family Promise (Homeless children)

The project will start in July serving homeless children in Santa Clarita Valley.

  • Domestic Violence Center of SCV

The project will start on July 15th serving children of Domestic Violence victims. 

  • Boys & Girls Club of SCV

The project will start on June 25th at Boys and Girls Club of SCV serving children ages 7-18 (a yearlong project)

      

    

Million Little is launching a grass roots effort to provide creative arts programs in the community. These programs will be implemented in the Los Angeles area and beyond at non-profit organizations and schools serving children and families that are facing hardships and challenges. The Million Little project will plant seeds of creativity in the community and serve as a ground from which hope, empathy, and transformation can sprout.

The Challenge:

  • There are not enough places for children to express, discover, and explore their curiosity and dreams in order to realize their full potential in life.
  • Due to the budget cuts, many schools have cut arts education.

The Impact:

  • The Million Little project will provide opportunities for children and families to express, empower, and transform their lives through the arts.

 

Fundraising Goals:           

       

The more funds we receive, the more programs we can implement in the community.

The funds will be used to cover fees for professional artists, educators, researchers, transportation, and materials. 

 

     

Who we are:

Ji Ahn founded Million Little in 2010 to provide children and families creative arts programs in which children's interests are nourished and encouraged. Million Little offers consulting services in developing curriculum, creating art sutdio/interactive classrooms, staff training, and implementing creative arts programs for schools and non-profit organizations.

www.MillionLittle.com

 

Project sponsors:

Sierra School:18045-18047 Sierra Hwy. Canyon Country, CA91351/661-252-6422

Canyon Cleaners:18635 Soledad Cyn Rd.#103, Santa Clarita, CA91351/661-298-3927

story:
FUND A RADICAL SOCIAL WORK & ANTI-RACISM DIALOGUE

**Please note: we have moved from a "workshop" to a "facilitated dialogue" framework, which we feel is significant because it captures the organic process we hope to foster rather than a solely didactic educational experience.**


As graduate students of UC Berkeley's School of Social Welfare, we are committed to holding our school community accountable to the value of social justice in our education and field work.

In order to take ownership over our own education and to focus social justice at the forefront of our work, we would like to host an anti-oppression group on campus for first-year MSW students. Our goals for this group are:

  • 1) To develop awareness of oppressive systems (e.g. racism, classism, sexism, ageism, etc.) and our participation in these systems on micro and macro levels, through brave and collaborative dialogue

  • 2) To inspire radical introspection and consciousness-raising that ultimately affect the work we do in our school and professional communities daily

  • 3) To inform our social work education and future practice, so that we may take responsibility for our historical and current roles in perpetuating oppression, identify and challenge oppressive structures, and partner with the communities within which we work

With your contribution, you will enrich the educational experience of future social workers and leaders in the field and, in turn, impact vulnerable communities with which we work throughout our social work careers.


Details

With $500, we will host a dynamic, engaging, challenging, and essential radical social work and anti-racism dialogue for first-year MSW students.

  • $250 will go toward paying a facilitator who is an expert at creating a brave and respectful space for students to discuss sensitive topics of race and racism

  • $200 will pay for food to encourage (hungry) students to attend and sustain their energy throughout the 4-hour training

  • $50 will pay for supplies, perks, and other administrative costs

  • Our STRETCH Goal: $2,000 will allow us to hold bi-monthly meetings to build upon the original dialogue as well as host an additional workshop in the fall semester for incoming MSW students

(Note: If we do not reach our goal, our initial priority will be to pay for facilitation, and we will get creative about feeding ourselves!)


Ways YOU Can Help

If you are in a position to contribute, any amount would be extremely appreciated! Whether you can spare $5, $50, or anything in between, you will help us get closer to our goal!

If you are unable to contribute at this time, that is totally understandable! Please forward our campaign to others and help spread the word.


THANK YOU!

THANK YOU for taking the time to read about our campaign! Like we said, we appreciate any way that you can help. Your support will both enhance social work students' education and the communities they will go on to serve in the future. Thank you for making a difference.



Peace,

Members of the Social Justice Committee
Social Welfare Graduate Assembly
School of Social Welfare
University of California, Berkeley
story_txt:
FUND A RADICAL SOCIAL WORK & ANTI-RACISM DIALOGUE**Please note: we have moved from a "workshop" to a "facilitated 
dialogue" framework, which we feel is significant because it captures the
 organic process we hope to foster rather than a solely didactic 
educational experience.**As graduate students of UC Berkeley's School of Social Welfare, we are committed to holding our school community accountable to the value of social justice in our education and field work.In order to take ownership over our own education and to focus social justice at the forefront of our work, we would like to host an anti-oppression group on campus for first-year MSW students. Our goals for this group are:
1) To develop awareness of oppressive systems (e.g. 
racism, classism, sexism, ageism, etc.) and our participation in these 
systems on micro and macro levels, through brave and collaborative 
dialogue
2) To inspire radical introspection and 
consciousness-raising that ultimately affect the work we do in our 
school and professional communities daily
3) To inform our 
social work education and future practice, so that we may take 
responsibility for our historical and current roles in perpetuating 
oppression, identify and challenge oppressive structures, and partner 
with the communities within which we work
With your contribution, you will enrich the educational experience of future social workers and leaders in the field and, in turn, impact vulnerable communities with which we work throughout our social work careers.DetailsWith $500, we will host a dynamic, engaging, challenging, and essential radical social work and anti-racism dialogue for first-year MSW students.
$250 will go toward paying a facilitator who is an expert at creating a brave and respectful space for students to discuss sensitive topics of race and racism

$200 will pay for food to encourage (hungry) students to attend and sustain their energy throughout the 4-hour training

$50 will pay for supplies, perks, and other administrative costs
Our STRETCH Goal: $2,000 will allow us to hold bi-monthly meetings to build upon the original dialogue as well as host an additional workshop in the fall semester for incoming MSW students

Your support will both enhance social work students' education and the communities they will go on to serve in the future. story:
You Don't Even Know Us.

But You Love Us.


Don't worry if you're unable to contribute to our project due to your financial pressures... A shout-out on your social network will be more than we could ever ask for!

In 2002 a group of dedicated prison staff had a vision to better the community they lived in… the Uganda Prisons Gym was meant to facilitate martial training for the staff, and members of the public. However, due to great financial burdens this dream is slowly withering away, but together we can make sure it doesn't.

Like famous American author Zig Ziglar once said “Remember, what you get by reaching your destination isn't nearly as important as what you become by reaching your goals - what you will become is the winner you were born to be!”

Help us reach this goal, so the disadvantaged can stand a chance to become the winners we all believe they can be.  

What We Need

Our goal is to expand this family of aspiring individuals from 30 to... well we are hoping infinity! Wow! 

Sounds exciting right? Well it is!

But we need your help to raise 5,500$ for a secondhand boxing ring and training equipment aimed at benefiting the aging public facility located within the Luzira Prison Services compound.

Through sports the disadvantaged youth of Uganda (and not only in Uganda) are equipped with life skills like; team work, discipline, respect and maximization of their full potential, values they would otherwise not had an opportunity to learn. 

So with your contribution we intend to build a gym that will not only benefit the current 30 members but also give room for many more to join this family.

Give every and anything you can, tell your friends, family, workmates, classmates too, even that handsome or beautiful stranger you meet in the mall or on your walk about the wonder their contribution could make in the life of a disadvantaged youth.

For USD 5,500:

  • We intend to spend .... on a used (secondhand) boxing ring

  • Boxing gloves

  • Used Shoes & Secondhand Training Kits

  • Renovation, aimed at not only making the gym safer for its users but also stand the test of time. So we need:

  • Jerry-cans of Paint

  • Wood for Windows & Doors

    

What You Get

We wanted to dispatch Ugandan t-shirts ("Somebody in Uganda Loves Me!") to every contributor... however, Uganda is a land-locked country, and we were very disappointed to find out that even regular mail would charge us US$38 for each parcel.

We've decided to go the digital way, as you can see from our 'rewards'.  If there's anything special you'd like us to do for you, we'd love to go that extra-mile... 


The Impact

Uganda has the world’s youngest population, with over 78% below 30 years and of these 65% have no jobs. It has been proved that sports (think boxing in this case) teaches respect, ensures good behavior and has saved many lives from choosing wrong paths.

      

Re-building this public gym will not only provide a venue for recreation and possibly career development, it will also support individual youths in pursuing a happier, healthier and more fruitful life.

We have partnered with Take-A-Chance, a small charity based in Uganda, which sponsored the video and is raising funds for similar projects, and Intensity Technologies a digital marketing company in Uganda that has offered to run a free social-media campaign for the period this project will be running on Indiegogo.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our dream, vision and goal. Share this within your networks.
Our hashtag on social media is #MartialArts4All 

Here, copy and share these on your social media accounts:


Help these young inspiring athletes in Uganda get better facilities. #MartialArts4All igg.me/at/martial-arts-ug

I just contributed to this awesome project on #indiegogo, supporting folks in Uganda. Be part of it too. #MartialArts4All igg.me/at/martial-arts-ug

Sports can change lives. Make that happen for these inspiring individuals in Uganda #MartialArts4All igg.me/at/martial-arts-ug

story:
The GLU Legal Fund

The Ghana Leadership Union, Inc was founded by Dr. Kwaku A. Danso (author of Leadership Concepts and the Role of Government in Africa: The Case of Ghana) with Dr. Eric Sekyere (Australia), Kwasi Kissi (Ghana), Okyere Bonna and other friends as a non-partisan forum to empower and strengthen democracy in Ghana through creative analysis and strategic solutions. The GLU forum has a membership of more than 300 mostly Ghanaian Professionals and a few students based in Ghana and around the world. The network is committed to supporting accountable governance in Ghana. The Legal Fund will be used to finance and support legal recourse against unconstitutional government acts and help educate and strengthen institutions for better governance service delivery to the people of Ghana. To request membership, contact dansojfk@gmail.com.

story:
Hello my friends. I am sending this out to a small group of my closet friends. I know that I have asked many of you to support some of my charitable efforts in the past and for your support I am eternally grateful. I truly am. This request is a little bit different. Most of you have been to eat with me at Shinsengumi (Shabu Shabu) in Gardena and many of you have met my friend Yusuke. He is on a student visa from Japan and however an unlikely combination we have become friends over the past four years. When I met Yusuke he could hardly speak a sentence in English but had the courage to say that he knew his english was poor but really wanted to speak it any chance he could to get a better grasp. Unlike most of the people that work at that restaurant who have come over on work visa's Yusuke is on a student visa, goes to school 5 days a week, works 5 days a week at the restaurant, and interns 3 days a week with a photographer. His only mode of transportation is his bicycle which he has been know to ride all the way from Torrance to Hollywood just to see something that interests him. This is a very special person, you will have to trust me on that. He is creative and driven and simply wants something more in life.

Over the years he has asked for my assistance with convincing his family to allow him to stay here to pursue his education, understanding legal documents, even helping him get paid back from a guy who hit him with his car while he was riding his bike. But in all of these years he has never asked me for anything like money. He came to me in tears last week because his father has decided to no longer cover the cost of his tuition which is $3700 a semester at El Camino College. He has saved $1000 so far. He only has 2 semesters left and has paid successfully for the past 3 years and has a plan to pay his tuition for future semesters but unfortunately was caught out at the last minute by his father and needs to pay his tuition by this Friday January 31st. He has come up with a repayment schedule but I think it will strap him so badly that he will not be eating for  the 6 months if he does it. I mentioned that I might be able to get a group of people together to donate the money and he said "no, I must be able to pay this money back"

So my thoughts on this are the following. I would like to have some of my friends chip in $100 each with no expectation of repayment. Just a simple pay it forward contribution to someone's future. I know that Yusuke will want to pay the money back and maybe we can do that when the time is right and in a way that may pay it forward to another person in need. I have never considered Yusuke a charity case. He is far from it. Just a person like any of us that is in a tight spot and could really use some help. He has no one in the US that he can ask for help so I would like to help him. If you feel like contributing it would be money well spent. I thank you in advance. Love you all.

story:
About Camp Notyamom

My name is Kristin Rolla and I am a senior film major at Webster University. This film, Camp Notyamom, will be my final project at Webster and I want to make it count. Camp Notyamom is a comedy based on true events about the life of head camp counselor Zoe. While Zoe tries to impress the camp inspector that has come in to evaluate the camp, things take a turn for the worst when the famous tortellini dinner is ruined by newbie counselors. Now it is up to Zoe to fix the tortellini dinner and prevent Camp Notyamom from going under.

What You Get

Perks! Who doesn't like perks!? On our way to reach our goal of $1,200, you can get a variety of perks including a DVD copy, t-shirts, and a chance to be in the film!

Since most of us are poor college students, any contribution or donation will help tremendously and will be put to use. With the money you donate, we will be able to provide meals for the crew and talent, rent necessary equipment needed to make the film, provide gas money and services, and will also go towards making custom Camp Notyamom t-shirts for the cast.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, no worries! Just sharing the link and getting the word out is help enough!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Boom, we nailed our goal! 

Help us stretch a bit further!

Thanks to everyone who helped us reach our goal of raising $10,000!!!  We did this very quickly, around the 1/2 way point of the campaign.  We'd like to take it a step further now, and double our goal over the 2nd half of the campaign, effectively upgrading our operational armor from Leather to Chainmail!

This initial goal feels a lot like getting a nice piece of leather armor--it's way better than having nothing, but it's not like having chain mail!  If we can stretch and reach $20,000 in the next two weeks we're looking at being able to get some administrative support to free up the core staff of Buddhist Geeks for additional improvements to Buddhist Geeks programming.  It also gives us a solid buffer to be able to operate with a bit more confidence during times of great change.  We literally would not be doing this work if it weren't for your support, generosity, and interest.  Thank you for making this possible!

Who Are We?

For the past several years we been exploring the question, or koan, “How can we serve the convergence of Buddhism with rapidly evolving technology and an increasingly global culture?”

Buddhist Geeks provides space for this ever deepening conversation. We aim to bring together perspectives from across the world, from across various fields of study, and of course from Buddhism. This year we will focus on a four day conference, a wide range of video conversations, and a member driven community of dedicated contemplatives hosting conversations at the intersection of Buddhism, technology and emerging global culture.



What Do We Want to Continue?

In 2014, we'll continue to convene a variety of conversations taking place at the intersection of Buddhism and contemporary life. These conversations, whether held at the Buddhist Geeks conference, through podcast interviews, retreats, or in peer-led community video hangouts--have augmented the Buddhist tradition and have supported the evolution of 21st century spirituality. We aim to continue to innovate and explore topics that may or may not be typically held in public space.


What are some examples of Buddhist Geeks conversations?

  • Getting a Handle on Scandal - Diane Hamilton, Kenneth Folk, Sofia Diaz, Shinzen Young and Michael Zimmerman
  • Enlightenment Engineering - Mikey Siegal
  • Present Shock - Douglas Rushkof
  • Feminine Practice and Gender Roles - Sofia Diaz and Trudy Goodman
  • The Emerging Science of Mindfulness Meditation - David Vago
  • Mindful Media: A New Culture of Immersiveness on the Internet - Megan Miller


Where your coin goes

The money you contribute allows Buddhist Geeks to continue to offer the Podcast, Community, and Conference. Specifically, your money goes to Buddhist Geeks core team of 3 people, conference speakers, as well as the associated costs of design, legal, accounting, hosting fees and all the other little and big costs that go into running a growing organization. We bring in a modest amount of money from community memberships and conference ticket sales--and yet we depend on raising money from our network of listeners.


What do we need?

In order to continue operating we need at least $10,000 for 2014. By contributing to this crowdfunder you will help offset the costs of both the conference and the community. Your support will allow us to keep the conversation alive and continue to make a difference in the world.


The Perks



What are people saying?

Community Members

"It feels to me like we are creating some model of group practice. The whole question of ‘how do I hold my identity lightly’ and ‘how do I recognize the three characteristics in a community setting’ and let things come together and fall apart and come together in new ways. I feel that this is the heart of individual practice in many ways. To see this on a community level really supports my practice. It feels like a new exploration." - Emma Roy
"We have a safe place here. People can lay out their practices and say this is what I do, this is how I benefited from it. People feel safe to do that here." -Laurel Carrington
"For me there’s something sacred about this community. I have a sort of respect for it. I’m very selective about what to present, out of respect. I know that anytime I’ve been open and vulnerable here it’s been met with respect also. I can’t possibly express how beneficial this has been to my practice, this community." -Duane Miller

The Conference

"The inaugural conference had incredible energy: the energy of potent potential. It's like being a kid: your whole life is still ahead of you." 
"After spending over 35 years in the business world and often attending various conferences, I'd say the Buddhist Geeks Conference was once of best I've ever attended as far as flow, organization, welcoming feeling, motivation, etc." 
"Stunned, floored, amazed by how wonderful it was especially for a first-time event." 

The Media

story:
Help Sponsor a student to finish their education!

  • Working in at university we have seen too many successful, bright students that are unable to afford the cost of education and inevitably they have to withdraw from school.
  • Some are able to work and come back and finish their degree while others never do.
  • Our hope is to (eventually) start a foundation to help students that can't quite pay for their tuition and may not qualify for scholarships or financial aid.
  • We believe that education is the key to not only individual success but also as a commitment and investment in our future!

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need your help and every dollar matters.
  • While we are starting this because one of our incredibly positive and impactful student leaders is facing financial restrictions to allow him to complete his education and graduate.  He is bright, intelligent, caring and has made a huge impact on his campus and we know he will make a difference in the world as well.
  • Whatever funds are raised will go directly to the student. If there is more than he needs then the plan is to use it to start the Starfish Foundation and hopefully help even more students to reach graduation!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:

  • Help spread the word to others you know!
story_txt:
Help Sponsor a student to finish their education!
Working in at university we have seen too many successful, bright students that are unable to afford the cost of education and inevitably they have to withdraw from school.
Some are able to work and come back and finish their degree while others never do.
Our hope is to (eventually) start a foundation to help students that can't quite pay for their tuition and may not qualify for scholarships or financial aid.
We believe that education is the key to not only individual success but also as a commitment and investment in our future!
What We Need & What You GetBreak it down for folks in more detail:
We need your help and every dollar matters.
While we are starting this because one of our incredibly positive and impactful student leaders is facing financial restrictions to allow him to complete his education and graduate.  He is bright, intelligent, caring and has made a huge impact on his campus and we know he will make a difference in the world as well.
Whatever funds are raised will go directly to the student. If there is more than he needs then the plan is to use it to start the Starfish Foundation and hopefully help even more students to reach graduation!

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:Help spread the word to others you know!

story:
Hate Crimes and Creative Response

Tires slashed. Dog feces. Hateful graffiti.
Houses in a Toronto neighbourhood have been the target of homophobic vandalism because they are flying rainbow flags outside.
So what are these amazing LGBTQ community members and allies going to do?
Are they going to take down their flags and hope the hate ends?
No - instead they are going to host a BBQ and give out 200 rainbow flags to their neighbours so they can be united and stand together in their belief that homophobia and transphobia isn't one of their community values.
More info HERE at CBC
and HERE on CityNews
and HERE at Xtra

How you can help...

These amazing folks have already ordered 100 rainbow flags and they are planning to feed everyone at the BBQ. Let's all pitch in so that this small group doesn't have to pay out of their own pocket to make our city more loving, more united and more colourful.

It costs about $5 per flag, including shipping.

Other stuff

If we exceed the goal of $500, then the extra money will first go towards paying for costs related to the BBQ and to fix the damage done by the vandals. Any extra funds will go to other groups who address homophobia and transphobia in our communities.

If you want to come to the BBQ, let us know and we'll send you an invite when the details have been worked out.

Note: This campaign is being run through the Glad Day Bookshop account but 100% of all the funds raised will go to these community organizers. Glad Day Bookshop is the world's oldest LGBTQ bookstore and we've been at the forefront of queer liberation, free speech and expanding love for 43 years.
www.gladdaybookshop.com

story:
Lambeth Valentine Youth Walk

Support The Walk

Young People Matter Charity is hosting the 1st ‘Lambeth Valentine Youth Walk’. Our aim is to raise £5,900 to take 30 inner city youth on their first meaningful experience of the great outdoors… Hindleap Warren Outdoor Education Centre. They will enjoy a residential adventure of archery, canoeing, wall climbing, high ropes, zip-wires, abseiling, obstacle courses, team challenges +more set in 300 acres of woodland!


Outdoor education creates opportunities for personal and social development that are second to none. It challenges young people, encouraging and enabling them to reach out beyond that which is familiar and comfortable. The sense of adventure it instills and the team-work it inspires, help young people come together, win new confidence and gain invaluable education for life. 

Here are 4 differences your contribution will mean:

  1. The monotonous confines of an all too familiar concrete jungle vs the thrilling freedom of 300 acres of woodland. 
  2. The smog and congestion of the Nation's capital vs the fresh air of the Ashdown Forest.
  3. A 3-day residential adventure vs just another 48 hours (no Eddie Murphy jokes).
  4. A potentially life changing opportunity to go from 'at risk' to 'at peace' whilst having fun, fun.. earth climbing fun!

What We Need & What You Get

  • A 3-day residential experience at Hindleap costs £182 p/p
  • A return seat on a coach costs 13.50 p/p
  • Buy a unique Music Icon perk NOW! Michael Jackson, Jessie J, Tupac +more
  • 100% of the funds raised goes towards safe & enjoyable opportunities for our youth

About Us

Young People Matter is the Business mind, Social heart, Community focus, Youth led, award-winning charity/ social enterprise based in the heart of South London. We deliver a multitude of life changing programmes. These include our intergenerational Seniors & Youth "Keep Calm & Drink Tea" events, our "Us LOT" peer mentoring in schools programme and our "101 Community Challenge". CLICK FOR PAST EVENTS

Here Are Other Ways You Can Help

Join us on the 4.5k walk from Stockwell to Balham! Be amongst the next generation of leaders by taking that first step towards a better tomorrow alongside them.

  • Ask friends and family to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and follow YPMCharity in cyberspace: 

twitter.com/YPMCharity facebook.com/YPMCharity instagram.com/YPMCharity

story:
Funds from Indiegogo will be used to:

  • Create a packaged curriculum and the opportunity for expansion to other schools

  • Develop a CD to be used by teachers, students and parents

  • Write and publish a curriculum handbook

  • Create a online video support channel for teachers

Green Light's Goal is to hear children say "YES" to these statements:

  • " I can make up my own songs"

  • " When I hear music I feel like I know how to be a part of it"

  • " I can read music notation"

  • " I want to play music every day and learn an instrument"

  • " Being involved in music makes me feel good"

Green Light's Goal is to hear classroom teachers say "YES" to these statements:

  • "Learning to teach music in my class has given me renewed confidence and energy"

  • " Music helps my students learn better"

  • " Music improves the overall atmosphere of my classroom"

How does it work?

  • Teacher Training:  Monthly Seminars provide classroom teachers with simple exercises and games, like teaching ABC's but with musical sounds and symbols.

  • Innovation and Cooperation:  Children create their own rhythm with classmates from the start.

  • Repetition:  Using simple phrases with different words and sounds deepens the students' experience and ability.

  • Foundation:  Strengthening basic musical building blocks assures future success.

This is a creative teaching modality that will:

  • Excite and harmonize the classroom

  • Bring calm and enjoyment to teachers and students

  • Give teachers a quick, straightforward and practical way to enter the world of music

What is the outcome?

  • Children receive all the benefits of musical training http://www.pbs.org/parents/education/music-arts/the-benefits-of-music-education/

  • Skills learned will greatly enhance later instrument study

  • Parents will become motivated by their kids' success

  • Provides a new way to learn spelling, times tables and memorization using rhythm

We have a K-3rd grade pilot program kicking off this fall at Woodland Star Charter School in Sonoma, CA.

story:
Us

In Panama we take debate really serious. Every school has a budget that the school gives them. Our school helps us through other ways, but is not enough.

We want to demonstrate that a small school can make a huge event, even though we are new. Also, to show people and other schools what we are capable to do when you have passion and when you care.

We know that everyone have its doubts, but we know we are going to do our best.

What we need from you

Let’s be honest a forum, with ever preparation, costs lots of money. We have money, yet we need more. Sponsors don’t believe in what we are capable of. They barely know what a Debate Club is about. We know, and we want you to know how much this means to us.

If you have any question, please don’t hesitate to ask me.

Help!

Your help is really important for us, our mates, the one who believe in us, and those who want a forum.

In the past, we’ve attended to lots of forum, they weren’t as good as we expect ours to be. We have participated in other international debates, such as: HACIA Democracy (Harvard Association Cultivating Inter-American Democracy) and NHI (National Hispanic Institute).

Participating in much of the forums that are in America, had given us enough experience to organize a forum.

No money? No worries…

If you have any money, then you can still help us. How? Tell other people of our forum. Share it. Talk about it with your friends. Make them know about us.

story:
About me and what I am about:

 Aloha!

I am one body, mind and spirit; suited with two feet, a cultivated open mind, and an ever building community with the world at my fingertips. I have repeatedly been told that I have a natural ability and enthusiasm that draws people together. I have also been told that I am courageous and inspiring. Without pride, I find that these strengths can be cultivated negatively or positively. I am only interested in what will truly fulfill Life ( with a capital “L”). And oh, I love the wonder that avails us as we intentionally cultivate those conditions which inspire a sustainable environment for just that.I have embraced my passion by cultivating deep listening, active and ongoing development while building a strong community who supports that goal. I have found the more I embrace the simplicities of life and all its wondrous opportunities the richer Life becomes.

Since I graduated from high school 6 years ago from Summerfield Waldorf, I have been looking for what is most fitting in my academic path. I was very fortunate and intentional about traveling abroad to learn as much as possible about different cultures. I have attended community college, “WWOOF”ed http://www.wwoofinternational.org/ in Hawaii and Oregon, by working on organic farms, gardens and at farmers markets by selling ayurvedic raw foods to our local community.

This spring I learned about the Weaving Earth Immersion Program in Sonoma County. While investigating the program and interviewing graduates, I heard my calling. I feel a deep connection to what the program offers and can provide. Being accepted a month ago has opened a new doorway to a greater sense of purpose and confirmed that my search and intentional trust of Life led me to appreciate who, what and how it all brought me to this destination. Hooray!!!

With your help I will be able to meet the mark for the expense of the program and the supplies I will need to finish out the three years. I will be forever grateful for your consideration and support.


About Weaving Earth:

Weaving Earth Immersion Program core curriculum covers these areas

"Recognizing our interdependency with all life, the WE Immersion seeks to cultivate leaders, stewards and pioneers for a socially just, ecologically harmonious and consciously awakened future. Discover and explore the possibilities that arise when we unite in an intentional, mentoring context:

Deep Connection with the Natural World

Design Skills for Earth Stewardship and Community Resiliency

Personal Development, Leadership and Vitality

Community Competency

Perhaps more than any other skill within the program, the WE Immersion flexes the muscle of connection. As connections strengthen, they form bridges of relationship—fostering stewardship, creativity and transformation.

Participants learn to bridge between the ancient and the modern, between themselves and the natural world, and between the instabilities of today and the possibilities of a regenerative future."

Please visit their website and find out about more wonderful opportunities.-www.weavingearth.com/programs/we-immersion


What I need and am asking for:

My fundraising goal of $9600 includes the following breakdown:

  • To cover the cost of the program at $8050

  • The additional funds are to cover the following:

    • $750 - Incentives! In order to provide a farm to fork meal I will be contacting local farms to see if they would donate towards this meal for a small group. If they are only able to reduce the cost for me. A little from my funding will go towards ensuring that the food we use will be only from Sonoma County.

    • $800 - approx 4%-11% indigogo expenses

Any funds that I make above my initial goal will go towards my second year tution, or to a training next summer that will enhance my learning in this field of study.

If I don't reach my entire goal all that is funded will still go directly towards my tuition for the program.


What You Get in Return:

I have come up with many perks that will keep you involved, raise your spirits, and reflect my deep gratitude for your support and contribution. (See below)

My blog can be found at - www.PagesToFill.wordpress.com,. I will be posting links to updates on Facebook and please subscribe to my blog directly.


The Impact:

In my life so far I have learned that personal development and education is not a consumer product but rather what you make of it. I believe that this program offers me an invaluable jumpstart by providing a forum for learning, building community, and inspiring ongoing growth.

My dream is to be apart of developing an ”ecovillage” where shared living can be accomplished with intentional sustainability. I also wish to use this facility as a place to offer solace and tranquility, learning, programs and workshops,

With your generous support I will be able to access what I believe is an invaluable education. I intend and promise to use this time to educate myself and cultivate being a valuable partner with others in the ongoing stewardship of sustainability.


Other ways you can help:

I understand that not everyone can contribute money, but if you could take the time to spread my campaign to friends and families. I am a firm believer that every penny counts. With your word of mouth I can reach my goal.

If you would like to donate other services or goods as well that I can add to my incentives as surprises I would gratefully accept!

Please contact me directly with any questions you might have.

With deep gratitude and optimism, I humbly thank you,

 

Morgan Campbell

story:
Information

According to cancer.org, 577,190 Americans died from cancer in 2012. That’s more than 1,500 people a day. Many of those who have passed away left small children behind. The fact that cancer affects more than just those who are diagnosed is often overlooked. Keisha Brown, the founder of the Angel Wings Fund, said this, “There are many men and women who are affected by cancer. There are many men and women doing research to find a cure. But what about the children, those who are not diagnosed with cancer, but lose a parent because of it?”

Keisha was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2007. Her biggest fear after hearing the diagnosis was what was going to happen to her, then 1-year-old daughter, Angel. This is what led Keisha and her husband, Damon, to later create the Angel Wings Fund, named after their daughter.

The Angel Wings Fund is designed to help children whose parent has passed away due to cancer in the form of a college scholarship. It is also hoped that this will alleviate the burden placed on the surviving parent. Another mission of the Angel Wings Fund is to bring cancer education events to schools, making children aware of the many types of cancer at an early age. The events can range from health fairs to motivational speakers.


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise 500.00.  In response to this problem our group has devised a fundraising event that not only will raise funds for Angel Wings, but also spreads awareness about all types of cancer. Through the “Knock Cancer Out of the Park” Homerun Derby, participants will be able to take their best swings at hitting as many homerun as they possibly can in a minute. The catch behind the homerun derby is that similar to the MLB homerun derby, the balls preceding the 10th and final out in our derby will also be painted. However, unlike the MLB homerun derby our softballs will be painted purple and have the Angel Wings logo on them not only to symbolize breast cancer but also all other forms of cancer. Then depending on however many of these “Cancer Awareness,” are hit out of the park local business will donate a certain amount of money back to Angel Wings general scholarship fund. Therefore, the more homeruns hit the better.

In addition to Homerun Derby are group will also be selling event T-shirts, silicone event bracelets, and sponsorship banners that will be displayed during the derby. Our goal behind this project is to bring Central Michigan University, Central Michigan Athletics, and the Mount Pleasant community together to help support this one great cause. 

Indiegogo users will have the opportunity to receive a free pink silicone bracelet with a donation of 20 dollars and a purple commemorative softball with a 100 dollar donation or more.

Goals and Objectives

  • Raise money for the Angel Wings Fund through participation, donations, and Indiegogo. 
  • Spread awareness of all forms of cancer
  • Provide participants and attendees with an event that fun, educational, and memorable event
  • Bring Indiegogo users, Mount Pleasant community, Central Michigan University, and Central Michigan Athletics together for the Angel Wings Cause

story:
IN a WORD

Headquartered in California, Athgo is a nonprofit that will bring 200 students and underserved youth from around 50 countries to the World Bank hq in Washington DC on May 22-24, 2013 to help them build 25 socially and environmentally impactful startup businesses. - ALL of YOUR Contributions in the US can be Tax Deductable. 

Who We Are

We are a small NGO with an exemplary track record in guiding and advancing youth through building startup business for themselves and their communities. It all started with the story of Athgo's founder, Armen Orujyan, PhD.

"I was once myself young and underserved. I experienced many challenges growing up: from severe shortages of means and resources, to being type-casted because of my background and left out of social circles and networks, to encountering major problems landing jobs, and to being forced to choose work over school. I was able to overcome those challenges through costly trial and error and by fortune of having compassionate people walk into my life at right times encouraging and mentoring me to build a future that aligned with my strengths and true desires. From those experiences, I knew firsthand that with a slight push, direction, and a compelling story, anyone, especially youth, can realize their potential.

I founded Athgo when I was 24 as a stage for young and underserved people pursuing innovation and entrepreneurship but lacking direction, access, or means. We started with a pilot program at UCLA with 20 low-income students from six local community colleges. Success was instant and we moved forward. In the past decade, we have provided intellectual, financial, and networking opportunities to over 5,000 young innovative entrepreneurs and students from over 600 universities in nearly 80 countries through our Global Innovation Forums at the United Nations and the World Bank headquarters. Now, Athgo is a global entrepreneurial platform in consultative statuses with the UN Economic and Social Council and the UN Department of Public Information." 

Photo 2005: Athgo Global Innovation Forum at the United Nations headquarters. Over 300 students and innovative youth from 40 countries at the UN Economic and Social Council Chambers.

Photos 2006: Athgo Global Innovation Forum at the United Nations headquarters. Over 400 students and youth from 70 countries are working in their teams developing  innovative and entrepreneurial solutions.

Photos 2007: Athgo Global Innovation Forum at the United Nations headquarters. An expert panel (left) followed by a youth panel presenting the solution to the experts and rest of the forum (right).

Photo 2008: Athgo Global Innovation Forum in Yerevan, Armenia. Over students and young entrepreneurs from 22 countries are on a sightseeing trip.

We are inspired by the capabilities, creativity, and fervor of young people, especially those with minimal resources; those who impact their communities; and those who reach great heights through dedication and drive. Stories, such as of Amal Kabalan, Athgo 2011 alum from Lebanon continue to inspire us and fuel our mission: 

"The Athgo Forum gave me the tools of putting a technical project in a business context. As an engineer I was only concerned about the technical aspect of a product design, however, working to put a project on a market made me realize how social, economic, and environmental factors play a role in making a successful project. In addition, the Forum put me in touch with very smart people that I am still working with till now. As a team, we currently have a prototype of a solar backpack that we thought of at the program. Several options were tried since and now we finalized the product design. Our product can power cell phones or an LED light. It has a power output of 1.6 W at full sunlight generating over 5 hours of energy source for students without power supply."

 

What We are Doing

In Washington D.C. from May 22-May 24, Athgo’s 5th Global Innovation Forum at the World Bank’s headquarters titled “ICT Powering Constructive Entrepreneurs”, will present intellectual, networking, and financial opportunities to over 200 promising young entrepreneurs and students, including those from underserved communities in nearly 50 countries. The industry leading knowledge framework, the 4-Pillars to Success, designed by Athgo founder will power this year’s program, providing a unique opportunity for the youth to transform entrepreneurial ideas into reality, capitalizing on their brilliant capabilities to create value-producing start-ups.

Young and innovative students and entrepreneurs from over 41 countries have already been confirmed to attend along with 25 youth interns who will be given an opportunity to facilitate and administer the Forum. We have the support of the President of the Republic of Rwanda, Mr. Paul Kagame—an inspirational leader who knows the importance and value of young people in rebuilding his country after the Rwandan Genocide. We are fortunate to have the President, along with other top leaders, experts, and executives including those from Boeing, Chrysler, Intel, Daimler, Alcatel-Lucent, the World Bank, the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), and the Broadband Commission for Digital Divide, join Athgo’s Forum to help guide the young delegates on their trek of building 25 new constructive start-up concepts. 

Photos: Athgo World Bank Innovation Forums: Nobel Peace Laureate Professor Muhammad Yunus with one of Athgo's winning entrepreneurial teams (left). US Congesswoman Linda Sanchez Presenting to Athgo Youth (right).

 

The participating young delegates will go through an interactive process of:

  1. Learning about where entrepreneurial ideas take root
  2. Joining a team of talented peers from around the world to form entrepreneurial ideas
  3. Establishing how best to turn ideas into commercially viable business
  4. Turning an idea into a start-up with the guidance of expert advisors
  5. Qualifying for Innovation Grants
  6. Building friendships and personable relationships with executives, high-level officials, and successful entrepreneurs
  7. Moving forward with an actual start-up and their own team

A student from Boston, one of over 100 youth who are already selected and confirmed, eloquently characterized the Forum as “an opportunity to stimulate my development as a person, my understanding of the world, help me identify my specific skills and strength..., and enhance my leadership and business skills, allowing me to move on with that new knowledge and make an impact in the society.” On the other side of the globe, a young entrepreneur from Burundi noted that “as a young woman, I see it as an opportunity not to miss, an opportunity to learn from others' experiences, share mine, and collectively build a dream.”

How Will the Funds be Spent - All of your contributions are Tax Deductable.

The contributions that we raise with your sponsorships and efforts will be used for supporting:

  • Subsidized participation for 35 youth - $5,000. Will cover nearly 60% of each young delegate’s registration costs

 

Photos: Athgo Global Innovation Forums at the World Bank headquarters. Youth participants from 2011 (top left), 2009 (top right), and 2008 (above center).

  • $6K Innovation grants for the  top 3 entrepreneurial teams
    • 3rd place Innovative Grant – $1,000
    • 2nd place Entrepreneur Grant – $2,000
    • 1st place Presidential Grant – $3,000

 

 

 

 

 

 

Photos 2011: Athgo Global Innovation Forum at the World Bank headquarters. One of the winning teams with our Keynote Speaker, Nobel Peace Laureate Muhammad Yunus and Athgo Founder (left). Another youth entrepreneurial team is presenting their startup concept to the Forum (right).

  • Subsidized participation for 5 interns – $3,500. Will cover travel, accommodations, transportation, and meals

 

 

 

 

 

 

Photos: Athgo Interns at the World Bank headquarters 2009 (left) and at the United Nations headquarters 2007 (right)

We have a list of unique rewards for our friends and patrons (read further for more details). Let’s power young constructive entrepreneurs together!

What Will be Considered as Success

Success will mean 25 new startup concepts developed and fully owned by the 200 participating young entrepreneurs and students. Additionally, they participating youth will come away with expanded networks, entrepreneurial teams, and importantly with deep understanding on how to structure and build startup businesses, work in teams, and maximize their and teams’ resources, however limited they may appear.  Our Global Innovation Forums have made lasting impacts on the youth participants who have attended. Let us meet some of them and see what they have to say about experience:

Amal Kabalan (Lebanon and United States)

My Athgo programs:

  • 2011 World Bank HQ, Washington DC

Then:

2nd year PhD Student, Electrical Engineering at Villanova University

Now:

Entrepreneur, Co-founder, SolarBright

Adjunct Instructor, Rowan University


My Athgo experience: (above)

 

Iva Iordanova (Bulgaria)

My Athgo programs:

  • 2007: United Nations HQ, New York City
  • 2008: United Nations HQ, New York City

Then:

Student, Management and Leadership, Berkeley College, New York 

Now:

Social Media and Digital Outreach Strategist at Political Party campaign of a former European Commissioner Meglena Kuneva

My Athgo Experience: Athgo is truly the starting point of my professional career. It is the organization that empowered me with the basic skills, initial knowledge and deep belief in the fact that every young person has a unique mission only s/he can achieve. Athgo’s forums provoked my interest to learn more about the Millennium Development Goals and led me to establish a student organization that promotes these ideals. That, in turn, helped me network with hundreds of like-minded individuals across the globe and map out projects and initiatives to explore and secure sustainable development. When I first attended Athgo’s events, I was still a senior in college and upon graduation I was curious to realize that one of the most impressing assets on my resume when I interviewed for jobs, was precisely my involvement with the organization. Since then, I have been able to use much of the skills I acquired thanks to Athgo’s training, as well as the priceless guidance and mentorship of the organization's chairman, Armen Orujyan, and thus find myself in a position where I can genuinely feel I can make a positive impact on my society and the world at large.

 

Nicole Andrea Rapista (United States)

My Athgo programs:

  • 2011: World Bank HQ, Washington DC

Then:

Student, Georgetown University 


Now:

Director of Social Innovation, The International Youth Council


My Athgo experience:

Before Athgo, I was not sure of what I wanted to study in college and what I wanted to do afterwards. After the Athgo forum in 2011, I developed a more comprehensive understanding of sustainable development and how entrepreneurship can be a means to further international development while creating green jobs. Athgo helped cultivate a passion for social entrepreneurship and international affairs. Since then, I have worked at Ashoka to help bring innovation and social entrepreneurship to higher-education. This led me to become the Director of Social Innovation at the International Youth Council. It is a global coalition of over 5,000 young leaders across 30 countries committed to sustainable development.

Isha Kasule (Uganda)

My Athgo programs:

  • 2008: World Bank HQ, Washington DC
  • 2008: Yerevan, Armenia

Then:

Study Abroad, Kansai Gaidai University, Osaka Japan 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Now:

Principal at Moeish Consult Limited


My Athgo experience:

Athgo helped me look at businesses and ideas in a more global perspective where I learned to leverage on resources around the world to get work done. The Innovation Forums also provided fantastic opportunities to Network with amazing minds whom up-to-date I am in touch with and who have assisted me in both business and social aspects of life. The Athgo programs also inspired me towards Entrepreneurship and gave me the foundational information on how to go about setting up my own business. I am currently running my Own Company called Moeish Consult Limited that focuses on Market Entry and Business Development Consulting plus fundraising for projects and companies in Africa. And last, the Athgo CEO, Dr. Armen Orujyan is also an inspiration to me and I am happy at the fact that to date, he still has the time to respond to an email or assist with queries I have.

 

You can check out more of testimonials on our website

 

Who else besides the Youth will join the Program

Among the 2013 Forum’s confirmed distinguished speakers, experts, and advisors are:

  • H.E. Mr. Paul Kagame, the President of the Republic of Rwanda, President Kagame is an inspirational leader who helped end the Rwandan Genocide in early 1990s and since has been the anchor of the country and in its social and economic growth through focus on technology and entrepreneurship.
  • H.E. Dr. Hamadoun Toure, the Secretary General of the ITU, a specialized agency of the United Nations dedicaed to information and communication technologies.
  • Dr. Armen Orujyan, the Founder of Athgo Corporation and Commissioner, Broadband Commission for Digital Development.
  • Ms. Naila Chowdhury, Founder/Chairperson, Women4empowerment
  • Mr. Jed Cohen, Founder and COO, RocketHub.com
  • Ms. Masiela Lusha, Author, Actress, Producer, and Humanitarian, Athgo Ambassador for Youth
  • Ms. Eidola Pashollari, Secretary General, World Assembly of Youth
  • Mr. Enrico Pisino, Head of Innovation, Chrysler Group LLC
  • Ms. Angelica Silvero, Head of the Speakers Bureau; the World Bank External Affairs
  • Mr. Aaron Sherinian, Vice President of Communications and Public Relations, UN Foundation
  • Mr. Chris Thomas, Chief Strategist, World Ahead Director of Architecture, Intel
  • Mr. Aleem Walji, Director of Innovation Labs, the World Bank
  • Mr. Jeff Werner, General Manager, International and Public Policy, Daimler

 Please visit our website for the full list

Photo 2008: Athgo Global Innovation Forum in Yerevan, Armenia. The Prime Minister of Armenia, H.E. Mr Tigran Sargsyan (2nd from right) and the Minister of Economy of Armenia, H.E. Mr Nerses Yeritsyan (right) are on a Panel with Athgo Founder (2nd from left) and the program MC, Johan Khairuddin, moderated by Mr. Sarbuland Khan (at the podium), the Executive Director of the United Nations Global Alliance for ICT and Development.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the campaign through your Social Media channels and you will be acknowledged as an Athgo DC Forum Spokesperson on all Athgo Social Media channels and on exclusive digital banner at the World Bank hq during the duration of the Forum. Use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Who?

The Yard, meaning “the quad or general outdoor gathering place on a college campus.”Our purpose is to create a mobile iPhone app to impact the campus environment and life in a positive way by reducing paper flyer waste and increasing the effectiveness of college event promotion. Everyone has a smartphone, and the information on flyers could be supplied digitally. The only reason this hasn’t happened is because a universal app hasn’t been established which everyone participates in that allows for a simple, high quality, and fair delivery platform. The Yard Event Stream is such an app.

This mobile app is being created for all Student Organizations, Colleges, and Students to create, promote, discover, and filter campus events. Alumni and High School students looking to connect with their future and past college events will also find ample use for theYard Event Stream App.

Did you know...There are 5,000 institutions of higher learning within the US. Many of these institutions foster anywhere from ten to hundreds of Student Organizations for any and interest you may have. Events happen everyday whether you know about it or not. The purpose of theYard is to give these events more visibility and opportunity to be successful. Cultural, Academic, Professional, Athletic, Greek, Service, Political, Religious, Arts, and other Special Interest Organizations are formed by students every year. These Organizations have multiple events throughout the semester targeting the student body, the surrounding community, and of course visiting students are always welcome.

Founder

Hello! My name is Brian and I am an engineer, entrepreneur, and exciting person! I was inspired to build an app that promotes college events to students no matter their institution, interests, or social connections! I am partnering with various student organizations to ensure that this app will deliver an effective voice and platform to promote every campus event. 

What?

Raising funds for design, testing, and development of "theYard Event Stream App" iOS version only.  

When?

Now. The app is already designed. Once the capital is available, the process of development and testing will begin. The target app launch date is August 2014.

Where?

There are no restrictions on the locations for this app. Colleges and Student Organizations will be approved to promote their events from day one no matter their location or enrollment.

Why?

1. Reduce Paper "Flyer" Waste

"If you hand out flyers they usually will end up unread or in the trash." 

Walking around campus I see a ton of flyers, posters, and other forms of traditional advertising (many of which are old) laying around polluting the walkways and bathrooms. I did my research and I found that most student organizations have difficulty promoting events to a large number of students effectively. This form of promotion is not efficient in this day and age of digital advertising. The benefits are outweighed by its lack of environmental sustainability because flyers have a higher financial and environmental footprint. The worst part about all this is that to be so ineffective (10% of flyers are used ineffectively), flyers cause literally tons of waste on campus.

2. Target Promoting for College Events

"I usually send hundreds of invites to my Facebook friends and Twitter followers."

- student organization member

Sure there is Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and the like but the point of having events is to expand and reach new people. There is still no app where you can promote events easily to those not already in your social circle. 

3. Discovering/Filtering Events

"I have no idea what's going on around campus if my friends don't tell me"

- student 

It's not always easy finding things to do. When you visit other campuses, road trip to another school, go on spring break, just transferred schools, or maybe you are just a freshman new to campus. In these cases what can you easily do to find interesting activities or events on campus? theYard will not only allow you to discover these events but, you will also be able to filter them so that you can get to the ones you will actually participate in!

4. Better Event Features

Sure posting events is great but theYard Event Stream App will strive to be more useful and insightful. By using our app you will be able to know more about your attendees, make better decisions, and target interested people for your event.

I want not only to build an app, I want to build a movement. Whether you know it or not, traditional college life is becoming less and less sustainable both financially and environmentally. Online courses and online degrees are becoming more and more common. Don't misunderstand me, these options are great but I would not be who I am today without the knowledge and experiences I learned from being involved on a college campus. By streamlining college events this app will begin to highlight the amazing things students and colleges are doing all over the country in an environmentally responsible way and will get more people excited about being involved on campus and experiencing college life.

Check out a few links:

http://theyardevents.com

http://www.bizjournals.com/memphis/news/2013/11/06/university-of-memphis-hosts.html?page=all

My name is Brian and I am an engineer, entrepreneur, and exciting person! I was inspired to build an app that promotes college events to students no matter their institution, interests, or social connections! I am partnering with various student organizations to ensure that this app will deliver an effective voice and platform to promote every campus event. What?Raising funds for design, testing, and development of "theYard Event Stream App" iOS version only.  When?Now. The app is already designed. Once the capital is available, the process of development and testing will begin. The target app launch date is August 2014.Where?There are no restrictions on the locations for this app. Colleges and Student Organizations will be approved to promote their events from day one no matter their location or enrollment.Why?
1. Reduce Paper "Flyer" Waste
"If you hand out flyers they usually will end up unread or in the trash." 
Walking around campus I see a ton of flyers, posters, and other forms of traditional advertising (many of which are old) laying around polluting the walkways and bathrooms. I did my research and I found that most student organizations have difficulty promoting events to a large number of students effectively. This form of promotion is not efficient in this day and age of digital advertising. The benefits
are outweighed by its lack of environmental sustainability because flyers have
a higher financial and environmental footprint. The worst part about all this
is that to be so ineffective (10% of flyers are used ineffectively), flyers
cause literally tons of waste on campus.
2. Target Promoting for College Events
"I usually send hundreds of invites to my Facebook friends and Twitter followers."
- student organization member
Sure there is Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and the like but the point of having events is to expand and reach new people. There is still no app where you can promote events easily to those not already in your social circle. 
3. Discovering/Filtering Events
"I have no idea what's going on around campus if my friends don't tell me"
- student 
It's not always easy finding things to do. When you visit other campuses, road trip to another school, go on spring break, just transferred schools, or maybe you are just a freshman new to campus. In these cases what can you easily do to find interesting activities or events on campus? theYard will not only allow you to discover these events but, you will also be able to filter them so that you can get to the ones you will actually participate in!
4. Better Event Features
Sure posting events is great but theYard Event Stream App will strive to be more useful and insightful. By using our app you will be able to know more about your attendees, make better decisions, and target interested people for your event.

I want not only to build an app, I want to build a movement. Whether you know it or not, traditional college life is becoming less and less sustainable both financially and environmentally. Online courses and online degrees are becoming more and more common. Don't misunderstand me, these options are great but I would not be who I am today without the knowledge and experiences I learned from being involved on a college campus. By streamlining college events this app will begin to highlight the amazing things students and colleges are doing all over the country in an environmentally responsible way and will get more people excited about being involved on campus and experiencing college life.Check out a few links:http://theyardevents.comhttp://www.bizjournals.com/memphis/news/2013/11/06/university-of-memphis-hosts.html?page=all

story:
AllMaia’s goal is to promote the exchange of ideas, cultures, and philosophies among people around the globe.

 

With your support we can start by bridging the gap between American and Chinese youth.

Where We Come From

AllMaia was conceptualized in a Boston University dorm room where our co-founders, Jimmy Hu and Zak Eisenberg, were roommates. They quickly became friends, bonding through discussions about the differences between their cultures. Jimmy, a native of Nanjing, China, and Zak, from New York, had different upbringings, but shared the desire to learn about the world. Like Jimmy and Zak, students desire to learn about and experience the intricacies of societies that are not their own. AllMaia’s goal is to inculcate American youth with a true understanding of China, an important global power.

 

Where We’ve Been: American Educators to China

More than 100 Chinese students attended AllMaia Global Conferences. Hosted in Nanjing, China, this past summer. The conferences brought American thinking, culture, and people to China. Lectures, discussions, and cultural activities during two, five-day, conferences challenged Chinese youth to explore new methods of critical thinking.

Our three pillars, Creativity, Social Sciences, and Ethics, gave students a holistic view of American society. Lectures surveyed American approaches to creative problem solving, political decision-making, and ethical dilemmas. Interactive discussions complemented lecture content, providing students a platform to debate contemporary world issues. Cultural activities completed our curriculum. Chinese students experienced American cultural activities, including music and card games. Throughout the process, we posed pressing world problems to student groups who then used the knowledge and tools acquired through the AllMaia curriculum to find solutions. In presentations, groups shared their solutions to issues including the international education gap, noise pollution, and overpopulation.

Imbedded in the AllMaia Global Youth Conferences were opportunities for Chinese students and American staff to interact and share their cultures. Each five-day conference concluded with a culture show where students showcased individual talents and Chinese traditions. (Video clips of performances are located in the Gallery.)

 

Where We’re Going: American Students to China

Study abroad is a unique component of college education. For many, this is the first experience of life outside the United States. Educational programs afford opportunities to learn about history, traditions, and culture. AllMaia will bring these rich components of a study-abroad program to high school students in an accelerated ten-day immersion experience.

Incorporating the fundamental aspects of study-abroad, academia and culture, AllMaia will go one step further, exposing students to the inner workings of Chinese business. Practicality will be at the core of our curriculum. Experience and knowledge acquired through lectures, panel discussions, and interactions with Chinese professionals will give students a multidimensional understanding of Chinese society.

Students will receive lectures from Chinese college professors and have the opportunity to interact with Chinese students, fostering lifelong friendships. Challenging preconceived notions about each other, AllMaia’s activities will push American students and their Chinese counterparts to overcome differences while working together to solve problems. Visiting companies, observing operations, and learning Chinese business etiquette will provide insight into the Chinese business world. Visiting historical sites and social centers, trying new cuisine, and participating in community service will complete AllMaia’s holistic approach to education through immersion.

 

Where The Funding Goes

We need $18,000 to finance operational costs for the second phase of AllMaia’s education through immersion programming.

This includes:

  • Deposits for flights
  • Deposits for logistics in China (classrooms, hotel, transportation, etc.)
  • Payment for programming in China (lecturers, etc.)
  • Outreach programs in the U.S.A.

 

IDEAS. CULTURES. PHILOSOPHIES.

                                         www.AllMaia.com

story:
This Campaign has ended but you can still donate to www.lighthousemuseum.org

We are ready to go, we  need your support to open the National Lighthouse Museum on Staten Island, New York City 

“"Lighthouse beacons continue to burn bright, guiding distressed ships to safety. ~ Tom Baker”

Raising the sizable sum of money needed has been left almost entirely to the directors and loyal supporters of the St. George Staten Island plan. And it’s an increasingly heavy lift. 

The museum has a new board with new energy and ideas, but it’s plagued with the same problem it has always had. What this project has always needed is backers with deep pockets. So far, they haven’t materialized but that wont deter the mission to open.

The goal is high because it's expensive to build a tribute to lighthouses & maritime history New York City located at  the original site of the US Light House Services General Depot in the mid 1800's, servicing all lighthouse operations in the nation.

We are  targeting a Summer 2013 opening of the U. S. National Lighthouse Museum's Educational Resource Center to be located in New York near the Staten Island Ferry Terminal on Staten Island, New York City; and can't do it without your support!

In 2010 a group of Lighthouse Preservationists and Maritime historians revived the charter to build the National Lighthouse Museum on Staten Island NY.   They raised a good deal of money and now need $600,000 for design/ display development, fabrication and construction; and another $400,000 for initial operations including equipment and program expenses to launch the Center. Almost $180,000 has been raised so far with a pro bono crew of dedicated volunteers moving this museum forward rapidly in the last two years.

Check out the column in the Staten Island Advance:

http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2010/10/islander_aims_to_refocus_atten.html#pd_a_3866960

Who we are:

The Board of Trustees are a group dedicated to the preservation of Lighthouses and US Maritime History.  Their goal is to build the National Lighthouse Museum on Staten Island New York.

 Executve Director Linda C. Dianto, MS

President Jack Vokral,PE

1st Vice President Captain Joseph Ahlstrom, Prof. SUNY Maritime

2nd Vice President John Arntzen, Pres. ACTA Maritime Development

Treasurer Richard M. Prinzi, Jr., CPA

Secretary Maryann Piazza, Majestic Vending, Inc.  

Members:

Chris Bendow, Esq.   Charles Di Bartolo, Pres. BetterBizWorks, Inc   Jim Dunlap LCDR USCG (Ret.) Fresnel Lens/Lighthouse Preservationist   Ralph Eshleman, PhD, Museum Director (Ret.)   Paul Foster, Esq., Playwright   Bruce Liozzi, Officer, Bay St. Landing Board   Aaron Luwisch, Owner, Victory Sports Arena   Alexander Psomas, CFA   Captain Thomas Walsh, Sandy Hook Pilots   Wayne Wheeler, Pres. US Lighthouse Society   Robert Williams, Prof., Wagner College

 This location is the original site of the US Light House Services General Depot in the mid 1800's, servicing all lighthouse operations in the nation. The navigational history of this site as the "Mother Ship" of lighthouses nationwide is vital to preserve and educate future generations to come on their purposes.

Currently, architects have designed an innovative Lighthouse Resource Center to initiate our project and the group will seek grants from organizations such as the National Trust for Historic Preservation and Saving America's Treasures to help us with further museum development.

The structures that remain today are the 1864 Workshop, the 1864 Storage Vaults, the 1868 Lampshop, the 1869 Administration Building, the 1884 Workshop, the 1902 Lampshop (now called Building 10), and the 1915 Foundry (now called Building 11). In 1991 JHPA prepared a conditions assessment and adaptive reuse study for the complex resulting in the stabilization of two historic structures. In 2000 JHPA prepared construction documents for the New York City Economic Development Corporation which included a complete exterior restoration and interior build-out of Building 11 along with an exterior restoration of Building 10. Construction was completed in 2005.


Shortly after opening, we will continue our mission in developing an an adjacent, far-larger building on the 10-acre city site and would require a major interior renovation and an investment of some $15 million.

The National Lighthouse Museum expects to attract many of the two million tourists yearly, who take the Staten Island Ferry, which docks a short distance from the old depot. In addition, plans are to introduce the maritime world to classes of children through regular class trips - teaching physics, history, geography, geometry and economics in a unique and exciting way.
The US coastlines and its environs have over 600 lighthouses of the 15,000 worldwide and due to modern navigational technology, many are endangered of being lost, decommissioned and abandoned...preservation is key!

In the past, merchants and seamen frustrated with shipwrecks due to the inability to navigate US coastlines requested more lighthouses be built - basically lighthouses were like the superhighways of the 1800's, allowing ships to navigate up and down the coasts and harbors with the guiding lights of the lighthouses, avoiding navigational disasters.

We are a 501-c3 charitable organization and all donations are tax deductible

You can also go to www.lighthousemuseum.org and click on "Donate" at the top right of the page. All donations go directly to support building the National Lighthouse Museum.

Visit us on Facebook at: www.facebook.com/NationalLighthouseMuseum or

Follow us on Twitter at @NLMSINY US Lighthouse Museum www.twitter.com/nlmsiny

Thank you for your time and consideration!

story:
Our Story

We are the New Democratic Youth of Prince Edward Island.  For the first time our numbers are really growing and we want to start building a viable third party here on PEI.  We want to send 20 of our members to the Federal NDP Leadership Convention in Toronto on March 23-24 to show our fellow members on the national level that we are here and ready to work together for a better Canada.  

The Impact

With a successful campaign we will be able to send a strong delegation of NDP of PEI youth members to a National Convention for the first time.  We have the opportunity to start building from the ground up a talented group of young members interested in getting involved in the party on a provincial level.  Our growth has already begun and this amount of interest in the party is a first for the Island.   Please help us grow.  


What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise enough money for group transportation and accommodation to and from Toronto from PEI for 20 of our youth delegates.  All money, raised regardless of if we reach our total goal, will go directly towards transportation and accommodation costs for this trip.  Any additional money will be used to further build the youth wing on PEI at our Provincial Convention in April.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us in any way you can! The party on PEI is building and begin to shape a viable alternative to the 2 party system currently in place here.  Please send this link to NDP members and supporters across the country through email, facebook, twitter, anything.  Change will happen here, please help us and be a part of it!

story:
Hi!  My name is Michelle Shaw and I live in the beautiful state of Maine.  In July of 2007, my husband and I traveled to Vietnam to adopt our daughter.  Since then we have been blessed with so much joy and happiness, and in October 2011 our family was finally complete when we adopted our daughter from China. 

The beauty of Vietnam is astounding, but sadly the poverty is equally striking.  Upon returning home we wanted to do something to make a difference in Vietnam and searched the web for organizations truly making a difference in the lives of families there.  When we found Families In Vietnam, we knew we'd found the organization we wanted to be connected to.  They have aided families in Vietnam on so many levels, and their commitment is unsurpassed.  Through their sponsorship program we have provided support for a boy to attend school for the past three years. 

Families In Vietnam President, Christen Buchert, travels to Vietnam each year bringing care packages, checking on each family and assessing their needs, etc.  This year we hope her luggage will include an additional two suitcases filled with sneakers stuffed with two pair of socks each. Sadly, having a pair of shoes is a luxury for many children, and we hope to change that for as many as we can.  Should we exceed our goal, the additional funds will be used to purchase much needed clothing for children in Vietnam.

We greatly appreciate any help you can give to help us reach our goal!  If you are unable to help out financially, please help by spreading the word about our fundraiser and the great work that Families In Vietnam does.

With Much Gratitude,

Michelle Shaw
