story:
Helping Kindergarteners Tell Stories Through Their Own Lens 

My name is Rebecca Crook and I have the privilege of teaching bilingual kindergarten in Richmond, California. My ultimate goal as a teacher is to foster and help develop the skills and mindsets my students need to realize their dreams, even in the face of many individual and institutional factors working to hold them back: including poverty, racism, classism, and immigration status. To this end, my kindergarteners work hard to hone their abilities to read, write, question, add, subtract, etc. so that they will be prepared for the academic challenges and opportunities that lie ahead. Equally important to their holistic development is their ability to think critically and express themselves creatively. Each 5 year-old has unique and beautiful narratives and perspectives that I fear get squashed in evermore regimented and test-driven schools.

 A new project for 2013 and many years to come is the integration of photography into our classroom. Inspired by projects in the US and abroad (check out Critical Exposure, Kids with Cameras, Literacy Through Photography), our classroom seeks to use photography as a platform for storytelling, self-expression, and creativity. The creation of images will empower each student to develop their voice and to find power in its expression. Writing and speaking about their images will give students new opportunities to apply academic skills. Photography also aids the development of fine motor skills, spatial perception, problem-solving skills,shape and color recognition and technology literacy. By donating you are making a powerful and transformative investment in the lives of young children's creative and cognitive abilities, as well as in their self esteem.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are in need of a class set of digital cameras.  The 28 refurbished Nikon cameras will be purchased for $60 a piece.  Each child will receive instruction on basic technical aspects of photography and learn to use and care for the cameras.  

We are so grateful for your partnership in this endeavor to enrich our learning experiences.  As a donor you can receive our thanks in the form of various gifts according to the amount of your donation (Post cards! Hand written notes from a kindergartener! Thank you video! Photographs signed by a young artist!) We will also be sure to invite you to our class photo exhibition in Spring 2013.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! If you know others who may be interested in supporting the integration of photography into education please share this project with them. For any questions or encouragement, I can be reached at rcrook03@gmail.com. THANK YOU for supporting education in Richmond. I am excited for the stories, photos and growth that will result from your generosity.

With gratitude,

Rebecca Crook

story:
Hello Friends, Family and People touched by the Berry family story:

I decided to start this crowdfunding college tuition campaign for Will and Wendy's four kids as it was the best way I could think to give back to a family who has lost their dad.  I can't imagine the pain and sorrow that Will's family is going through right now and asking for money from friends & family is the last thing they need to be doing.

Using the GET WA tuition program, it will cost $90,000 to purchase 500 credits at $179/credit per child at today's tuition rate. This will fully pay for tuition, books, room/board at UW, WSU or can applied to any other qualified college in the U.S. when the the first Berry child graduates high school.
 
My personal connection to the Berry family is through Will's younger brother, Jason and his wife Donna.  The Berrys are adventurers - hiking, fishing, skiing, boating - anything that has to do with the outdoors.  I've experienced the beauty of Scottish Lakes High Camp with Jason.  This is where Will's tragic fall happened while hiking back to High Camp with his son, Finn from what I'm sure was a fun day fishing on an alpine lake.  
 
I've never set up a charity or run a donation before but have smart friends who are giving me advice on how raise $90,000 (or more!) over the next few weeks.  We need to raise another $270,000 to send all four kids to college but this is the first step.
 
I guarantee all of this money will go directly to the Poppa Bear Memorial College Fund at WSECU but wanted to create an easier way to give online in remembrance of Will.
 
Please visit Will's Facebook page that his family set up to share your own picture or story and tweet, share, post, bug everyone you know to help support this cause.
 
Thanks again you for your donation!  If you have questions or concerns, please contact me on my Facebook page below. 
 
Best,
Jason Milstead

story:
Hello my name is Content,

Please help me raise the last amount of money I need to send my son Jonathan to a Sober Living program.

I got a generous grant from a foundation for ten thousand dollars to help pay for the cost of the program. So now all I need is twenty five thousand more to raise.

Jonathan is seventeen year old and struggles with ADHD and Bipolar disorder. This past year Jonathan got himself into a bad situation. He was using drugs, selling drugs and hanging out with the wrong people.

Jonathan just completed a rehab program. He is home now and in a IOP program but is having a very hard time staying sober. And feels he needs to go to a sober living program to have long term success.

The program Jonathan and I like is Turning Point in Haven Connecticut. It is a structured yet supportive environment where residents are given the time, tools and support to continue healing while developing a lifestyle free of drugs and alcohol. They also help them finish school and get jobs. So they can become self-sufficient.

Please Donate to help me send Jonathan to Turning Point in Haven Connecticut. So he can stay on the right path and stay away from Drugs and Alcohol!

 

Thank You from the bottom of my heart,

Content Sasso

story:
We felt like we needed to act fast on this. These poor people will not have houses to come back to. My wife and I own a popular store in Manchester nh Level up gaming. www.levelupnh.com I will be heading out there in 10 days to find and help these people out as best as I can. I will contact the red cross to find out who needs the money. I will personally hand the checks over to the people in need. It could take 30-90 days for these people to get insurance checks! They need help now not later. The worse is not even here yet...

 

Only thing I can offer for a donation is a picture of the people you have helped threw this crisis. I will go out there either way as I have a few skills and some time to donate. If you can not give here please contact the red cross in Colorado Springs  and ask how you can help them..

story:
* note please do not buy yet as we need to make some changes to our campain funding type, i chose the wrong funding type and it cant be  be changed without starting a new campain all those who have paid will be reimbursed 

Our Story 

Our skills sets lie in developing electronic solutions for automating refrigeration systems for the HVAC&R industry. Due to the propriety nature of the business our projects are unfortunately always closed source not to mention expensive. But we were so inspired by the open source nature and price point of the Raspberry Pi  project that we wanted to give back something to the community. After a bit of research we found that while there  were a lot of add-ons they were fairly limited in peripherals and lacked the peripherals needed for home automation projects. So if your in the process of automating your home and you want to use the Raspberry Pi to do it then the PIC PI offers an affordable solution for you.  

Raspberry PI open source Software 

The pic chip will come pre-programmed (this software will be open source too) and all the control of the PIC Pi hardware can be achieved easily though Programming the Raspberry PI using the python libraries developed for the PIC PI hardware. In the future we will also be writing bash commands for  Raspbain to control the PIC PI hardware. If you have a Micorchip programmer you will also be able to write your own code for the pic chip . Here is a link to the python API    

PIC Pi open source Hardware 

Schematic

1 x RS232

1x RS485

1x Real Time Clock 

2x 240Vac Relays rated to 10A

2x Analog Outputs 0-10V

22x Pins individually settable as Analog inputs or Digital Outputs 

Production Ready Unit 

We have a Production ready unit, the hardware is 100% tested and working. We have the Software is 100% finished and tested for functionality. 

What can i do with it ?

Once we have finished the PIC PI Python hardware libraries we will work on developing some open source applications here are some of the projects we will be working on  

- Switching lights over the internet 

- Web controlled thermostat 

- Web controlled pet feeder 

How can i help

I would love to get this product off the ground, but i dont have enough money to cover the intial start up costs of a build ie stencil, surface mount machine programming, board assembly. If i get enough interest then i will be able to afford the first build of this product and get the ball rolling if not the i cannot afford to make this product avaliable to the public. 

Production plan

We will be outsourcing the manufacturing to ACD in Melbourne we have had a long relationship with them and we trust there quality of manufacturing. If we reach our target we will run a build this should take around a week.

Shipping

We will be handling all the shipping though our dispatch team in our existing company which mean reliable fast delivery worldwide shipping is included in the cost

story: I’m Tremaine Wheaton and I’m a sophomore majoring in fashion design at the Academy of Art University. I currently hold a 3.67 GPA and am loved by my teachers for my drive and creativity. In addition to school I have volunteered at SMAAC youth center and APEB. I live at home, my moms a single parent and finances aren’t always the most orderly to say the least, but we get by. Recently I was informed that I had to pay the 2097 dollar balance before I could go back to school, but they told me that only two week before I had to go back. I tried reaching out to family, but being that we’re not the richest, no one really had the means to support. I tried to take out a loan and was denied. So the idea of a fundraiser was given to me and this has brought me to this point. The reasons I don’t want to miss spring semester are vast. It puts me into a position where I may graduate later than planned, I will have to spend extra money to take classes during the summer and not all of the classes that I would need before graduation are offered during summer intersession, If I’m not enrolled I can’t do work study this semester to make sure that I can pay the balance left for spring and I can’t apply for scholarships as they typically ask for verification of enrollment. One of my larger concerns is that my financial aid or eligibility for financial aid may be altered by missing this semester. Unfortunately I think missing school it would rob me of my competitive edge in school not only might I, myself, lose momentum, but I would not be able to, like my peer, utilize the summer to advance my career by doing internships and while most of my peers are getting ready to graduate by portfolio building or working on collections, I will be spending my summers playing catch-up!

story:
This summer, more than 40 future LGBTQ pastors will travel to the mountains of Georgia to find community, training, and hope. The process to become an ordained pastor in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) is anything but easy. But when you’re lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or queer it is significantly more difficult, especially if you try it alone. 

Eight years ago Presbyterian Welcome, a New York City-based non-profit working for LGBTQ inclusion in the church and beyond, established an annual retreat. We are dedicated to making sure that every LGBTQ future pastor in the country has the support they need as they pursue ordained ministry.

“This retreat sustained me in a way that is hard to describe. We are able to be fully the children of God that God created us to be. We can worship, laugh, cry, talk and connect in ways that do not happen anywhere else. Thank you for making this possible.”

In our community, which connects online year-round, there are about 100 future pastors at various stages in the ordination process. Some are attending seminary. Some are working in churches and hospitals. And some, because they are LGBTQ, are kept from working in ministry. Though LGBTQ persons can now legally be ordained in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), many regions of the country still refuse to bless their ministries. 

“The retreat has reminded me that I’m not alone and renewed me in my ministry.”

The retreat offers a space where LGBTQ future pastors can discern how to move forward in their ordination processes. We also build hard and fast skills for current and future ministry and hear from LGBTQ clergy who have gone before us. Most of all, we find strength for the journey in knowing that we are never alone.

“It helps me remember why I am staying in the PC(USA).”

For the past eight years, a handful of churches have provided support for the retreat. But our numbers have grown so that we need more support from more people. We need your help to inspire and encourage this generation of LGBTQ Presbyterian pastors.

“The Presbyterian Welcome retreat is the place where I can be my most authentic self and learn to be that self out in the world.”

Through this campaign we are asking for $10,000 (out of a total of $50,000). The  portion you help us raise will cover the cost of the retreat center and airfare, which enables many who are students to attend. In exchange for your support, we're offering all kinds of ways to connect with our community, which you can read more about to the right. 

“The retreat has expanded my vision to know that I will see and get to the promised land.” 

By supporting this retreat, you are helping birth a new age for the Church, who so desperately needs the ministries of these brave souls.

Contributions to Presbyterian Welcome are tax deductible less the value of any goods or services received, as allowed by law.

All Photos From THEYbklyn.

story:
This summer I am venturing to Malawi to volunteer in a rural village school. During my time there i will not only be teaching but helping the school develop. Currently the school  does not have the resources or able adults to provide the children with a basic education.  The children living in the surrounding areas of the school are from very poor families or orphans, due to the high levels of adults dying from aids. Many of the children eat only one meal a day, a dish called Nsima which is flour and water mixed together and boiled. 

The fund raising I am doing will allow me to make a significant difference to the lives of these children. Money to buy resources such as books,pencils and paper so the children can learn to read and write. Also just ten pounds can feed all the children a nutritional meal at school for a week. I am hoping to raise enough money to fund this while I am out there and also for it to be sustained after I leave.

Thankyou to anybody who donates,it will make such a difference to these children's lives.

story:
Press Release
   English  French  Spanish  German

The goal
LudoSchool's goal is to offer 1 billion children and their families free and easy access to innovative educational games so they can learn the four keys skills : reading, writing, counting, calculating.
These four keys skills

- represent the essential part of a child's education
- they are key for an adult to learn a trade
- and finally, they are necessary for a country's economic and social development

LudoSchool educational games improve learning :
- they Promote intuitive learning
- they Develop autonomy
- and finally they reflect a child's learning rhythm

LudoSchool wants to change things
- 300 million primary school aged children can not read or write
- 600 million children have to learn in unacceptable learning conditions
- girls are often excluded from education
- a majority of families are not able to properly follow their child through their education.

To be this succesful, we did a good job
In order to be successful in our mission we have done a lot of work. LudoSchool has already ten educational games used in over fifty countries in 4 languages available on the AppStore. All these games are designed for children between 2 and 10 years, but they are also interesting for all ages, whatever the skills, the maturity, the origins or beliefs.

LudoSchool games are international
Share of downloads per region
40% North America (USA, Canada)
30% Europe (United Kingdom, France, Germany, Spain..)
10% The Pacific (Australia, New Zealand)
10% South America (Mexico,Argentina,Brazil)
10% The Rest of World (Africa, Asia)

Why Indiegogo ?
LudoSchool is a project for children, a project for families and for school.
The project is of interest for all countries. It seemed natural to me to chose Indiegogo, to share this project with the most amount of people around the world.

Why 1 billion Children ?
There are between 2 and 3 billion people who speak one of these following 4 languages fluently (english, spanish, french, german). This represeents more or less 1.5 billion children. 1 billion is both a idealistic number and a realistic goal.

Why not 4 billion children ?
Yes why not...It's question of time and means, but I am not excluding the idea of extending this project to Asia. I have taken some Chinese lessons. I don't see any major obstacles. It could be a new goal in 2014.

Is technology an obstacle ?
No it is not an obstacle, even in Africa which is today a fast moving
continent. The majority of people on this planet now have a phone, have access to a TV. Networks are developing quickly and now extend accross Africa. Cheap smartphones and tablets are arriving in high numbers. I am particularly aware of the situation in Africa and the project is naturally also for this region of the world.

You can trust the project
Well, we have already done a good job.. And thanks to our educational background (bachelor sociology, master computer science, business adminisration) and our experience in the business world, we have an excellent Understanding of the world of education and the innovations currently unfolding in this domain. Our future games are dedicating to reading and counting. The reading method is particularly innovative ... I should say revolutionary!
You can also trust this project because, when I was a child I felt school usuelly boring. So when we create a new game I have always in mind it must help children and give the keys to learn better.

About the budget
Ten educational games is not enough ...
Because to provide one billion children with free access to these skills,the project must move faster and go further. That's why ludoschool need to finance fifteen new games dedicated to reading and calculation. As we are determined to reach our goal, with your support this project can go further and faster.

You have the power to change the world for 1 Billion children
Your donation will help finance new games and every dollar sponsors one thousand children with free access to the four key kills.
For example a donation of 5$ equals basic for 5 000 children.
So each 1$ is a great gift, and it becomes an educational game for all children.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Max Byer, a 10th grader at the McLean School of Maryland. I want to start a school newspaper for the McLean Community. Journalism is my passion; I want to reflect that passion on the school that I love and owe so much to. I need YOI in order to gain the funds for the service to host the site. 

I am asking for 600 dollars to reach this funding. That is the minimum I need in order to start the paper and acheive my dream. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, if you can't contribute, please take 5 seconds to share this with friends and family however possible: Facebook, Twitter, anything!

I am asking for 600 dollars to reach this funding. That is the minimum I need in order to start the paper and acheive my dream. 
Other Ways You Can Help


Please, if you can't contribute, please take 5 seconds to share this with friends and family however possible: Facebook, Twitter, anything!

story:
We are a small Catholic elementary school with a big heart. In fact, in our area we are known as “The Little School That Could”. In 2012 against the odds we raised the money and created a plan to stay open when faced with closing. We “Prayed like it all depended on God, and worked like it all depended on us”. Our prayers were answered, and we are taking this great blessing we’ve been given and working the plan. Part of that is adding a preschool to our campus.

      Our playground is in dire need of a fence. It is bordered on one side by a street and another by an alley with only a chain put up to block cars during recess. While we have a vigilant cadre of staff and volunteers supervising recess, we need to make it safer for the very young children we will be welcoming next year. Younger children are often unaware of the danger posed by vehicles and are much safer playing in an enclosed area which can be more closely supervised.

      Also, next year we will have several students on the Autism spectrum who tend to wander away when upset. Bolting and wandering are the leading cause of death among Autistic children.  A fenced playground would deter wandering children and help ensure their safety.

       In addition, we want to make our playground more inviting and fun for students with physical disabilities. Remember waiting in line for your turn on the swings? What if it was never your turn, because you couldn’t use the swing safely? One of our students, Mady, has cerebral palsy, and has outgrown a swing provided by her parents. We want to install a swing that will be fun for her right through 6th grade, and that other students will be excited to use. Not her “special” swing, but everybody’s swing.

       At St. Boniface Catholic School, we want all children to feel safe and welcome… and to have fun. You can be a part of that.

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

       We need $5,000 to add a fence and swing to our playground. The project cost for the fence is $3,784 for materials, $1,960 for installation. The swing we would like to purchase is a Jennswing, which includes the swing, safety harness and chains to hang it from a frame we already have. It is priced at $499. We have raised about $1,000 already.

       If we don’t meet our entire goal, in the interest of safety for all the children, the money will go toward installing a fence. (But our fundraising will continue- Mady’s getting that swing!)

       In addition to the satisfaction of knowing you've made the world a little safer, a little more compassionate and a lot more fun, we have some thank you gifts to show our appreciation for supporting our school. Our students are our greatest ambassadors, and their personal touch and talent comes through in everything from a hand-written thank-you note to a St. Boniface family portrait, autographed by all our students.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't donate at this time, that's ok. You can help in other ways:

PRAY, PRAY, PRAY for our school and campaign. It works!

SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT US. Go out to all the world...and tell them about the St. Boniface S.A.F.E. Playground Project! Talk us up to people you know. Post us on your Facebook page. Text us up to whoever you text to. Spread the word to anyone who believes in faith-based schools, safe playgrounds, and swings for everybody!

story:
About us

The Summerhouse is a unique 501(c)(3) non-profit organization focused on developing the skills of young adults with intellectual disabilities in order to support active, engaged lives.  The mission of The Summerhouse is to provide customized programs for young adults with intellectual disabilities where individuals feel valued, respected, and are contributing members of society.

Our focus at The Summerhouse is in three parts: vocational or work-related tasks, activities of daily living, and community involvement.  This campaign is focused specifically on the vocational component of our program.  Through Shred for Independence clients learn valuable skills necessary for holding a job: consistency, follow-through, and persistence.  In addition, they learn to value themselves as important members of a team.  Without each member of our team, the work does not get done.  They feel productive and successful – because they are.

For more information you can visit our website at www.shredforindependence.com or The Summerhouse website at www.summerhousehouston.org.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need new and improved shredders to keep up with customer demand.  We currently have 3 shredders that often overheat after short periods of use.  With your help we will purchase 3 new microcut shredders with continuously running motors that do not overheat.

With your donation, you get one of the perks listed on this page in addition to knowing that you have positively influenced the lives of young adults with intellectual disabilities.

The Impact

Shred for Independence mission is to increase the employment rate of young adults with intellectual disabilities by providing vocational rehabilitiation services.  Your donation allows us to continue this mission by teaching important work skills to our clients.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate at this time, there are other ways to help:

  • forward this on to others who may be able to donate using Indiegogo share options
  • if you are in the Houston area and need shredding services check out our website at www.shredforindependence.com

story:
Short Summary

My name is Yvonne Shortt. Five years ago the Rego Park Green Alliance was founded because a First Lego League robotics team and I wanted to have a long lasting impact on our community. We were upset because of the dirt and graffiti that littered our streets.  And, because of this, the Garden and Mural program was created. All of our murals are painted by hundreds of people working collaboratively who live in the community. Our gardens are planned and seeded by kids and adults with input from the community. Cooperation and collaboration are key. Each garden and mural project takes months of planning but it has changed people at their core. Liter and graffiti have lessened, collaboration is up, we are more aware of what we eat, we now know how to plant and maintain a vegetable garden, and we all are more appreciative of nature. And, because of our work others have been inspired. We now have a beautiful new playground, and more trash cans in our community.

Our program has been so successful mobilizing the community that our gardens and murals have been featured nationally, we participated in a public service announcement at the bequest of the NYC Mayor's Office, school capital construction campaigns have taken place after our garden programs have shown real community interest, community investments of over 20,000, and we wrote a book that is available at several public libraries in NYC and Connecticut.

We are engaging the community and demonstrating that every person can be a catalyst for meaningful change.  

And, now we want to  grow our program by fixing up another school in Queens!

What We Need 

  • 4 planters for planting a garden. We use planters because in many cases blocking off a section of the schoolyard doesn't protect the garden from footballs, basketballs, and the general things that can cause havoc in a city garden.  
  • Soil to fill the planters
  • Paint (200-500 square feet), painter cans, gloves, towels, brushes, markers, chalk, and more
  • Stipend for the artist(s)
  • Administrative cost charged by our fiscal sponsor. All donations are tax deductable!

Our Impact To Date

  • Over 2500 children and adults have painted a wall or created a garden in their community. For many, this was the first time they planted a vegetable or took part in a group paint day.
  • $20,000 of community investments because of our coolaborations with small businesses and the citty.  Everything from fixing cracked sidewalks to installing cement on an underpass that was so tiny people had to form a stop lane to walk under it.
  • A new schoolyard costing over 160,000 becsause of our ability to collaborate and motivate
  • Our produce has been donated to those in need. This reinforces the importance of children/adults helping others. Children have also eaten the food they have grown, reinforcing the importance of eating healthy.
  • Once installed, the gardens are planted every year.
  • 2 of our murals have never been graffitied after installation. 
  • Kids have stepped into leadership roles. In cases where the wall was graffittii'ed they painted over the graffiti. When someone broke trellises the kids fixed them. 
  • Adults have seen the call of the community and stepped in with capital campaigns to make major improvements to our playgrounds and streets.
  • We have participated in local and nationally televised newscasts demonstrating how youth can make a difference and hopefully inspiring millions of others to get involved.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Let other people know about our project.
  • If you own a paint company or wood company and you are in the giving mood, we can be so there!
  • Send others an email link to our campaign.  If we have learned one thing it is we are nothing without help!

 

The Rego Park Green Alliance is Fiscally Sponsored By The Open Space Institute,Inc., As part of its Citizen Action Program

story:
The World Peace College at Neve Shalom/Wahat al-Salam (NSWAS), the "Oasis of Peace"

We recently lost a dynamic educator and advocate for peace to a tragic and untimely accident. Ahmad Hijazi and his son Adam (age 9) were killed in a car accident while on vacation in Zanzibar on August 20, 2012.

Ahmad Hijazi, the Director of the NSWAS School for Peace, oversaw all programs of the School, including EU and USAID-sponsored programs targeting Israeli and Palestinian professionals, youth encounters, university courses and facilitator training. He also directly implemented and facilitated many of these programs.

For the past year, Ahmad had been developing a major program, the World Peace College at NSWAS. This program, in partnership with the American Friends of Neve Shalom/Wahat al-Salam (AFNSWAS) will be the first college in the Middle East focusing specifically on the study of peace. The college is scheduled to launch in Fall of 2013 and support of this campaign is to provide economic support for programs, scholarships, library support, and technological infrastructure to make the World Peace College the epicenter of peace education in the Middle East. 

 

The World Peace College at Neve Shalom/What al-Salam

The American Friends of NSWAS is working to launch a new Peace College in the "Oasis of Peace" centered in the Fred Segal Friendship Library. The mission of the college is to prepare skilled peace-builders to integrate theoretical models and practical experiences of conflict-reduction and peacebuilding in regions of conflict. The college will offer research-based, experiential teacher training program in bilingual/binational education and a research-based, experiential graduate (MA/MS) program of conflict reduction and peace building.  To build an academically rigorous institution, the college draws upon a unique critical perspective on inter-group conflict in the context of the reality of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and provides tools and skills for active engagement. The objectives are:

  • To prepare cadre of peace builders from and for the full range of socio-political frameworks,
  • To explicitly link theory and practice with critical perspective,
  • To integrate micro and macro levels of inter-group conflict, and 
  • To bridge relations between individual, group and community levels.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your “sphere of influence” and inspire change!

story:
I recently received a scholarship to be one of the first 20 students to pursue MBA in this university in Tokyo. It has always been a dream of mine to go to Japan, and now the dream has come true! 

But, Japan is an expensive country, and with not much savings, it looks like I will be starving and homeless!

In all honesty, I have always considered my friends as my family mainly. Maybe it is because I am not close to my family hence I am always looking out for my version of "family". And thankfully, I have always been lucky because my friends are AWESOME, I can always depend on them when I am in trouble. Because of this, I have always believed in paying back. Some might call it "paying it forward" but it is just me repaying my blessings by always keeping a hand open when a friend asks for help. I'm a big believer of paying kindness for kindness. So, I reached out, and with a little help from my friends, we set up a little campaign, titled, 5foraFriend.

So now, I'm reaching out further. I need help to raise this funds, and that is why, I am looking for YOU and YOUR FRIENDS to help me. I am only requesting for 5 because it is not a burdensome amount (of course, if you like me enough, I'd appreciate if you could please contribute more to get me to the goal faster). However, in order for this to work, I will need 4,000 generous people to contribute to the fund within this 2 months. So please, spare me your fiver and spread the world through the power of social media (also please hashtag it with #5foraFriend) and start a movement here with me! 

I know I know, many of you would ask, why should we contribute to this stranger who we barely even know. Well, imagine that one day at the mamak, you need a fiver to cover for your cup of coffee. I'm sure there would be people kind enough who would lend you that money and not expect anybody back. I want to believe that this is not an impossible scenario. 

I also want to keep this funding alive. From the comments from strangers that I have received, my case is not unique, and my cause is not totally alien. Hence, once I have reached the amount I need, the rest of the contributions will go to somebody else who might need it in the future. Now this is paying it forward. 

So please, open up your hearts and "DONATE". I need all the help I can get.

story:
A secessionist rebellion that began in Mali's north early this year, and the ensuing fighting that occurred between the rebel group and the Malian army, produced several hundred thousand internally displaced persons and refugees. The rebellion was eventually hijacked by armed Islamist groups who currently control the north of the country. 

A peaceful resolution is looking increasingly unlikely and there is a real possibility of armed intervention. In any case, the refugee situation persists.  

I am trying to raise $1,000 for Relief International, an organization that is providing humanitarian support for Malian refugees in Niger. If the campaign is funded, I will teach 100 different people how to draw camels in a 24 hour period in Bamako, Mali. I will document this process and the video will be available to backers of the campaign. 

The money raised by this campaign goes directly to the Relief International paypal account. Any amount raised over $1,000 will also go directly to Relief International. 

Why Camel Drawing?

For more information on why I believe so strongly in camel drawing, please see the video above. You can also visit my website http://howtodrawcamels.com and http://philintheblank.net. Do not take the camel drawing too seriously, please.

Why Relief International? 

Relief International was initially recommended to me by a friend who was familiar with their work. After learning more about their efforts, which are holistic and exhaustive in nature, I spoke directly to a RI representative and was once more encouraged by the organization. 

To get a sense for their approach, I recommend reading this PDF report that they released in July: 

http://www.ri.org/files/uploads/RI_Mali_Refugees_in_Tahoua_Niger_Assessment_Report.pdf 

The money from this campaign is specifically targeted to go to Relief International's support of Malian refugees. 

For more information on the situation in Mali...

Quality reporting on Mali has been limited, but there are a number of journalists, analysts and researchers who have been providing valuable information on the situation. 

I recommend reading this blog post from journalist Peter Tinti, which explains the hazy reporting situation while offering some key reads that provide a strong background on the current crisis: 

http://ptinti.com/2012/09/27/mali-must-reads/ 

I would also recommend following his twitter account (@petertinti) along with the following list of people who provide excellent analysis and reporting in English. 

@tweetsintheME 

@tommymiles

@HannahHaniya 

@ArnaudContreras  

@themoornextdoor

@JoePenney

@DG_Lewis

@7our

@katarinah 

If you speak French, I would also recommend: 

@Babahmed1

@fabienoff 

@fasokan

@ArnaudContreras

@Abdou_diarra

These lists are not comprehensive 

Help me complete an unprecedented camel drawing mission while supporting humanitarian efforts for Malian refugees. Even if you cannot donate, please consider sharing this campaign with someone (or everyone) that you know.
